Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Ãðàíèöû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êóëüòóðíàÿ àííåêñèÿ ãîðîäîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ãîðîä ñ âûñîêèì êóëüòóðíûì óðîâíåì ðàñïîëîæåí ðÿäîì ñ ìåíåå çíà÷èìûì ãîðîäîì, ïðèíàäëåæàùèì äðóãîé äåðæàâå, òî îí ïîä÷èíèò ñåáå ñîñåäà. Êàê ïðàâèëî, áîëåå ñèëüíûé ãîðîä ïðè ýòîì çàõâàòûâàåò çåìëþ ìåæäó ãîðîäàìè - à èíîãäà è âñþ òåððèòîðèþ âîêðóã âòîðîãî ãîðîäà. Ïîñëåäíåå ìîæåò ïðèâåñòè ê ãîëîäó â ïîä÷èíåííîì ãîðîäå, à â êðàéíåì ñëó÷àå - ê [LINK=CONCEPT_REVOLUTION]ïåðåâîðîòó[\LINK] è ïðèìûêàíèþ ê áîëåå êóëüòóðíî çíà÷èìîé äåðæàâå.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðåæäå ÷åì ïåðåéòè ê äîìèíèðóþùåé äåðæàâå, ãîðîä áóíòóåò äâàæäû. Ïîñëå ïåðâîãî áóíòà ãîðîä ïåðåõîäèò ïîä âëàñòü èñêîííîé äåðæàâû. Åãî âëàäåëåö ìîæåò ïîïûòàòüñÿ ïîâûñèòü êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü ãîðîäà, ÷òîáû èçáåæàòü âòîðîãî áóíòà. Åñëè ýòî íå óäàåòñÿ, òî ïîñëå âòîðîãî áóíòà ãîðîä ïåðåõîäèò ê äîìèíèðóþùåé äåðæàâå. Ïîñëå ýòîãî ãîðîä áóäåò àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ïðèíîñèòü âàì ïðèáûëü îò çäàíèé è ÷óäåñ, ÷òî äåëàåò êóëüòóðíîå çàâîåâàíèå êóäà áîëåå âûãîäíûì (ïóñòü è áåç òîãî ìîðàëüíîãî óäîâëåòâîðåíèÿ), ÷åì çàõâàò ñèëîé.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ê ïðàâèëó î êóëüòóðíîì çàõâàòå ãîðîäîâ ñóùåñòâóåò âàæíîå èñêëþ÷åíèå. Åñëè ãîðîä áûë çàõâà÷åí ñèëîé, îí íå ìîæåò ïåðåéòè ê èñêîííîìó âëàäåëüöó ïîñðåäñòâîì êóëüòóðíîãî âëèÿíèÿ. Âïðî÷åì, ïîñëåäíåå ìîæåò ñäåëàòü ãîðîä ïðàêòè÷åñêè áåñïîëåçíûì äëÿ çàõâàò÷èêà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ãîðîäà âàðâàðîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ó âàðâàðñêèõ ãîðîäîâ åñòü òàêîé æå óðîâåíü êóëüòóðû, êàê è ó âñåõ ïðî÷èõ. Èõ òàêæå ìîæíî çàõâàòûâàòü ïðè ïîìîùè êóëüòóðíîãî âëèÿíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Culture[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, "culture" refers to a civilization's accomplishments in literature, the arts, and so forth. Civilizations with high cultures are respected or envied by lesser civilizations. These civilizations tend to intellectually dominate their neighbors, which can be very useful when two civilizations are striving for control over limited terrain.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Generating Culture[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Culture is generated in [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK], and each city has its own cultural value. A new city, containing just a few citizens intent more upon survival than on anything else, generates very little culture. But once the city grows and begins to construct [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] dedicated to religion, arts, literature, and so on, its cultural output will increase. The city can further increase its cultural output by creating certain [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Specialists[\LINK], as well as by using [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK]. However, the greatest increase in culture can be gained through the construction of [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Culture Button[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Once you have discovered the [LINK=TECH_DRAMA]Drama[\LINK] technology, you can devote a certain percentage of your civilization's commerce to culture using the Culture Button. This can allow you to create culture in cities that have no buildings in them (although it may be expensive to do so!) The Culture Button also provides [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]Happiness[\LINK] in addition to culture; see the related Civilopedia entry for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Building Culture[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]After discovering the [LINK=TECH_MUSIC]Music[\LINK] technology, you can devote a city's production to the creation of culture. The city will not build anything, but it will produce culture.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Culture and City Defense[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]People fight harder when defending particularly holy, beautiful, or otherwise culturally-important cities. To reflect this, cities with high cultures get a "city defense bonus." This bonus increases as the city's culture grows. See [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Culture and Borders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city's cultural value determines the size of the land it dominates. See [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK] for details on this important effect.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cultural Conversion of Cities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If a culturally-superior city is near to another civilization's city which has little going for it culture-wise, the superior city will tend to dominate the inferior. This usually results in the superior city gaining control over the land between the two cities, and sometimes of all the land surrounding the inferior city. This can lead to starvation and, in extreme cases, of the inferior citizens [LINK=CONCEPT_REVOLUTION]Revolting[\LINK] from their civilization and joining the superior city's civilization.[PARAGRAPH:2]A city must revolt twice before it flips to the dominating civilization's control. The first time that the city revolts, it will eventually return to the original owner's control. The owner may then try to pump up the city's culture to avoid a second revolution: but if the owner is unsuccessful and the city revolts again, it will flip and join the dominant civilization's empire. When a city "flips" to your control, you automatically gain all of that city's buildings and great wonders, making this a far more profitable (if perhaps less satisfying) way of conquering a city than through direct force of arms.[PARAGRAPH:2]There is one exception to the above rule about cultural conversion: a city that has been captured militarily will never flip back to its original owner, no matter how much cultural pressure the original owner brings to bear (although it may be near-useless to the conqueror due to constant revolts).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Barbarian Cities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Barbarian cities have cultural values just like other cities. They too can be converted through cultural dominance.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Äèïëîìàòèÿ[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïî ìåðå òîãî êàê âàøè þíèòû [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]èññëåäóþò[\LINK] òåððèòîðèþ, âàì íà÷íóò âñòðå÷àòüñÿ äðóãèå äåðæàâû: êàê âîèíñòâåííûå, òàê è âïîëíå ìèðîëþáèâûå. Íåêîòîðûå ëèäåðû íîðîâÿò íàïàêîñòèòü âàì çà âàøåé ñïèíîé, à òî è ïîïðîñòó âîòêíóòü êèíæàë ìåæäó ëîïàòîê, äðóãèå ïðåäïî÷èòàþò ÷åñòíóþ - íó, èëè ïî÷òè ÷åñòíóþ - èãðó. Ó÷èòåñü âçàèìîäåéñòâîâàòü ñ ñîñåäÿìè è ñîïåðíèêàìè. Äëÿ íåêîòîðûõ íàèáîëåå âåñêèì àðãóìåíòîì ñòàíåò âàøà ïîáåäîíîñíàÿ àðìèÿ, ñ äðóãèìè èìååò ñìûñë çàêëþ÷èòü ñäåëêó - äî òåõ ïîð ïîêà âû íå âîçíàìåðèòåñü ñòåðåòü èõ ñ ëèöà Çåìëè, ðàçóìååòñÿ. [PARAGRAPH:2]Äèïëîìàòèÿ - ìîùíûé èíñòðóìåíò. Îíà ïîçâîëÿåò îáìåíèâàòüñÿ òåõíîëîãèÿìè, ðåñóðñàìè, êàðòàìè, çîëîòîì, è äàæå ãîðîäàìè. Êðîìå òîãî, ñ åå ïîìîùüþ ìîæíî çàêëþ÷àòü äîãîâîðû î ñîâìåñòíîé îáîðîíå, îáúÿâëÿòü âîéíó è çàêëþ÷àòü ìèð. Â èãðå Civilization IV âàøè äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèå òàëàíòû âàæíû íå ìåíåå, ÷åì ïîëêîâîä÷åñêèå è ýêîíîìè÷åñêèå. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ëèäåðû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íå çàáûâàéòå, ÷òî ó êàæäîãî ëèäåðà åñòü ñîáñòâåííûå öåëè. Îíè - êàê è âû - ñòðåìÿòñÿ ê ïîáåäå: ñ ïîìîùüþ îðóæèÿ, âûñîêèõ òåõíîëîãèé èëè êóëüòóðíîãî ïðåâîñõîäñòâà. Âåäÿ ïåðåãîâîðû, ìîæíî âû÷èñëèòü èç íàìåðåíèÿ: âîèíñòâåííûå äåðæàâû íå ïðîäàþò âîåííûå þíèòû, íàñòðîåííûé íà òåõíîëîãè÷åñêóþ ïîáåäó ëèäåð áóäåò ïðàâäàìè è íåïðàâäàìè èñêàòü íîâûå òåõíîëîãèè è ò.ï. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Ëèäåðû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîäðîáíåå îá îòíîøåíèè[\BOLD]. Â ïðîöåññå èãðû êàæäûé ëèäåð ñôîðìèðóåò î âàñ ìíåíèå, îñíîâûâàÿñü íà ñèëå âàøåé äåðæàâû, íà òîì, âñòóïàëè ëè âû â êîíôëèêòû, çàêëþ÷àëè ëè ñîþçû ñ åãî âðàãàìè è äåðæèòå ëè ñëîâî. [PARAGRAPH:2]Îòíîøåíèå ëèäåðà ê âàì ìîæåò áûòü ïÿòè âèäîâ: äðóæáà, ñèìïàòèÿ, íåäîâåðèå, íåïðèÿçíü è âðàæäà. ×åì ëó÷øå ëèäåð ê âàì îòíîñèòñÿ, òåì ïðîùå ñ íèì äîãîâîðèòüñÿ î òîðãîâëå è òåì âûãîäíåå áóäåò ñäåëêà. Ìîæíî òîðãîâàòü è ñ âðàãàìè, íî â ýòîì ñëó÷àå ïðèãîòîâüòåñü ê íåïîìåðíûì öåíàì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îòêàç îò îáùåíèÿ[\BOLD]. Èíîãäà îñîáåííî ðàçîáèæåííûé ëèäåð ìîæåò è âîâñå îòêàçàòüñÿ ñ âàìè ðàçãîâàðèâàòü. Îáû÷íî ýòî ïðîèñõîäèò, êîãäà âàøè äåðæàâû âîþþò. Ïîäîæäèòå íåñêîëüêî õîäîâ, âîçìîæíî, âàø ñîáåñåäíèê ñìåíèò ãíåâ íà ìèëîñòü - îñîáåííî åñëè íà÷íåò ïðîèãðûâàòü.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðåæèì ïåðåãîâîðîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â ðåæèì ïåðåãîâîðîâ ìîæíî ïåðåéòè ñ ýêðàíà äèïëîìàòèè - èëè ùåëêíóâ èìÿ ëèäåðà íà ïàíåëè ñ÷åòà â ãëàâíîì èãðîâîì îêíå. Èíîãäà ëèäåðû ìîãóò ñàìè âñòóïàòü ñ âàìè â ïåðåãîâîðû - â ýòîì ñëó÷àå áóäåò îòêðûò ýêðàí äèïëîìàòèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèå õîäû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â ðåæèìå ïåðåãîâîðîâ ó âàñ (êàê è ó ïðî÷èõ ëèäåðîâ) åñòü íåñêîëüêî âîçìîæíûõ õîäîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îáúÿâèòü âîéíó[\BOLD]. Âåæëèâûé ñïîñîá ïåðåéòè ê àãðåññèè. Ìåíåå âåæëèâûé - ââåñòè âîéñêà íà òåððèòîðèþ ñîñåäà, ñ êîòîðûì íåò ñîãëàøåíèÿ îá îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïðåäëîæèòü ìèð[\BOLD]. Âîçìîæíîñòü äîñòóïíà òîëüêî â ñîñòîÿíèè âîéíû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Òîðãîâëÿ[\BOLD]. Ïîïûòêà çàêëþ÷èòü ñ äðóãîé äåðæàâîé òîðãîâóþ ñäåëêó. Íà ýêðàíå ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ ïàíåëü òîðãîâëè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïðîñìîòð òåêóùèõ ñäåëîê[\BOLD]. Ïîìèìî ðàçîâûõ ñäåëîê â èãðå èìåþòñÿ òàêæå "ãîäîâûå", êîòîðûå îñòàþòñÿ àêòóàëüíûìè íåêîòîðîå âðåìÿ (ñì. íèæå). Äàííàÿ êîìàíäà ïîçâîëÿåò ïðîñìàòðèâàòü âñå òåêóùèå ñäåëêè ñ âûáðàííûì ëèäåðîì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âûõîä[\BOLD]. Çàâåðøèòü ïåðåãîâîðû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê ïðåäëîæèòü ñäåëêó[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà ïàíåëè òîðãîâëè âñå ïðîäóêòû, êîòîðûå âû ìîæåòå âûñòàâèòü íà ïðîäàæó, ïåðå÷èñëåíû â ïðàâîì ñòîëáöå, à òîâàðû âàøåãî ïàðòíåðà - â ëåâîì. ×òîáû âûñòàâèòü òîâàð íà ïðîäàæó, ùåëêíèòå åãî â ñâîåì ñòîëáöå, à çàòåì ùåëêíèòå òîâàð äëÿ îáìåíà â ñòîëáöå ïàðòíåðà è íàæìèòå êíîïêó òîðãà. Åñëè ïàðòíåð ñîãëàñåí, ñäåëêà çàêëþ÷åíà. Åñëè îí îòêàçûâàåòñÿ, ìîæíî âûéòè èç ðåæèìà ïåðåãîâîðîâ èëè ïîïðîáîâàòü çàêëþ÷èòü åùå îäíó ñäåëêó. [PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ùåëêíóòü òîëüêî ïðåäìåò â ñòîëáöå ïàðòíåðà, ýòî áóäåò îáîçíà÷àòü, ÷òî âû òðåáóåòå äàíü - ïðèêàçûâàÿ ïàðòíåðó îòäàòü âàì ýòîò òîâàð äàðîì. Ðàçóìååòñÿ, åñòü øàíñ, ÷òî âû ïîëó÷èòå îòêàç, à îòíîøåíèå ê âàì â ëþáîì ñëó÷àå èçìåíèòñÿ ê õóäøåìó. Åñëè, íàïðîòèâ, ùåëêíóòü òîëüêî ñâîé òîâàð, ýòî áóäåò îçíà÷àòü, ÷òî âû ïåðåäàåòå åãî äàðîì, â êà÷åñòâå "àêòà äîáðîé âîëè". Îò ïîäàðêîâ íå îòêàæåòñÿ íè îäèí ëèäåð, è îíè íåðåäêî ïðèâîäÿò ê ïîâûøåíèþ âàøåé ðåïóòàöèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê îòâåòèòü íà ïðåäëîæåíèå ñäåëêè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîëó÷èâ ïðåäëîæåíèå îò äðóãîãî ëèäåðà, ìîæíî ïðèíÿòü åãî èëè îòâåòèòü îòêàçîì. Â ïåðâîì ñëó÷àå ñäåëêà áóäåò çàêëþ÷åíà íåçàìåäëèòåëüíî, âî âòîðîì - ëèäåð ìîæåò ïîïðîñèòü âàñ î âñòðå÷íîì ïðåäëîæåíèè, çàâåðøèòü ïåðåãîâîðû èëè îáúÿâèòü âàì âîéíó.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òîâàð, íå ïîäëåæàùèé îáìåíó[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íàçâàíèÿ íåêîòîðûõ òîâàðîâ â ñòîëáöå âàøåãî ïàðòíåðà ìîãóò îòîáðàæàòüñÿ êðàñíûì øðèôòîì. Ýòî îçíà÷àåò, ÷òî ëèäåð íå ìîæåò - èëè íå æåëàåò - îáìåíèâàòüñÿ ýòèì òîâàðîì ñ âàìè, òàê ÷òî ïðåäëàãàòü ñäåëêó â ýòîì ñëó÷àå ñìûñëà íå èìååò. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òåõíè÷åñêèå òðåáîâàíèÿ ê òîðãîâëå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ òîðãîâëè íåêîòîðûìè òîâàðàìè íåîáõîäèìî èìåòü äîñòóï ê îïðåäåëåííûì òåõíîëîãèÿì. Â íà÷àëå èãðû âàøè äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèå ñïîñîáíîñòè âåñüìà îãðàíè÷åíû. Ïðè ýòîì òåõíîëîãèåé íå îáÿçàòåëüíî äîëæíû âëàäåòü îáå ñòîðîíû - äîñòàòî÷íî, ÷òîáû åå çíàëè ëèáî âû, ëèáî âàø ïàðòíåð. Òàê, òîðãîâëÿ òåõíîëîãèÿìè çàáëîêèðîâàíà äî ðàçðàáîòêè òåõíîëîãèè [LINK=TECH_ALPHABET]Àëôàâèò[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òèïû ñäåëîê[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñóùåñòâóåò äâà òèïà òîâàðîâ: "åäèíîâðåìåííûå" è "ãîäîâûå" Ïåðâûå ìîæíî ìåíÿòü òîëüêî íà òàêèå æå åäèíîâðåìåííûå òîâàðû, âòîðûå - òîëüêî íà ãîäîâûå. Âíóòðè ãðóïïû òîâàðîì ìîæíî îáìåíèâàòüñÿ ñâîáîäíî: òàê, òåõíîëîãèþ ìîæíî îáìåíÿòü íà çîëîòî èëè êàðòó ìèðà, îäíàêî åäèíîâðåìåííûé òîâàð íåëüçÿ ìåíÿòü íà ãîäîâîé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Åäèíîâðåìåííûå òîâàðû[\BOLD]. Òîâàðû äëÿ åäèíîâðåìåííûõ ñäåëîê. Ñþäà îòíîñÿòñÿ, íàïðèìåð, åäèíîâðåìåííî âûïëà÷èâàåìûå äåíåæíûå ñóììû, êàðòû, òåõíîëîãèè, ãîðîäà, ìèðíûå ñîãëàøåíèÿ è ò.ï.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãîäîâûå òîâàðû[\BOLD]. Çàìåòüòå, ÷òî îò âûïîëíåíèÿ óñëîâèé ñäåëêè âàñ íå îñâîáîäÿò íè ïóñòàÿ êàçíà, íè àíàðõèÿ, íè ïðî÷èå áåäñòâèÿ. ×òîáû âûïëà÷èâàòü äîëã, âàø êàçíà÷åé áóäåò àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ëèêâèäèðîâàòü þíèòû è çäàíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Êàðòà ìèðà - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Èññëåäîâàííàÿ ïàðòíåðîì òåððèòîðèÿ ñòàíîâèòñÿ âèäèìîé âàì - è íàîáîðîò. (Ñì [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Èññëåäîâàíèå òåððèòîðèè[\LINK].)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îòêðûòûå ãðàíèöû - ãîäîâàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Âàøè þíèòû ñâîáîäíî ïåðåäâèãàþòñÿ ïî òåððèòîðèè ïàðòíåðà è íàîáîðîò. Â ñëó÷àå îáúÿâëåíèÿ âîéíû âàøè þíèòû áóäóò àâòîìàòè÷åñêè óáðàíû ñ âðàæåñêîé òåððèòîðèè è íàîáîðîò.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ãîðîäñêèå òîðãîâûå ïóòè áóäóò âêëþ÷àòü â ñåáÿ ãîðîäà äåðæàâû, ñ êîòîðîé ïîäïèñàí äîãîâîð îá îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ. Ïîñêîëüêó ìåæäóíàðîäíûå òîðãîâûå ïóòè çíà÷èòåëüíî ïðèáûëüíåå âíóòðåííèõ, ïîäïèñàíèå äîãîâîðà îá îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ ïðèâåäåò ê ñóùåñòâåííîìó ðîñòó êîììåðöèè â ãîðîäàõ. Äîõîä ìîãóò åùå áîëåå óâåëè÷èòü íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]çäàíèÿ[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñîãëàøåíèå î ñîâìåñòíîé îáîðîíå - ãîäîâàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè îäíó èç ñòîðîí àòàêóåò òðåòüÿ äåðæàâà, âòîðàÿ ñòîðîíà àâòîìàòè÷åñêè îáúÿâëÿåò àãðåññîðó âîéíó. Ñîãëàøåíèå àâòîìàòè÷åñêè àííóëèðóåòñÿ, åñëè îäíà èç äåðæàâ-ó÷àñòíèêîâ ñàìà ñòàíîâèòñÿ àãðåññîðîì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîñòîÿííûé ñîþç - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Äâå äåðæàâû ñòàíîâÿòñÿ îäíîé - ñ äâóìÿ ïðàâèòåëÿìè. Êàæäûé èç ëèäåðîâ ïðîäîëæàåò óïðàâëÿòü ñâîèìè þíèòàìè è ãîðîäàìè, îäíàêî âñå îñòàëüíîå - ðåñóðñû, òåõíîëîãèè, êàðòà è ïîáåäà/ïîðàæåíèå - ó íèõ îáùèå. Åñëè îäèí ó÷àñòíèê íà÷èíàåò âîéíó, âòîðîé àâòîìàòè÷åñêè âñòóïàåò â íåå. Åñëè îäèí ïîäïèñûâàåò äîãîâîð, âòîðîé îáÿçàí âûïîëíÿòü åãî óñëîâèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Òåõíîëîãèè - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Âû ìãíîâåííî ïîëó÷àåòå äîñòóï ê ïðèîáðåòåííîé òåõíîëîãèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðåñóðñû - ãîäîâàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðè ïðîäàæå ðåñóðñîâ âû ïîëó÷àåòå èõ â òå÷åíèå âñåãî ñðîêà äåéñòâèÿ ñäåëêè. Ïðîäàâåö òåðÿåò âñå áîíóñû, äàâàåìûå ðåñóðñîì, åñëè òîëüêî íå îáëàäàåò åùå îäíèì èñòî÷íèêîì. Ïðèìåð: åñëè âàì ïðîäàëè æåëåçî, âû ìîæåòå ñîçäàâàòü âîåííûå þíèòû, äëÿ êîòîðûõ òðåáóåòñÿ æåëåçî. Ïðîäàâåö æå òåïåðü íå ìîæåò èõ ñîçäàâàòü, åñëè íå îáëàäàåò âòîðûì æåëåçíûì ðóäíèêîì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âîåííûé ñîþç - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îäíà äåðæàâà ìîæåò ïîïðîñèòü äðóãóþ îáúÿâèòü âîéíó òðåòüåé. Ïðè ýòîì ïåðâàÿ äåðæàâà ìîæåò ñàìà è íå íàõîäèòüñÿ â ñîñòîÿíèè âîéíû ñ òðåòüåé, íî òîãäà ëèäåð âòîðîé çàëîìèò çà ñâîè óñëóãè âåñüìà è âåñüìà ïðèëè÷íóþ öåíó.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãîðîäà - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïàðòíåð ïåðåäàåò âàì îäèí èëè íåñêîëüêî ñâîèõ ãîðîäîâ. Åñëè ìåæäó âàìè äåéñòâóåò ñîãëàøåíèå îá îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ, âñå þíèòû îñòàþòñÿ íà ìåñòàõ. Â ïðîòèâíîì ñëó÷àå þíèòû ïåðåìåùàþòñÿ èç ãîðîäîâ íà ñâîþ òåððèòîðèþ. Ëèäåðû êðàéíå ðåäêî óñòóïàþò äðóãèì äåðæàâàì ãîðîäà, åñëè èõ ê òîìó íå ïðèíóæäàþò èñêëþ÷èòåëüíûå îáñòîÿòåëüñòâà - èëè âåñêèå àðãóìåíòû â âèäå ìîùíîé àðìèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñìåíà ïàðàäèãìû - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñîãëàøåíèå î ñìåíå ñîöèàëüíîé ïàðàäèãìû. Êàæäûé ëèäåð îáëàäàåò "ëþáèìîé" ïàðàäèãìîé: Åêàòåðèíà, ê ïðèìåðó, áëàãîâîëèò ê "Íàñëåäíîìó ïðàâëåíèþ". Ëèäåðû íà÷èíàþò ëó÷øå ê âàì îòíîñèòüñÿ, åñëè âû ïðèíèìàåòå èõ ëþáèìóþ ïàðàäèãìó.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îáðàùåíèå - åäèíîâðåìåííàÿ ñäåëêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñîãëàøåíèå î ñìåíå ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèè íà ðåëèãèþ ïàðòíåðà. Ðåëèãèîçíûå ðàçíîãëàñèÿ ìåæäó äåðæàâàìè ìîãóò ïðèâîäèòü ê íàïðÿæåííîñòè è âçàèìíîìó íåäîâåðèþ. Îáðàùåíèå â ðåëèãèþ ïàðòíåðà - îòëè÷íûé ñïîñîá óêðåïèòü îòíîøåíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ìèðíîå ñîãëàøåíèå - îñîáûé àêò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìåæäó âàìè è ïðîòèâíèêîì íàñòóïàåò ïåðåìèðèå. Âñå þíèòû óäàëÿþòñÿ ñ ÷óæîé òåððèòîðèè. Ïåðåìèðèå äëèòñÿ êàê ìèíèìóì 10 õîäîâ. Îïëà÷èâàåòñÿ òîëüêî çîëîòîì è òåõíîëîãèÿìè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïðåêðàùåíèå îãíÿ - îñîáûé àêò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìåæäó âàìè è ïðîòèâíèêîì íàñòóïàåò ïåðåìèðèå. Âñå þíèòû óäàëÿþòñÿ ñ ÷óæîé òåððèòîðèè. Ïðåêðàùåíèå îãíÿ ÿâëÿåòñÿ ðàçîâûì àêòîì: ñòîðîíû ìîãóò ñðàçó æå ñíîâà íà÷àòü âîéíó. Ñîãëàøåíèå î ïðåêðàùåíèè îãíÿ ìîæíî ïðåäëàãàòü òîëüêî îòäåëüíî îò äðóãèõ òîâàðîâ, èíà÷å îíî áóäåò ïðåîáðàçîâàíî â ìèðíûé äîãîâîð.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Diplomacy[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]As Civilization IV progresses and your units [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Explore[\LINK] the world around them, you will meet the leaders of the other civilizations around you. Each leader is different: some are warlike; others, peaceful. Some are backstabbing liars; others are (usually) honest. You'll have to learn how to deal with these characters: some you'll fight right away; others you'll negotiate with - at least until it's time to destroy them...[PARAGRAPH:2]You can accomplish a lot through diplomacy. You can trade technologies, resources, maps, gold, and even cities. You can form mutual protection pacts; you can declare war; you can negotiate peace settlements. Success in Civilization IV depends as much on your diplomatic skills as it does on your martial and management prowess.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leaders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Each leader has his or her own agenda. They, too, seek to achieve victory - some through force of arms, others through technological prowess, others through cultural domination. You'll get clues to their intentions as the game progresses - the more warlike leaders will usually not trade anything of military value, the knowledge-focused leaders will seek advanced technologies, and so forth. See [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Leaders[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Leader Attitudes:[\BOLD] During the game, each leader will form an opinion of you: how great a threat you are to their civilization, whether you have fought them in the past, whether you have allied with their enemies, how much you can be trusted to keep your word, etc.[PARAGRAPH:2]Leader attitudes come in five flavors: friendly, pleased, cautious, annoyed, and furious. The more a leader likes you, the more likely he or she is to be willing to trade with you, and the better deal you'll get. You may be able to trade with hostile leaders, but you're likely to pay a stiff price for whatever you get.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Refusing to Talk:[\BOLD] Sometimes a particularly angry leader won't speak to you at all. This occurs most often when your civilizations are at war. Check back again in several turns - by then he or she may have cooled off enough to be willing to speak, especially if his or her military situation has declined.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Opening Diplomacy[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can open diplomacy from the diplomacy screen, or by clicking on the leader's name in the "score box" on the main screen. Occasionally, a leader might open negotiations with you. When diplomacy begins, the diplomacy screen appears.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Diplomatic Options[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When diplomacy opens, you (and the other leaders) usually have several choices available:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Declare War:[\BOLD] The polite way to open hostilities. (The less polite way is to march your units into the enemy's territory without an open borders agreement.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Offer Peace:[\BOLD] Available only if you're at war.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Trade:[\BOLD] Try to trade stuff with the other civilization. This takes you to the trade table.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Review Ongoing Deals:[\BOLD] Some "annual" deals continue over time (see below). This option lets you review any such deals you have in place with the leader.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Exit:[\BOLD] End the diplomatic session.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Making Trade Offers[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]On the trade table, all of your tradable items are listed in the right-hand column, while the other leader's stuff is in the left-hand column. To make an offer, click on one (or more) items in your column, and one (or more) items in the other leader's column, and then click on the "make offer" button. If the leader agrees, the deal is done. If not, you can exit diplomacy or try another deal. [PARAGRAPH:2]If you click only on an item in the other leader's column but not on anything in your column, you are "demanding tribute:" ordering the leader to give you the item for free. He or she may decline, of course, and in either case, his opinion of you will probably decline. If you click only on an item in your column but none in the other leader's, you are giving the leader that item for free, as a "goodwill gesture." Leaders never refuse goodwill gestures. Goodwill gestures often cause the leader to raise his or her opinion of you.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Responding to Offers[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When another leader makes you an offer, you must choose to refuse or accept the offer. If you accept, the trade occurs immediately. If you decline, the other leader may ask you to make a counter-offer, may end diplomacy, or may declare war on you.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Untradeable Items[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Often you will see items in the leader's column that are colored red. This indicates that the leader will not (or cannot) trade these items with you, so don't bother asking.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Technical Requirements for Trade[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You need access to certain technologies to trade some items; at the beginning of the game, your diplomatic options are severely limited. Both sides do not need to know the required technology, but at least one of the traders must. You cannot trade technology, for example, until either you or your trading partner knows the [LINK=TECH_ALPHABET]Alphabet[\LINK] technology.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Trading Types[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]There are two distinct kinds of items you can trade: "immediate" items or "annual" items. Immediate items can only be traded for other immediate items, and annuals only for other annuals. You are free to trade any items within a group - technology for gold and a world map, for instance, since they're all immediate items - but you can't trade an immediate item or items for one or more annuals.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Immediate Items:[\BOLD] These are items that are exchanged immediately. That is, the deals have no duration. Immediate items include: lump sum of gold, maps, technology, peace treaties, cities, and so on.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Annual Trade Items:[\BOLD] Annual trades last for a minimum of 10 turns. They can continue for longer than 10 turns if both sides agree, but neither side can cancel an annual trade before 10 turns are up, except by declaration of war. Annual items include: resources, gold per turn.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Tradable Things[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Gold, Lump Sum - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A chunk of gold. 1 gold. 15 gold. A billion-billion gold.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Gold, Per Turn - Annual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A certain number of gold per turn: 2 gold/turn. 30 gold/turn. This lasts a minimum of 10 turns. Note that you are obligated to pay this gold no matter what: empty treasury, anarchy, etc. Your treasurer will automatically disband units and buildings as necessary to fulfill your obligations.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]World Map - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]All of the territory explored by your partner is now visible on your main map and vice versa. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploration[\LINK].)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Open Borders - Annual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Your units can now move freely through your partner's territory, and vice versa. If you declare war against a civilization you have an open borders agreement with, all of your units are removed from his territory, and all of his units are removed from yours.[PARAGRAPH:2]Furthermore, your cities' trade routes extend to include those civs which whom you have Open Borders. Since foreign trade routes are much more lucrative than domestic ones, signing Open Borders can significantly increase the commerce of your cities. Various [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] can increase this income even more.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Defensive Pact - Annual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If either of your civilizations is attacked by a third party, the other civilization automatically declares war on the attacker. This agreement is nullified if either of the signatories attacks anybody.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Permanent Alliance - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Your two civilizations essentially become one nation with two rulers. You each continue to have control over your units and cities, but you share everything else: resources, technologies, maps, and victory or defeat. If one declares war, the other automatically does so as well. If one signs a treaty, the other is bound by it.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Technology - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You immediately learn the technology that has been traded to you.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Resources - Annual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If a resource is traded to you, you get all of its benefits for as long as the agreement is in place. The trader loses all of the benefits, unless he or she has more than one. (For instance, if somebody trades you iron, you can then construct any military unit that requires iron. The trader can no longer produce such units, unless he's got another source of iron.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Declare War with - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]One civilization asks another to declare war on a third. A leader can ask another leader to declare war on a civilization that the first civilization is not at war with, but the other leader will usually charge through the nose for doing so.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cities - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Your opponent agrees to give you one or more of his or her cities. If you have open borders with the other civilization, all units remain in place. If not, the units in the city are shifted back to their own territory. It is extremely rare for a leader to give up a city unless under great duress.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Adopt - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]One civilization asks another to change civics. Each leader has a favorite civic-type - Catherine, for example, likes Hereditary Rule. Leaders like you better if you are employing their favorite civic.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Convert - Immediate[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]One civilization asks another civilization to change its state religion to match the first civilization's state religion. Religious differences between civilizations cause a lot of tension: adopting another civilization's religion is an excellent way to firm up relations with that civilization.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Declare Peace - Special[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Peace breaks out between you and your opponent. All units are immediately vacated from each other's terrain. Peace lasts for a minimum of 10 turns. You can only trade peace for gold or technology.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Declare Cease Fire - Special[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Peace breaks out between you and your opponent. All units are immediately vacated from each other's terrain. There is no duration for this cease fire - either side can immediately declare war again. Nothing can be combined with a cease fire deal.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ïðèçûâ[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_NATIONHOOD]Íàöèîíàëüíàÿ èäåÿ[\LINK] ïîçâîëÿåò ïðèçâàòü íà âîåííóþ ñëóæáó äî òðåõ þíèòîâ çà õîä. Ïðè ìîáèëèçàöèè åäèíèöà ãîðîäñêîãî íàñåëåíèÿ ïðåîáðàçóåòñÿ â âîåííûé þíèò.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òèï þíèòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìîáèëèçîâàííûé þíèò áóäåò îòíîñèòüñÿ ê ñèëüíåéøåìó èç äîñòóïíûõ òèïîâ ïåõîòû. Â ðàííèå ýïîõè ýòî áóäåò ìå÷íèê, ïîçæå - áóëàâîíîñåö, ìóøêåòåð èëè ïåõîòèíåö.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îïûò þíèòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìîáèëèçîâàííûé þíèò ïîëó÷àåò 50%% îò ñòàíäàðòíîãî íà÷àëüíîãî îïûòà äëÿ þíèòà äàííîãî òèïà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñíèæåíèå íàñòðîåíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðèçûâ ãîðîæàí íà âîåííóþ ñëóæáó ïðèâîäèò ê âðåìåííîìó ñíèæåíèþ [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]íàñòðîåíèÿ[\LINK] â ãîðîäå. Ñî âðåìåíåì íàñòðîåíèå ïîâûñèòñÿ. Åñëè ïîâòîðèòü ïðèçûâ íåñêîëüêî ðàç â îäíîì ãîðîäå, âðåìÿ âîññòàíîâëåíèÿ âîçðàñòåò.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Draft[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CIVIC_NATIONHOOD]Nationhood[\LINK] civic allows you to "draft" three units each turn. When you draft a unit in a city, some of the city's population is turned into a military unit.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Unit Type[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The drafted unit is the best "standard" foot-soldier available to your civilization: in early eras this might be a swordsman, while later it might be a maceman, musketeer or infantry.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Unit Experience[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Drafted units begin with half as much experience as a standard unit trained in the same city would receive.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Unhappiness[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Employing the draft causes [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]Unhappiness[\LINK] in the city where you drafted the unit. This unhappiness isn't permanent: it dissipates over time. Drafting the same city multiple times will increase the unhappiness duration further.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Èññëåäîâàíèå òåððèòîðèè[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Â íà÷àëå èãðû áîëüøàÿ ÷àñòü ìèðà ÿâëÿåòñÿ äëÿ âàñ terra incognita. Èññëåäîâàòü íîâûå òåððèòîðèè êðàéíå âàæíî. Ýòî ïîçâîëÿåò íàõîäèòü íîâûå ðåñóðñû, ïîäûñêèâàòü ìåñòà äëÿ íîâûõ [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäîâ[\LINK] è âõîäèòü â êîíòàêò ñ äðóãèìè äåðæàâàìè. Èññëåäóþò òåððèòîðèþ þíèòû, êîòîðûå âû îòïðàâëÿåòå â íåâåäîìûå çåìëè. Âû ìîæåòå âèäåòü âñå íîâûå ó÷àñòêè êàðòû ïî ìåðå òîãî, êàê îíè îòêðûâàþòñÿ "âçîðàì" âàøèõ èññëåäîâàòåëåé.[PARAGRAPH:2]Â èãðå Civilization IV èìååòñÿ òðè âèäà òåððèòîðèè: íåèññëåäîâàííàÿ, îòêðûòàÿ è îñâîåííàÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Íåèññëåäîâàííàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåèññëåäîâàííàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ çàêðûòà ÷åðíîé ïåëåíîé, è âàì î íåé íè÷åãî íå èçâåñòíî: íè òèïà ìåñòíîñòè, íè îáúåêòîâ, íè òîãî, íàõîäÿòñÿ ëè íà íåé ÷óæèå þíèòû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îñâîåííàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Îñâîåííàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ îòîáðàæàåòñÿ ÿðêèìè êðàñêàìè. Ýòî òåððèòîðèÿ, êîòîðàÿ íàõîäèòñÿ â çîíå âèäèìîñòè âàøèõ þíèòîâ è ãîðîäîâ. Ê îñâîåííîé òåððèòîðèè îòíîñèòñÿ âñÿ òåððèòîðèÿ â ïðåäåëàõ çîíû êóëüòóðíîãî âëèÿíèÿ. Â çîíó âèäèìîñòè þíèòîâ è ãîðîäîâ âñåãäà âõîäÿò êëåòêè, êîòîðûå òå çàíèìàþò, à òàêæå íåïîñðåäñòâåííî ïðèëåãàþùèå ê íèì. Íà âîçâûøåííîñòè, íà âîäíîé ïîâåðõíîñòè èëè ïðè ïðèìåíåíèè îïðåäåëåííûõ òåõíîëîãèé çîíà âèäèìîñòè óâåëè÷èâàåòñÿ. Íà êàðòå â çîíå âèäèìîñòè äîñòóïíî âñå, ÷òî "âèäÿò" âàøè ïîääàííûå: ðåñóðñû, äðóãèå þíèòû, îáúåêòû, êóëüòóðíûå ãðàíèöû è ò.ï. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îòêðûòàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Îòêðûòàÿ, íî íåîñâîåííàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ îòîáðàæàåòñÿ íà êàðòå áîëåå áëåêëûìè êðàñêàìè. Ñþäà îòíîñÿòñÿ êëåòêè, íà êîòîðûõ âàøè þíèòû êîãäà-òî ïîáûâàëè, íî óøëè, íè÷åãî íå ïîñòðîèâ. Íåîñâîåííàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ îòîáðàæàåòñÿ íà êàðòå â òîì âèäå, â êîòîðîì åå â ïîñëåäíèé ðàç âèäåëè âàøè þíèòû. Èçìåíåíèÿ (íîâûå ãîðîäà, îáúåêòû, äîðîãè) ÍÅ îòîáðàæàþòñÿ. Íà íåîñâîåííîé òåððèòîðèè íåëüçÿ óâèäåòü ÷óæèå þíèòû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îáìåí êàðòàìè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðè îáìåíå [LINK=CONCEPT_MAPS]êàðòàìè[\LINK] ñ äðóãîé äåðæàâîé (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Äèïëîìàòèÿ[\LINK]) âñÿ îòêðûòàÿ ïàðòíåðîì òåððèòîðèÿ îòîáðàæàåòñÿ êàê "íåîñâîåííàÿ" - ïî ñîñòîÿíèþ íà òîò ìîìåíò, êîãäà ïàðòíåð âèäåë åå ïîñëåäíèé ðàç, íî áåç þíèòîâ. Åñëè âàø ïàðòíåð ïîñòðîèò íîâûå ãîðîäà èëè îáúåêòû, èçìåíåíèÿ íå áóäóò îòîáðàæåíû íà êàðòå, åñëè òîëüêî âû íå ðåøèòå ïðîèçâåñòè îáìåí åùå ðàç.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Exploration[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]At the beginning of a game, most of the world is unknown to you. It is important to explore the world, to discover resources and sites to build new [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK] and to encounter other civilizations. You explore your world by sending units out into the unknown: the spaces become visible once your units can "see" them.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are three different kinds of spaces in Civilization IV: unexplored spaces, visible spaces, and explored spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Unexplored Spaces[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Unexplored spaces are black. You don't know what terrain they contain, whether they are occupied by units, or anything else.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Visible Spaces[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Visible Spaces are very bright. They are all the spaces that your units and cities can currently "see." Spaces within your cultural borders are always visible. Your units and cities can always see the squares they occupy and those directly adjacent to them; if on hills, if looking across water, or if you have certain technological advances, they can often see farther. When you look at the map, you can see everything that any of your units or cities can see: other units, visible resources, improvements, cultural borders, and so forth.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Explored Spaces[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Explored spaces are darker than visible spaces, but not as black as unexplored spaces. These are spaces that you have seen in the past, but which none of your units or cities can see at present. Explored spaces are displayed on the map in the state you last saw them: you do NOT see any changes (new cities, improvements, roads, so forth) which have taken place since you last actually saw that space. You cannot see units in explored spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Map Trading[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When you trade [LINK=CONCEPT_MAPS]Maps[\LINK] with another civilization (see [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK]), all of the newly-visible territory is "explored" to you - you see the territory as your trading partner last saw it, but you don't see any units occupying those spaces. If your trading partner then builds new cities or improvements in these spaces after trading you his or her map, you will not see the changed conditions unless you trade for their map again.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ïèùà[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïèùà íåîáõîäèìà äëÿ âûæèâàíèÿ ãîðîäîâ. Îò åå êîëè÷åñòâà çàâèñèò ñêîðîñòü ðîñòà ãîðîäà. Ïèùà çàãîòàâëèâàåòñÿ íà òåððèòîðèè âîêðóã ãîðîäà (íà êëåòêàõ, êîòîðûå íàõîäÿòñÿ êàê â ïðåäåëàõ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]ãðàíèöû[\LINK], òàê è âíóòðè [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]çîíû âëèÿíèÿ ãîðîäà[\LINK].)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîòðåáëåíèå ïèùè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàæäûé æèòåëü (åäèíèöà íàñåëåíèÿ) [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäà[\LINK] ïîòðåáëÿåò 2 åä. ïèùè â õîä.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Èçëèøêè ïèùè[\BOLD]. Åñëè ãîðîä ïðîèçâîäèò áîëüøå ïèùè, ÷åì ïîòðåáëÿåò, èçëèøêè çàïàñàþòñÿ. Êîãäà êîëè÷åñòâî çàïàñîâ äîñòèãàåò îïðåäåëåííîãî óðîâíÿ, ïèùà èñ÷åçàåò, à íàñåëåíèå ãîðîäà óâåëè÷èâàåòñÿ íà åäèíèöó. Ïî ìåðå ðîñòà ãîðîäà äëÿ óâåëè÷åíèÿ íàñåëåíèÿ ïîòðåáóåòñÿ âñå áîëüøåå êîëè÷åñòâî ïèùè. Â [LINK=BUILDING_GRANARY]àìáàðå[\LINK] õðàíèòñÿ ïîëîâèíà êîëè÷åñòâà ïèùè, íóæíîãî äëÿ ïðèðîñòà íàñåëåíèÿ. Òàêèì îáðàçîì ýòî çäàíèå ñóùåñòâåííî óñêîðÿåò ðîñò.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íåäîñòàòîê ïèùè[\BOLD]. Åñëè ãîðîä íå ìîæåò îáåñïå÷èòü ïèùåé âñåõ æèòåëåé, íà÷èíàþò ðàñõîäîâàòüñÿ çàïàñû. Åñëè çàïàñû èñòîùåíû, îäèí èç æèòåëåé óìèðàåò îò ãîëîäà. Óìåíüøåíèå íàñåëåíèÿ ïðîäîëæèòñÿ äî òåõ ïîð, ïîêà áàëàíñ íå áóäåò âîññòàíîâëåí.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Çäîðîâüå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]Çäîðîâüå[\LINK] ãîðîäñêîãî íàñåëåíèÿ îêàçûâàåò çíà÷èòåëüíîå âëèÿíèå íà ïðîèçâîäñòâî ïèùè: áîëüíûå æèòåëè åäÿò áîëüøå. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. ñîîòâåòñòâóþùóþ ñòàòüþ.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Àãðàðíûå òåõíèêè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàæäûé òèï [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]ïî÷âû[\LINK] è êàæäûé [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñ[\LINK] ïðîèçâîäÿò çàäàííîå êîëè÷åñòâî ïèùè. Èíîãäà ìîæíî ïîâûñèòü ïëîäîðîäíîñòü êëåòêè ïóòåì ïîñòðîéêè íà íåé ñîîòâåòñòâóþùåãî [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]îáúåêòà[\LINK]. Ê ïðèìåðó, íà ëóãîâûõ êëåòêàõ âáëèçè ïðåñíîé âîäû ìîæíî ïîñòðîèòü ôåðìû, è ýòè êëåòêè áóäóò ïðîèçâîäèòü áîëüøå ïèùè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Çäàíèÿ è ÷óäåñà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåêîòîðûå[LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]çäàíèÿ[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà[\LINK] òàêæå ìîãóò ïîâûøàòü îáúåì ïðîèçâîäèìîé ïèùè (íàïðèìåð, [LINK=BUILDING_LIGHTHOUSE]ìàÿê[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò ïèùåâóþ ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü âîäíûõ êëåòîê).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàðàäèãìû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]Ãîñóäàðñòâåííàÿ ñîáñòâåííîñòü[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò ïèùåâóþ ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü ðÿäà îáúåêòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òåõíîëîãèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]òåõíîëîãè÷åñêèå íîâøåñòâà[\LINK] ïîçâîëÿþò ñòðîèòü îáúåêòû, êîòîðûå óâåëè÷èâàþò êîëè÷åñòâî ïðîèçâîäèìîé ïèùè. Äðóãèå òåõíîëîãèè ïîâûøàþò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü ñóùåñòâóþùèõ îáúåêòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Food [\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Cities need food to survive. The more food available, the larger the city can grow. Cities get food by working the lands around them (spaces that are both within the national [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK] and within their [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City Radius[\LINK].)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Food Consumption[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Each citizen (population point) in a [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK] consumes two food per turn to survive.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Excess Food:[\BOLD] If a city generates more food than its citizens consume, it stores the excess food. Once it has enough stored food, all of its stored food disappears and the city's population increases by one. As a city grows larger, it takes more stored food to increase its population. The [LINK=BUILDING_GRANARY]Granary[\LINK] stores half of the food needed to grow to the next size, thus accelerating the speed at which the city's population increases.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Insufficient Food:[\BOLD] If a city does not produce enough food to support its population, the city will begin to lose stored food. When a city loses all of its stored food, one of its citizens starves. Starvation will continue until the city is producing enough food to support the population.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Health[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city's [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]Health[\LINK] has a large effect on its food production; when a city slips into unhealthiness, it requires additional food to feed all of the citizens. See that section for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Working the Land[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Each type of [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Terrain[\LINK] generates a specific amount of food, as does each [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resource.[\LINK] You can often increase a square's food output by [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improving[\LINK] it with your workers; for example, grassland tiles next to fresh water can be irrigated with farms to produce additional food.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Buildings and Wonders[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Some [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] can increase a city's food output (for example, the [LINK=BUILDING_LIGHTHOUSE]Lighthouse[\LINK] building adds more food to water tiles).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Civics[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]State Property[\LINK] civic increases the food output of certain improvements.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Technology[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Some [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technological Advances[\LINK] allow your workers to construct improvements increasing your land's food output, while other advances make already-existing improvements more efficient.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Çîëîòîé âåê[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Â æèçíè ìíîãèõ äåðæàâ ñóùåñòâóþò ïåðèîäû áóðíîãî ðàñöâåòà: âåëèêèå îòêðûòèÿ è øåäåâðû ñëåäóþò îäèí çà äðóãèì, ëþáûå íîâøåñòâà äàþòñÿ ëåãêî è äåðæàâà ñòàíîâèòñÿ îáðàçöîì è ïðåäìåòîì çàâèñòè äëÿ âñåãî ìèðà. Òàêîé áûëà ýïîõà Âîçðîæäåíèÿ äëÿ Èòàëèè, òàêèì áûë XIX âåê äëÿ Âåëèêîáðèòàíèè. Â èãðå Civilization IV òàêèå ïåðèîäû íàçûâàþòñÿ "Çîëîòûìè âåêàìè".[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê íà÷àòü Çîëîòîé âåê[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]×óäåñà[\BOLD]. Îäèí èç ñïîñîáîâ íà÷àòü Çîëîòîé âåê - ïîñòðîèòü [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Òàäæ Ìàõàë[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Çíàìåíèòîñòè[\BOLD]. Åùå îäèí ñïîñîá - ïîæåðòâîâàòü äâóìÿ èëè áîëåå [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]çíàìåíèòîñòÿìè[\LINK] ðàçíûõ òèïîâ. Ñòîèìîñòü ïðè ýòîì âîçðàñòàåò: ïåðâûé Çîëîòîé âåê ïîòðåáóåò 2 çíàìåíèòîñòè, âòîðîé - 3 - è òàê äàëåå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]×òî äàåò Çîëîòîé âåê[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â òå÷åíèå Çîëîòîãî âåêà çíà÷èòåëüíî âîçðàñòàåò ïðîèçâîäñòâî ïðîäóêöèè è äåíåã à ñëåäîâàòåëüíî, ïîâûøàåòñÿ ñêîðîñòü ñîçäàíèÿ ëþáûõ îáúåêòîâ è èññëåäîâàíèÿ íîâûõ òåõíîëîãèé. (Â òåðìèíàõ èãðû - âñå êëåòêè â çîíå âëèÿíèÿ ãîðîäà, êîòîðûå ïðîèçâîäÿò ïðîäóêöèþ, íà÷èíàþò äàâàòü äîïîëíèòåëüíóþ åäèíèöó çà õîä.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïðîäîëæèòåëüíîñòü Çîëîòîãî âåêà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Çîëîòîé âåê äëèòñÿ 8 õîäîâ. Åñëè â òå÷åíèå ýòîãî ïåðèîäà âûïîëíÿþòñÿ óñëîâèÿ äëÿ åùå îäíîãî Çîëîòîãî âåêà, ê ñðîêó ïðèáàâëÿåòñÿ åùå 8 õîäîâ (èíûìè ñëîâàìè, îáùàÿ äëèòåëüíîñòü ñîñòàâèò 16 õîäîâ).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Çàâåðøåíèå Çîëîòîãî âåêà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîñëå çàâåðøåíèÿ Çîëîòîãî âåêà ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü äåðæàâû âîçâðàùàåòñÿ íà îáû÷íûé óðîâåíü.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Golden Ages[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]During certain periods of time, some civilizations seem to burst with energy and creativity. The civilization's people become increasingly productive; technological advances come easy to the civilization; and its culture is the envy of the world. Italy during the Renaissance is one such example, and Great Britain in the 19th century another. In Civilization IV, such periods are called "golden ages."[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entering a Golden Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A civilization can enter a golden age by constructing the [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK] wonder.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Great People:[\BOLD] A civilization can combine 2 or more [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] of different types to start a golden age. The cost of this method escalates: the first golden age costs two great people, the second costs three, and so on.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During a golden age, your civilization greatly increases its output of production and commerce, meaning faster build times and research rates. (In game terms, every space within your cities' radii that provides commerce produces an extra commerce, and every space that provides production now produces an additional one.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Golden ages last eight turns. If you achieve another golden age while in the midst of one already, the eight additional turns are tacked onto the end of the present golden age (meaning that the two ages will last a combined total of 16 turns).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]The End of the Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Once the golden age ends, your civilization's commerce and production return to normal levels.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Çíàìåíèòîñòè[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà ïðîòÿæåíèè âñåé èñòîðèè ðîæäàëèñü ëþäè, îáëàäàâøèå ñèëàìè è òàëàíòîì çíà÷èòåëüíî èçìåíÿòü ìèð âîêðóã ñåáÿ: õóäîæíèêè, ó÷åíûå, ïðîðîêè è ïðî÷èå, ÷åé ãåíèé âîçíîñèë èõ íàä òîëïîé. Â èãðå Civilization IV òàêèõ ëþäåé íàçûâàþò çíàìåíèòîñòÿìè.[PARAGRAPH:2]Â èãðå ñóùåñòâóåò 5 òèïîâ çíàìåíèòîñòåé: Âåëèêèå ïðîðîêè, Âåëèêèå òîðãîâöû, Âåëèêèå òàëàíòû, Âåëèêèå ó÷åíûå è Âåëèêèå èíæåíåðû. Êàæäûé èç ýòèõ òèïîâ îáëàäàåò óíèêàëüíîé ñïîñîáíîñòüþ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñîçäàíèå çíàìåíèòîñòåé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Çíàìåíèòîñòè ïîÿâëÿþòñÿ â ãîðîäàõ. Êàæäûé ãîðîä âûðàáàòûâàåò íåçàâèñèìîå êîëè÷åñòâî áàëëîâ "ðåéòèíãà ãåíèàëüíîñòè". Êîãäà ðåéòèíã äîñòèãàåò îïðåäåëåííîé âåëè÷èíû, îí îáíóëÿåòñÿ è íà ñâåò ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ çíàìåíèòîñòü. Ñòîèìîñòü çíàìåíèòîñòè âîçðàñòàåò: ïåðâàÿ ñòîèò 100 áàëëîâ, âòîðàÿ - 200 è òàê äàëåå. (Êîëè÷åñòâî áàëëîâ, íåîáõîäèìûõ äëÿ ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòè, îòëè÷àåòñÿ îò ñòàíäàðòíîãî â âûñîêîì è íèçêîì ñêîðîñòíûõ ðåæèìàõ.) Áåñïëàòíî çíàìåíèòîñòü ìîæåò ïîëó÷èòü äåðæàâà, ñòàâøàÿ ïåðâîîòêðûâàòåëüíèöåé îïðåäåëåííîé òåõíîëîãèè. Òàê, ïåðâîîòêðûâàòåëü [LINK=TECH_MUSIC]ìóçûêè[\LINK] ïîëó÷àåò Âåëèêèé òàëàíò. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðåéòèíã ãåíèàëüíîñòè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñóùåñòâóåò íåñêîëüêî ñïîñîáîâ çàðàáîòàòü áàëëû ãåíèàëüíîñòè: ìîæíî ïîñòðîèòü [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäî[\LINK], ïðåâðàòèòü ãîðîæàíèíà â ñïåöèàëèñòà èëè âûáðàòü îïðåäåëåííóþ [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìó[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]×óäåñà[\BOLD]. ×óäî äàåò ãîðîäó îïðåäåëåííîå êîëè÷åñòâî áàëëîâ ãåíèàëüíîñòè êàæäûé õîä. Íåêîòîðûå ÷óäåñà ìîãóò çíà÷èòåëüíî ïîâûñèòü êîëè÷åñòâî áàëëîâ ãåíèàëüíîñòè, ïðîèçâîäèìîå ãîðîäîì (à â íåêîòîðûõ ñëó÷àÿõ - è âñåé äåðæàâîé!) çà õîä (ïîäðîáíåå ñì., íàïðèìåð, [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Ïàðôåíîí[\LINK]). Êàê è ñïåöèàëèñòû (ñì. íèæå), íåêîòîðûå ÷óäåñà ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòè îïðåäåëåííîãî òèïà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñïåöèàëèñòû[\BOLD]. Â êàæäîì [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäå[\LINK] ìîæíî ïðåîáðàçîâûâàòü ãîðîæàí â ñïåöèàëèñòîâ. Êàæäûé ñïåöèàëèñò äàåò ãîðîäó îïðåäåëåííûé áîíóñ ê ïðîèçâîäñòâó, è áîëüøèíñòâî èç íèõ âûðàáàòûâàþò òàêæå áàëëû ãåíèàëüíîñòè. Åäèíñòâåííîå èñêëþ÷åíèå - ãîðîæàíèí. Òèïû ñïåöèàëèñòîâ, èìåþùèõñÿ â ãîðîäå, îïðåäåëÿþò òèï çíàìåíèòîñòè. Åñëè âñå ñïåöèàëèñòû - ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëè, çíàìåíèòîñòü îêàæåòñÿ Âåëèêèì ïðîðîêîì. Åñëè ïîëîâèíà ñïåöèàëèñòîâ òîðãîâöû, à âòîðàÿ ïîëîâèíà - õóäîæíèêè, òî çíàìåíèòîñòü èìååò ðàâíûå øàíñû ñòàòü Âåëèêèì òîðãîâöåì èëè Âåëèêèì òàëàíòîì. Åñëè ïðîâåñòè óêàçàòåëåì ìûøè íàä øêàëîé ñîçäàíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòè, âî âñïëûâàþùåé ïîäñêàçêå îòîáðàçÿòñÿ øàíñû ïîÿâëåíèÿ òîãî èëè èíîãî òèïà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïàðàäèãìû[\BOLD]. Íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK] óñêîðÿþò ñêîðîñòü ñîçäàíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Õàðàêòåðèñòèêè çíàìåíèòîñòåé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàê óæå óïîìèíàëîñü âûøå, ñóùåñòâóåò 5 òèïîâ çíàìåíèòîñòåé. Ó êàæäîãî èç ýòèõ òèïîâ åñòü ñâîè ñïîñîáíîñòè, íî ïðè ýòîì èõ îáúåäèíÿåò ðÿä õàðàêòåðèñòèê.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàçðàáîòêà òåõíîëîãèé[\BOLD]. Çíàìåíèòîñòü ìîæíî "èçðàñõîäîâàòü" íà áûñòðóþ ðàçðàáîòêó íîâîé òåõíîëîãèè. Îáû÷íî ýòà òåõíîëîãèÿ áûâàåò ñâÿçàíà ñ òèïîì çíàìåíèòîñòè (ïðîðîêè ðàçðàáàòûâàþò ðåëèãèîçíûå òåõíîëîãèè è ò.ï.), îäíàêî íåîáÿçàòåëüíî. Åñëè âñå îòíîñèòåëüíî íåäîðîãèå òåõíîëîãèè óæå ðàçðàáîòàíû, çíàìåíèòîñòü ìîæåò è íå ñïðàâèòüñÿ ñ òåõíîëîãèåé, îäíàêî â ýòîì ñëó÷àå âðåìÿ íà åå ðàçðàáîòêó ñóùåñòâåííî ñîêðàòèòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Çîëîòîé âåê[\BOLD]. Äâóõ èëè áîëåå çíàìåíèòîñòåé ìîæíî ïîòðàòèòü íà ñîçäàíèå [LINK=CONCEPT_GOLDEN_AGE]Çîëîòîãî âåêà[\LINK] (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. ñîîòâåòñòâóþùóþ ñòàòüþ).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñóïåðñïåöèàëèñòû ãîðîäà[\BOLD]. Ëþáàÿ çíàìåíèòîñòü ìîæåò îñåñòü â ãîðîäå â êà÷åñòâå "ñóïåðñïåöèàëèñòà". Ýòî äàåò ãîðîäó äîïîëíèòåëüíûå áîíóñû êàæäûé õîä (íàïðèìåð, Âåëèêèé ïðîðîê ïðèíîñèò ãîðîäó 2 åä. ïðîäóêöèè è 5 åä. çîëîòà). [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñïåöèàëüíûå ñïîñîáíîñòè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âäîáàâîê ê îáùèì ñïîñîáíîñòÿì è âîçìîæíîñòÿì êàæäûé òèï çíàìåíèòîñòåé îáëàäàåò ñâîèì, óíèêàëüíûì òàëàíòîì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âåëèêèå òàëàíòû[\BOLD]. Âåëèêèé òàëàíò ìîæåò ñîçäàòü øåäåâð, ïðèíîñÿùèé ãîðîäó åäèíîâðåìåííî îò 2000 äî 6000 åä. [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]êóëüòóðû[\LINK] (òî÷íîå êîëè÷åñòâî çàâèñèò îò ñêîðîñòè èãðû). Ýòà ñïîñîáíîñòü î÷åíü ïîëåçíà, åñëè ãîðîäó óãðîæàåò êóëüòóðíàÿ àííåêñèÿ (èëè åñëè âû ñàìè õîòèòå àííåêñèðîâàòü ãîðîä ñîñåäà). Îñåâ â ãîðîäå, Âåëèêèé òàëàíò ïðèíîñèò çíà÷èòåëüíîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö êóëüòóðû è íåáîëüøîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö èññëåäîâàíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âåëèêèå èíæåíåðû[\BOLD]. Âåëèêèé èíæåíåð ìîæåò îïòèìèçèðîâàòü ïðîèçâîäñòâî â ãîðîäå, çíà÷èòåëüíî óñêîðèâ ðàáîòó íàä òåêóùåé çàäà÷åé. Â ðàííèå ýïîõè èíæåíåð ñïîñîáåí ïîñòðîèòü ëþáîå ÷óäî çà îäèí õîä. Ñêîðîñòü ñîçäàíèÿ áîëåå ïîçäíèõ ÷óäåñ òàêæå ñóùåñòâåííî âîçðàñòàåò. Ïîñåëÿÿñü â ãîðîäå, èíæåíåð äàåò êðóïíûé ïðèðîñò ïðîäóêöèè è íåáîëüøîé - èññëåäîâàíèé..[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âåëèêèå òîðãîâöû[\BOLD]. Âåëèêèé òîðãîâåö ìîæåò ñîçäàòü "òîðãîâóþ ìèññèþ", åäèíîâðåìåííî ïðèíîñÿùóþ êðóïíóþ ñóììó äåíåã. Äëÿ ñîâåðøåíèÿ òîðãîâîé ìèññèè íóæíî ïåðåìåñòèòü òîðãîâöà â êðóïíûé ïðîöâåòàþùèé èíîñòðàííûé ãîðîä - êàê ìîæíî äàëüøå îò âàøèõ ãîðîäîâ. ×åì äàëüøå îò âàøåé äåðæàâû è ÷åì áîãà÷å ãîðîä, òåì áîëüøå çîëîòà ïðèíåñåò ìèññèÿ. Ïîñåëÿÿñü â ãîðîäå, òîðãîâöû ïðèíîñÿò áîëüøîå êîëè÷åñòâî çîëîòà è ìàëîå - ïèùè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âåëèêèå ïðîðîêè[\BOLD]. Âåëèêèå ïðîðîêè ìîãóò ñòðîèòü ðåëèãèîçíûå ñâÿòûíè: íàïðèìåð [LINK=BUILDING_JEWISH_SHRINE]Õðàì Ñîëîìîíà[\LINK] èëè [LINK=BUILDING_CONFUCIAN_SHRINE]Êóí Ìÿî[\LINK]. Ñâÿòûíè ìîæíî ñòðîèòü ÒÎËÜÊÎ ïðè íàëè÷èè ñàìîé ðåëèãèè. Ñâÿòûíþ ìîæåò ïîñòðîèòü òîëüêî ïðîðîê. Ïîñåëèâøèñü â ãîðîäå, ïðîðîê ïðèíîñèò áîëüøîå êîëè÷åñòâî çîëîòà è ìàëîå - ïðîäóêöèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âåëèêèå ó÷åíûå[\BOLD]. Âåëèêèå ó÷åíûå ìîãóò ñòðîèòü [LINK=BUILDING_ACADEMY]àêàäåìèþ[\LINK] - çäàíèå, çíà÷èòåëüíî ïîâûøàþùåå ñêîðîñòü èññëåäîâàíèé è ïðèðîñò êóëüòóðû â ãîðîäå. Ïîñåëèâøèñü â ãîðîäå, ó÷åíûé ïðèíîñèò åìó áîëüøîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö èññëåäîâàíèé è ìàëîå - ïðîäóêöèè.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Great People[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Time and again through history, there have arisen men and women who have profoundly changed the world around them - artists, scientists, prophets and others whose genius sets them head and shoulders above the rest. In Civilization IV, such visionaries are called "Great People."[PARAGRAPH:2]There are five different kinds of great people in the game: Great Prophets, Great Merchants, Great Artists, Great Scientists, and Great Engineers. Each has a special ability.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Generating Great People[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Great people are generated in cities. Each city generates a separate pool of "great people points" - when the city has earned enough points, it will generate a great person. The cost of generating a great person escalates throughout the game: the first great person costs 100 great people points, the second costs 200, and so forth. (The number of points needed to produce a great person is different on the Quick and Epic game speeds.)[PARAGRAPH:2]The first civilization to discover certain technologies will also receive a free great person in their capital city. For example, the first civ to discover [LINK=TECH_MUSIC]Music[\LINK] receives a Great Artist.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great People Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city generates great people points in a number of ways: by constructing [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK], by assigning citizens to be specialists, and by choosing certain [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A wonder will generate a certain number of great people points each turn. Further, some wonders can increase a city's (or entire civilization's!) great people point generation significantly (see the [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] for an example). Like specialists (see next), some wonders increase the chances of generating a specific type of great person in their city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Specialists:[\BOLD] In each [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK] you can assign citizens to be "specialists." Each specialist provides some kind of production bonus to its city; in addition, most generate great people points (the citizen specialist being the sole exception). Further, the kinds of specialists you have in a city determine which great people you generate: if all of your specialists in a city are priests, when that city generates a great person, he or she will be a great prophet. If half the specialists are merchants and the other half artists, you'll have a fifty-fifty chance of generating a great artist or great merchant.Moving the mouse over the great person points bar will display the percentage of getting each type of great person.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civics:[\BOLD] Some [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] increase the speed at which you generate great people.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great People Characterists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]As mentioned above, there are five types of great people. Each type has its own special abilities, but they all share some characteristics:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Can Discover New Technologies:[\BOLD] You can expend a great person to discover a new technology. Typically this technology will be in the great person's area of expertise (prophets will usually discover religious technologies and so on), but not always. Once all of the relatively inexpensive technologies have been discovered, the great person may not be able to entirely discover a new tech, but he or she can dramatically decrease the time it takes you to discover it.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Golden Ages:[\BOLD] You can expend two or more great people to start a [LINK=CONCEPT_GOLDEN_AGE]"Golden Age"[\LINK]; see that section for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Settling in Cities:[\BOLD] All great persons also have the ability to settle in a city as a sort of "super-specialist". Settling a great person in a city will add certain bonuses to that city each turn; for example, a Great Prophet will add 2 production and 5 gold to the city it settles in. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Special Abilities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] In addition to their common abilities, each great person type has other unique abilities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Artists:[\BOLD] Great Artists can create great works of art in a city; this immediately gives that city additional [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] points (from 2,000 to 6,000, depending upon game speed). This is extremely useful if a city is under cultural threat from a neighbor (or you wish to culturally attack those cities!). Great Artists can also "permanently settle" in a city, providing a continuing large cultural and small research boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Engineers:[\BOLD] Great Engineers can "hurry" a city's production, greatly speeding up the creation of whatever the city is presently constructing. Most early wonders can be completed in a single turn by Great Engineers, and later ones can be sped up dramatically. Great Engineers can permanently settle in a city, providing a continuing large production and small research boost to that city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Merchants:[\BOLD] A Great Merchant can conduct a "trade mission" which will immediately give you a whole bunch of gold. To conduct a trade mission, first move the merchant to a wealthy and powerful city as far away from your cities as possible. When the merchant reaches the target city you'll be able to conduct the mission; trade missions can ONLY be carried out in foreign cities. The value of the mission increases the further away and wealthier the target city is. Great Merchants can also settle permanently in a city, providing a continuing large commerce and small food boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Prophet:[\BOLD] Great Prophets can create religious shrines - the [LINK=BUILDING_JEWISH_SHRINE]Temple of Solomon[\LINK] and the [LINK=BUILDING_CONFUCIAN_SHRINE]Kong Miao[\LINK], for example. However, Great Prophets can create religious shrines ONLY in a city where a religion was founded. Using a Great Prophet is the only way to build a religion's shrine. Great Prophets can also settle in a city, providing a continuing large commerce and small production boost to that city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Scientist:[\BOLD] Great Scientists can construct an [LINK=BUILDING_ACADEMY]Academy[\LINK], a building which greatly boots a city's scientific research as well as its culture. Great Scientists can also settle permanently in a city, providing a large research and small production boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Íàñòðîåíèå[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Äàæå ñàìûì áåçæàëîñòíûì äèêòàòîðàì â èãðå Civilization IV ïðèõîäèòñÿ áåñïîêîèòüñÿ î íàñòðîåíèè ïîääàííûõ. Äîâîëüíûé ïîääàííûé, êàê èçâåñòíî, ðàáîòàåò ëó÷øå çà òå æå äåíüãè. Íåäîâîëüíûé ïîääàííûé áóäåò òîëüêî áåñïîëåçíîé íàãðóçêîé äëÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäà[\LINK]: îí íè÷åãî íå ïðîèçâîäèò, à åñò íå ìåíüøå ïðî÷èõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êòî íå ðàáîòàåò, òîò... âñå ðàâíî åñò![\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ó êàæäîãî ãîðîæàíèíà åñòü ðàáîòà. Áîëüøèíñòâî îáðàáàòûâàåò òåððèòîðèþ âîêðóã ãîðîäà, íåêîòîðûå ÿâëÿþòñÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]ñïåöèàëèñòàìè[\LINK], âûïîëíÿþùèìè äðóãóþ âàæíóþ ðàáîòó. Íåäîâîëüíûé ãîðîæàíèí ðàáîòàòü îòêàçûâàåòñÿ, ñîêðàùàÿ òàêèì îáðàçîì ÷èñëî ðàáîòíèêîâ èëè ñïåöèàëèñòîâ â ãîðîäå. Â òîæå âðåìÿ ýòîò ëîäûðü èñïðàâíî ïîòðåáëÿåò ñâîè 2 åäèíèöû ïèùè â õîä, à ïîòîìó ãîðîäó ñ áîëüøèì êîëè÷åñòâîì íåäîâîëüíûõ ãðîçèò ñíèæåíèå ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòè, èñòîùåíèå êàçíû, íèçêàÿ ðîæäàåìîñòü çíàìåíèòîñòåé, à âîçìîæíî, è [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]ãîëîä[\LINK]. [PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû íå äàòü ãîðîäó ðàçðàñòèñü äî ïîÿâëåíèÿ íåäîâîëüíûõ, èìååò ñìûñë èñïîëüçîâàòü ñïåöèàëèñòîâ èëè êîìàíäó "Íóëåâàÿ ðîæäàåìîñòü" íà ïàíåëè ãðàäîïðàâëåíèÿ. Â ïîñëåäíåì ñëó÷àå ïðàâèòåëü ãîðîäà ïðèîñòàíîâèò ðîñò ãîðîäà, êîãäà ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ ðèñê âîçíèêíîâåíèÿ íåäîâîëüíûõ. Âïîñëåäñòâèè, êîãäà îáùèé óðîâåíü íàñòðîåíèÿ â ãîðîäå ïîâûñèòñÿ, íàñåëåíèå ñíîâà íà÷íåò ðàñòè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê îïðåäåëèòü íàñòðîåíèå â ãîðîäå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â êàæäîì ãîðîäå èìååòñÿ ñîáñòâåííûé óðîâåíü íàñòðîåíèÿ æèòåëåé. Íåäîâîëüñòâî ñðåäè ãîðîäñêîãî íàñåëåíèÿ ìîãóò âûçûâàòü ðàçíûå ïðè÷èíû, îñíîâíûìè ñðåäè êîòîðûõ ÿâëÿþòñÿ ïåðåíàñåëåíèå è âîéíû (ñì. íèæå ïîëíûé ñïèñîê). Êàæäàÿ èç ýòèõ ïðè÷èí ïðèâîäèò ê ïîÿâëåíèþ íà ïàíåëè ãîðîäà îäíîãî èëè íåñêîëüêèõ íåäîâîëüíûõ ñìàéëèêîâ (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Ãîðîäà[\LINK]). Ñóùåñòâóåò òàêæå ðÿä ôàêòîðîâ, ïîâûøàþùèõ íàñòðîåíèå ãîðîæàí. Íå íà ïîñëåäíåì ìåñòå ñðåäè íèõ ñòîÿò ðåëèãèÿ è äîñòóï ê îïðåäåëåííûì ðåñóðñàì. Êàæäûé èç ýòèõ ôàêòîðîâ ïðèâîäèò ê ïîÿâëåíèþ äîâîëüíûõ ñìàéëèêîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû îïðåäåëèòü óðîâåíü íàñòðîåíèÿ â ãîðîäå, ñðàâíèòå êîëè÷åñòâî íåäîâîëüíûõ ñìàéëèêîâ ñ êîëè÷åñòâîì äîâîëüíûõ. Åñëè ïîñëåäíèõ áîëüøå, íàñåëåíèå ãîðîäà äîâîëüíî æèçíüþ. Åñëè áîëüøå íåäîâîëüíûõ, òî êîëè÷åñòâî íåäîâîëüíûõ æèòåëåé â ãîðîäå ðàâíî ðàçíèöå ìåæäó ÷èñëîì äîâîëüíûõ ñìàéëèêîâ è ÷èñëîì íåäîâîëüíûõ. (Òàê, åñëè â ãîðîäå 5 äîâîëüíûõ ñìàéëèêîâ è 7 íåäîâîëüíûõ, òî ðàáîòàòü îòêàæóòñÿ 2 æèòåëÿ.)[PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè â ãîðîäå åñòü õîòÿ áû îäèí íåäîâîëüíûé æèòåëü, íà ÿðëûêå ãîðîäà ðÿäîì ñ åãî íàçâàíèåì ïîÿâèòñÿ íåäîâîëüíûé ñìàéëèê.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ôàêòîðû, ñíèæàþùèå íàñòðîåíèå [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïåðåíàñåëåíèå[\BOLD]. Ñ êàæäûì íîâûì óðîâíåì â ãîðîäå ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ íîâûé íåäîâîëüíûé ñìàéëèê. ×åì áîëüøå ãîðîä, òåì ñèëüíåå íåäîâîëüñòâî.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íåäîâîëüñòâî âîéíîé[\BOLD]. ×åì äîëüøå äëèòñÿ âîéíà, òåì áîëüøå ëþäåé íà÷èíàþò âîçìóùàòüñÿ. Ýòî â ïåðâóþ î÷åðåäü êàñàåòñÿ çàõâà÷åííûõ ãîðîäîâ ïðîòèâíèêà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îòñòàâàíèå â êóëüòóðå[\BOLD]. Íåäîâîëüñòâî â ãîðîäå ðàñòåò, åñëè îí ïîïàäàåò â çîíó êóëüòóðíîãî âëèÿíèÿ ÷óæåçåìíîãî ãîðîäà (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Êóëüòóðà[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Ãðàíèöû[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íåçàùèùåííîñòü[\BOLD]. Íàñòðîåíèå ñíèæàåòñÿ, åñëè â ãîðîäå íåò íè îäíîãî âîåííîãî þíèòà. Òèï þíèòà íåâàæåí, òàê ÷òî äîñòàòî÷íî ïðîñòî ïðîñëåäèòü, ÷òîáû â êàæäîì ãîðîäå êâàðòèðîâàë õîòü îäèí âîåííûé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàáñòâî è âîèíñêàÿ ïîâèííîñòü[\BOLD]. Íàðîä íà÷èíàåò âîçìóùàòüñÿ, åñëè çàñòàâëÿòü åãî ðàáîòàòü äî ïîëóñìåðòè (ñì. [LINK=CIVIC_SLAVERY]Ðàáñòâî [\LINK]). Íå îäîáðÿþò ìèðíûå æèòåëè è ïðèíóäèòåëüíîãî ïðèçûâà â àðìèþ (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CIVIC_NATIONHOOD]Íàöèîíàëüíàÿ èäåÿ[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàâíîïðàâèå[\BOLD]. Åñëè ïðî÷èå äåðæàâû ïðèíÿëè [LINK=CIVIC_EMANCIPATION]Ðàâíîïðàâèå[\LINK], âàøè ïîääàííûå áóäóò âîçìóùàòüñÿ, ïîêà âû íå ïîñëåäóåòå ïðèìåðó ñîñåäåé. ×åì áîëüøå äåðæàâ ïðèíÿëè ýòó ïàðàäèãìó, òåì ñèëüíåå íåäîâîëüñòâî æèòåëåé îñòàâøèõñÿ äåðæàâ[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ôàêòîðû, ïîâûøàþùèå íàñòðîåíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Òàêèõ ôàêòîðîâ ìíîãî. Ïðèâåäåì íåñêîëüêî.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðåñóðñû[\BOLD]. Ìíîãèå [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñû[\LINK], â ÷àñòíîñòè [LINK=BONUS_FUR]ïóøíèíà[\LINK] è [LINK=BONUS_GOLD]çîëîòî[\LINK], ïîâûøàþò íàñòðîåíèå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Çäàíèÿ[\BOLD]. Õðàìû, [LINK=BUILDING_COLOSSEUM]ñòàäèîíû[\LINK], è [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]òåàòðû[\LINK] ïîâûøàþò íàñòðîåíèå íà ðàííèõ ñòàäèÿõ èãðû. Íàëè÷èå [LINK=BUILDING_JAIL]òþðüìû[\LINK] ñíèæàåò íåãàòèâíûé ýôôåêò, âûçûâàåìûé âîéíîé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]×óäåñà[\BOLD]. [LINK=BUILDING_GLOBE_THEATRE]Òåàòð "Ãëîáóñ[\LINK] ñíèìàåò âñå íåãàòèâíûå ýôôåêòû ñ ãîðîäà, ãäå åãî ïîñòðîèëè. [LINK=BUILDING_ROCKNROLL]Ðîê-í-ðîëë[\LINK] ïðèâîäèò ê ïîÿâëåíèþ ïîïóëÿðíûõ ïåñåí (êàæäàÿ åäèíèöà ðåñóðñà äàåò óëûáàþùèéñÿ ñìàéëèê).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïàðàäèãìû[\BOLD]. Íàëè÷èå [LINK=CIVIC_POLICE_STATE]Ïîëèöåéñêîãî ãîñóäàðñòâà[\LINK] ñíèìàåò âñå íåãàòèâíûå ýôôåêòû îò íåäîâîëüñòâà âîéíîé. [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_SPEECH]Ñâîáîäà ñëîâà[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò íàñòðîåíèå (ïðè íàëè÷èè [LINK=BUILDING_BROADCAST_TOWER]ðàäèîâûøåê[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Êíîïêè ôèíàíñèðîâàíèÿ êóëüòóðû[\BOLD]. Ïîñëå ðàçðàáîòêè òåõíîëîãèè [LINK=TECH_DRAMA]Äðàìàòóðãèÿ[\LINK] ó âàñ ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ âîçìîæíîñòü âûäåëÿòü ÷àñòü ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé êàçíû íà êóëüòóðó ïðè ïîìîùè [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]êíîïîê ôèíàíñèðîâàíèÿ êóëüòóðû[\LINK], ÷òî ïîâûøàåò êàê êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü ãîðîäà, òàê è íàñòðîåíèå æèòåëåé. Íåêîòîðûå çäàíèÿ - â ÷àñòíîñòè [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]òåàòðû[\LINK] è [LINK=BUILDING_COLOSSEUM]ñòàäèîíû[\LINK] - ïîâûøàþò ïîçèòèâíûé ýôôåêò îò ïðèìåíåíèÿ êíîïîê ôèíàíñèðîâàíèÿ êóëüòóðû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]È ýòî åùå íå âñå![\BOLD] Â ïðîöåññå èãðû âû îáíàðóæèòå ìíîãî äðóãèõ ôàêòîðîâ, âëèÿþùèõ íà íàñòðîåíèå ãîðîäñêèõ æèòåëåé.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Happiness[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]If he wants to be successful in Civilization IV, even the most ruthless dictator must give some thought to his people's happiness. A happy citizen is a productive citizen. An unhappy citizen is a useless drag on his [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK], producing nothing but still eating as much as anyone else.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Unhappiness[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Each citizen in a city has a job to do. Many are employed working the land around the city, and some few may be [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Specialists[\LINK], performing various other critical work. When a citizen is "unhappy" he or she refuses to work, thus reducing the city's laborers or specialists by one. This slacker still consumes two food each turn, however, and a city with too many unhappy citizens faces loss of productivity, commerce, a slowdown of the generation of great people, and perhaps [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Starvation[\LINK]. [PARAGRAPH:2]Rather than allowing a city to grow until it is unhappy, it is often a good idea to use specialists or the "Avoid Growth" governor command to halt a city at the size just before it would become unhappy. When more happiness is added later, the city can then go back to growing again.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Determining Happiness[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Each city has its own individual happiness level. There are many factors which can cause unhappiness in a city, with overpopulation and war being two of the most common (see below for a full list). Each source of unhappiness generates one or more "unhappy faces" (see [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK]). There are also many factors which produce happiness in a city, with religion and access to certain resources being two of the most important. Each of these generates one or more "happy faces."[PARAGRAPH:2]To determine a city's happiness, compare the number of happy faces to unhappy faces. If a city has as many or more happy faces as it has unhappy ones, all of the citizens in that city are happy. If the city has more unhappy faces than happy ones, a number of citizens equal to the difference will be unhappy. (Thus, if a city has five happy faces and seven unhappy faces, two of the city's citizens will refuse to work.)[PARAGRAPH:2]If a city has at least one unhappy citizen, an unhappy face will appear next to the city's name on the main map.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Causes of Unhappiness[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Overpopulation:[\BOLD] Every citizen in a city generates one unhappy face. The bigger the population, the more unhappy everybody is.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]War Weariness:[\BOLD] As a war continues, more and more citizens become unhappy about it. This is especially true in cities that you have recently captured from the civilization you're fighting.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cultural Inferiority:[\BOLD] A city will become unhappy if it is being "culturally dominated" by a nearby foreign city (see [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Undefended:[\BOLD] A city becomes unhappy if you have no military units in that city. The type of unit does not matter, so make sure to have at least one unit in every city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Slavery and the Draft:[\BOLD] Citizens are unhappy if you work them to death (see the [LINK=CIVIC_SLAVERY]Slavery[\LINK] civic). They don't much like it either if you forcibly draft them into the military (see the [LINK=CIVIC_NATIONHOOD]Nationhood[\LINK] civic).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Emancipation:[\BOLD] Citizens become unhappy if other civilizations have adopted the [LINK=CIVIC_EMANCIPATION]Emancipation[\LINK] civic and you have not. The more civilizations that have adopted emancipation, the more unhappy become the citizens of the remaining holdouts.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Causes of Happiness[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]There are plenty of them. Here are a few:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Resources:[\BOLD] Many [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK] produce happiness: [LINK=BONUS_FUR]Fur[\LINK] and [LINK=BONUS_GOLD]Gold[\LINK], to name two.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Buildings:[\BOLD] Temples, [LINK=BUILDING_COLOSSEUM]Colosseums[\LINK], and [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]Theatres[\LINK] are some early buildings which produce happiness. The [LINK=BUILDING_JAIL]Jail[\LINK] removes some unhappiness caused by war weariness.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] The [LINK=BUILDING_GLOBE_THEATRE]Globe Theatre[\LINK] removes all unhappiness in the city where it is built. [LINK=BUILDING_ROCKNROLL]Rock-n-Roll[\LINK] produces the Hit Singles resource, which generates one happiness.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civics:[\BOLD] The [LINK=CIVIC_POLICE_STATE]Police State[\LINK] civic negates all war weariness. [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_SPEECH]Free Speech[\LINK] produces happiness (in combination with [LINK=BUILDING_BROADCAST_TOWER]Broadcast Towers[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Culture Button:[\BOLD] After discovering the [LINK=TECH_DRAMA]Drama[\LINK] technology, you can devote a percentage of your civilization's commerce to the [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture Button[\LINK], which increases both culture and happiness. Certain buildings like [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]Theatres[\LINK] and [LINK=BUILDING_COLOSSEUM]Colosseums[\LINK] increase the happiness effect from the Culture Button even further.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]And More:[\BOLD] As you play, you will discover many other factors that can increase or decrease a city's happiness.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Çäîðîâüå[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Çäîðîâüå [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäà[\LINK] âëèÿåò íà ñêîðîñòü íàêîïëåíèÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]ïèùè[\LINK], à ñëåäîâàòåëüíî - íà ñêîðîñòü ðîñòà ãîðîäà (èëè íà ðîñò ñìåðòíîñòè îò ãîëîäà). Çäîðîâûé ãîðîä áóäåò ïðîöâåòàòü è ðàñòè, òîãäà êàê ãîðîä ñ áîëüøèì êîëè÷åñòâîì áîëüíûõ æèòåëåé îæèäàåò óïàäîê.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ôàêòîðû, âëèÿþùèå íà çäîðîâüå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà çäîðîâüå ãîðîäà ìîãóò îêàçûâàòü âëèÿíèå îêðóæàþùàÿ åãî [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]ìåñòíîñòü[\LINK], íàëè÷èå äîñòóïà ê ïðåñíîé âîäå è [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñàì[\LINK], ÷èñëåííîñòü íàñåëåíèÿ, [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]çäàíèÿ[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà[\LINK], à òàêæå ðÿä ïðèíÿòûõ â ãîñóäàðñòâå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãì[\LINK]. Îáúåêòû, ïîâûøàþùèå óðîâåíü çäîðîâüÿ, îòîáðàæàþòñÿ íà ïàíåëè ãîðîäà â âèäå áåëûõ êðóæêîâ ñ êðàñíûìè êðåñòàìè. Âðåäíûå äëÿ çäîðîâüÿ îáúåêòû îòíèìàþò ó ãîðîäà îäíó èëè íåñêîëüêî åäèíèö çäîðîâüÿ è îòîáðàæàþòñÿ â âèäå çåëåíûõ áîëåçíåííûõ ðîæèö. [PARAGRAPH:2]Âàæíûì ôàêòîðîì, óõóäøàþùèì çäîðîâüå ãîðîäà, ÿâëÿåòñÿ ÷èñëåííîñòü íàñåëåíèÿ. ×åì áîëüøå ãîðîä, òåì áîëüøå òðåáóåòñÿ åìó "áîíóñíûõ" åäèíèö çäîðîâüÿ, ÷òîáû óáåðå÷ü æèòåëåé îò ýïèäåìèè. Íåêîòîðûå çäàíèÿ - îñîáåííî ñâÿçàííûå ñ ïðîìûøëåííîñòüþ - òàêæå ìîãóò ñíèæàòü çäîðîâüå. Íàêîíåö, åñëè âàì ïðèäåòñÿ îáìåíÿòüñÿ ñ âðàæäåáíîé äåðæàâîé ïàðîé ÿäåðíûõ óäàðîâ, çîíà ïîâûøåííîé ðàäèàöèè âîêðóã ãîðîäà òàêæå íå ïîñïîñîáñòâóåò çäîðîâüþ íåìíîãèõ âûæèâøèõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê îïðåäåëèòü óðîâåíü çäîðîâüÿ â ãîðîäå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè êîëè÷åñòâî áîíóñíûõ î÷êîâ çäîðîâüÿ (êðàñíûõ êðåñòîâ) ïðåâûøàåò êîëè÷åñòâî øòðàôíûõ î÷êîâ (çåëåíûõ ðîæèö), òî çäîðîâüå â íîðìå. Åñëè øòðàôíûõ î÷êîâ áîëüøå, òî ãîðîæàí ïîðà ëå÷èòü. Áîíóñíûå è øòðàôíûå î÷êè çäîðîâüÿ îòîáðàæàþòñÿ íà ïàíåëè ãîðîäà íàä î÷êàìè íàñòðîåíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîñëåäñòâèÿ ñíèæåííîãî çäîðîâüÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà êàæäûé íåñêîìïåíñèðîâàííûé øòðàô ê çäîðîâüþ ãîðîä òðàòèò äîïîëíèòåëüíóþ åäèíèöó ïèùè. Ïðîùå ãîâîðÿ, åñëè ó ãîðîäà 2 áîíóñà ê çäîðîâüþ è 4 øòðàôà, òî ñ êàæäûì õîäîì ãîðîä áóäåò òåðÿòü 2 äîïîëíèòåëüíûå åäèíèöû ïèùè. Ýòî â ëó÷øåì ñëó÷àå ñíèçèò ñêîðîñòü ðîñòà íàñåëåíèÿ, à â õóäøåì - ïðèâåäåò ê [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]ãîëîäó[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê ïðåäîòâðàòèòü áîëåçíè â ãîðîäå [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñóùåñòâóåò íåñêîëüêî ñïîñîáîâ ïîâûñèòü çäîðîâüå â ãîðîäå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàçìåùàéòå ãîðîä ðÿäîì ñ èñòî÷íèêîì ïðåñíîé âîäû[\BOLD]. Äîñòóï ê ïðåñíîé âîäå äàåò äîïîëíèòåëüíûå î÷êè çäîðîâüÿ ñ îáðàáàòûâàåìûõ âîäíûõ êëåòîê. ×òîáû ïðîâåðèòü, ïðåñíàÿ èëè ñîëåíàÿ âîäà íà êîíêðåòíîé êëåòêå, ïðîâåäèòå íàä íåé óêàçàòåëåì ìûøè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Óëó÷øàéòå êà÷åñòâî ïèùåâûõ ðåñóðñîâ[\BOLD]. Íåêîòîðûå ïèùåâûå ðåñóðñû - â ÷àñòíîñòè [LINK=BONUS_DEER]îëåíèíà[\LINK], [LINK=BONUS_BANANA]áàíàíû[\LINK] è [LINK=BONUS_CRAB]êðàáû[\LINK] - ïðèíîñÿò äîïîëíèòåëüíûå î÷êè çäîðîâüÿ ïîñëå ïîñòðîéêè ñîîòâåòñòâóþùåãî [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]îáúåêòà[\LINK] íà êëåòêå, ãäå îíè ðàñïîëîæåíû. Åñëè èñòî÷íèê òàêîãî ðåñóðñà ñîåäèíåí ÷åðåç òîðãîâûå ïóòè áîëåå ÷åì ñ îäíèì ãîðîäîì, òî áîíóñ ê çäîðîâüþ ïîëó÷àò âñå ãîðîäà. Ó÷òèòå, ÷òî îäèí âèä ðåñóðñà äàåò íå áîëåå îäíîãî áîíóñà ê çäîðîâüþ - íåçàâèñèìî îò êîëè÷åñòâà èñòî÷íèêîâ ýòîãî ðåñóðñà (à ñëåäîâàòåëüíî, èçëèøêè ìîæíî ñìåëî ïðîäàâàòü ñîñåäÿì).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñòðîéòå çäàíèÿ è ÷óäåñà[\BOLD]. Íåêîòîðûå çäàíèÿ è ÷óäåñà òàêæå äàþò áîíóñ ê çäîðîâüþ ãîðîäà. Íà ðàííèõ ñòàäèÿõ èãðû òàêîé ôóíêöèåé îáëàäàþò [LINK=BUILDING_AQUEDUCT]àêâåäóê[\LINK] è [LINK=BUILDING_GRANARY]àìáàð[\LINK]. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàçðàáàòûâàéòå òåõíîëîãèè[\BOLD]. Ðàçðàáàòûâàéòå òåõíîëîãèè, ïîçâîëÿþùèå ñòðîèòü çäàíèÿ, êîòîðûå ïîâûøàþò çäîðîâüå. Òàê, äëÿ ïîñòðîéêè àêâåäóêà íåîáõîäèìî îñâîèòü [LINK=TECH_MATHEMATICS]ìàòåìàòèêó[\LINK] è [LINK=TECH_MASONRY]êàìåííóþ êëàäêó[\LINK]. Íà áîëåå ïîçäíèõ ñòàäèÿõ èãðû ñóùåñòâóåò íåñêîëüêî òåõíîëîãèé, äàþùèõ áîíóñ ê çäîðîâüþ âñåì ãîðîäàì âàøåé äåðæàâû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñòðîéòå ãîðîäà ðÿäîì ñ ëåñíûìè ìàññèâàìè[\BOLD]. Êëåòêè, ïîðîñøèå [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]ëåñîì[\LINK], â çîíå âëèÿíèÿ ãîðîäà äàþò ãîðîäó äîïîëíèòåëüíûå î÷êè çäîðîâüÿ. Âûðóáêà ëåñîâ ïðèâîäèò ê ñíèæåíèþ çäîðîâüÿ â ãîðîäå - áóäüòå âíèìàòåëüíåå è íå äîâåäèòå æèòåëåé äî ãîëîäíîé ñìåðòè![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ìåíÿéòå ïàðàäèãìû[\BOLD]. Íåêîòîðûå ïàðàäèãìû äàþò ãîðîäàì äåðæàâû äîïîëíèòåëüíûå î÷êè çäîðîâüÿ. Ïðèìåðîì òàêîé ïàðàäèãìû ìîæåò ïîñëóæèòü [LINK=CIVIC_ENVIRONMENTALISM]Îõðàíà ïðèðîäû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Health[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City's[\LINK] health affects the rate at which the city accumulates [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Food[\LINK], and thus the rate at which the city grows (or starves). A healthy city will grow larger, faster, while an unhealthy city will languish.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Factors Affecting Health[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Many factors affect a city's health: the [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Land[\LINK] around it and its access to water and [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK], the city's population, its [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK], and the [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] that the civilization is running. Health-giving objects provide one or more "positive health points," displayed as little red crosses in white circles. Unhealthy objects provide one or more "negative health points," displayed as green unhealthy faces. [PARAGRAPH:2]Further, a city's population can be a major source of negative health points. The larger a city is, the more positive health points it needs to cancel out its population-based unhealthiness. Certain buildings, especially ones dealing with industry, will also add unhealthiness. And, finally, if you engage in any unpleasant nuclear exchanges with your neighbors, the resulting fallout can be extremely unhealthy for the few battered survivors.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Determining a City's Overall Health[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If a city has as many or more positive points as it has negative points, that city is healthy. If the city has fewer positive points than it has negatives, that city is unhealthy. The healthy and unhealthy icons are displayed at the top of the city screen, above the happy and unhappy face icons.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Unhealthiness[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city loses one food for each point of excess unhealthiness. In other words, if a city has two positive health points and four negative points, the city will lose two food each turn. This will at the least slow the city's growth, and at the worst cause the city to [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Starve.[\LINK][PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Correcting Early Bad Health in a City[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]There are a number of steps you can take to improve the health of your cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Site the City by a River:[\BOLD] A city sited on or near to fresh water gains health points from the river spaces its citizens work. You can check whether a tile is on fresh water or not by moving the mouse cursor over it.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Improve Food Resources:[\BOLD] Various food resources - [LINK=BONUS_DEER]Deer[\LINK], [LINK=BONUS_BANANA]Bananas[\LINK] and [LINK=BONUS_CRAB]Crabs[\LINK], to name three - provide positive health points once your workers build the appropriate [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvement[\LINK] on them. And if the improved resource is connected to more than one city by your road, river, and ocean trade network, all of your cities will gain the health bonus. Note that you can never get more than one health bonus from a single kind of resource; if you have two or more of the same resource, you still get only one health point (so you might as well trade the excess resources to your neighbors in return for his or her excess resources).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Construct Buildings and Wonders:[\BOLD] Some buildings and wonders provide positive health points. The early [LINK=BUILDING_AQUEDUCT]Aqueduct[\LINK] provides positive health points, as does the [LINK=BUILDING_GRANARY]Granary[\LINK]. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Research Healthy Technologies:[\BOLD] Research the technologies which allow you to construct the healthy buildings. For instance you need to know both [LINK=TECH_MATHEMATICS]Mathematics[\LINK] and [LINK=TECH_MASONRY]Masonry[\LINK] to build an Aqueduct. There are a few late-game technologies that also add health to all of your cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Build Near Woodlands:[\BOLD] Cities receive extra health from having [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]Forest[\LINK] tiles in their city radius. Chopping down these forests will reduce the health of the city - be careful not to send the city into starvation![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Change Civics:[\BOLD] Certain civics add additional health to your cities. [LINK=CIVIC_ENVIRONMENTALISM]Environmentalism[\LINK] is one such example.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Óñêîðåíèå ïðîèçâîäñòâà[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñóùåñòâóåò íå îäèí ñïîñîá ïîâûñèòü [LINK=CONCEPT_PRODUCTION]ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü[\LINK] ãîðîäà. Íåêîòîðûå èç ýòèõ ñïîñîáîâ ïîâûøàþò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü âðåìåííî, äðóãèå äàþò ïîñòîÿííóþ ïðèáàâêó. Ïðèâåäåì íåñêîëüêî ïðèìåðîâ. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîâûøåíèå ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðîñò íàñåëåíèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]×åì áîëüøå ãîðîä, òåì áîëüøå íàðîäó ðàáîòàåò â åãî îêðåñòíîñòÿõ è òåì áîëüøå ïðîèçâîäèòñÿ ïðîäóêöèè. Óâåëè÷èâàòü [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäà[\LINK] ïîëåçíî âî âñåõ îòíîøåíèÿõ - ñëåäèòå òîëüêî çà óðîâíåì çäîðîâüÿ è íàñòðîåíèåì æèòåëåé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îáúåêòû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îáúåêòû íà êàðòå (íàïðèìåð, [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MINE]ðóäíèêè[\LINK]) ïîâûøàþò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü êëåòêè èëè äàþò îïðåäåëåííûå [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñû[\LINK]. [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_WATERMILL]Âîäÿíàÿ ìåëüíèöà[\LINK], íàïðèìåð, ïîâûøàåò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü êëåòîê, ñìåæíûõ ñ ðåêîé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Çäàíèÿ è ÷óäåñà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìíîãèå çäàíèÿ è ÷óäåñà òàêæå ïîâûøàþò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü. Òàê, [LINK=BUILDING_FORGE]ëèòåéíûé çàâîä[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò êîëè÷åñòâî ïðîèçâîäèìîé ãîðîäîì ïðîäóêöèè íà 25%, à [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_DAM]äàìáà "Òðè óùåëüÿ"[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü âî âñåõ ãîðîäàõ íà 10%.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âåëèêèé èíæåíåð [\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îäèí èç ñïîñîáîâ èñïîëüçîâàòü [LINK=UNIT_ENGINEER]Âåëèêîãî èíæåíåðà[\LINK] - ïîæåðòâîâàòü èì â îáìåí íà ðàçîâóþ êðóïíóþ ïðèáàâêó åäèíèö ïðîäóêöèè. Âåëèêèå èíæåíåðû ìîãóò òàêæå óñêîðÿòü ïîñòðîéêó ÷óäåñ íà ðàííèõ ñòàäèÿõ èãðû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñïåöèàëèñòû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Ñïåöèàëèñò[\LINK]-èíæåíåð ïîâûøàåò ïðèòîê ïðîäóêöèè íà 2 åäèíèöû çà õîä. Äðóãèå ñïåöèàëèñòû òàêæå ìîãóò ïîâûøàòü ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü ãîðîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàðàäèãìû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îðãàíèçîâàííàÿ ðåëèãèÿ[\BOLD]. [LINK=CIVIC_ORGANIZED_RELIGION]Îðãàíèçîâàííàÿ ðåëèãèÿ[\LINK]ïîâûøàåò ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü ãîðîäà íà 25%, íî òîëüêî â ñëó÷àå ñòðîèòåëüñòâà ãîðîäà è òîëüêî åñëè òàì èñïîâåäóåòñÿ ãîñóäàðñòâåííàÿ ðåëèãèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âñåîáùåå èçáèðàòåëüíîå ïðàâî[\BOLD]. [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Âñåîáùåå èçáèðàòåëüíîå ïðàâî[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò íà 1 åäèíèöó ïðîèçâîäèòåëüíîñòü [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]ãîðîäêîâ[\LINK], à òàêæå ïîçâîëÿåò óñêîðÿòü ñîçäàíèå þíèòîâ è çäàíèé çà äåíüãè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Áþðîêðàòèÿ[\BOLD]. [LINK=CIVIC_BUREAUCRACY]Áþðîêðàòèÿ[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò ïðèòîê ïðîäóêöèè è äåíåã â ñòîëèöå íà 50%.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàáñòâî[\BOLD]. [LINK=CIVIC_SLAVERY]Ðàáñòâî[\LINK] ïîçâîëÿåò óñêîðÿòü ïðîèçâîäñòâî, æåðòâóÿ íàñåëåíèåì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íàöèîíàëüíàÿ èäåÿ[\BOLD]. [LINK=CIVIC_NATIONHOOD]Íàöèîíàëüíàÿ èäåÿ[\LINK] ïîçâîëÿåò ïðèçûâàòü ãðàæäàíñêîå íàñåëåíèå íà âîåííóþ ñëóæáó. Ïðè ýòîì ñíèæàåòñÿ íàñòðîåíèå è ñîêðàùàåòñÿ íàñåëåíèå ãîðîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Hurry Production[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are various ways to increase a city's [LINK=CONCEPT_PRODUCTION]Productivity[\LINK], some permanent, some of limited duration. Here are some examples: [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Increasing Productivity[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Population Growth[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The bigger a city, the more population that is available to work the land and thus generate hammers. It is generally a good idea to grow your [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK] as large as the health and happiness of the city will allow.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Improvements[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Tile improvements such as [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MINE]Mines[\LINK] increase the productivity of a hill or certain [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK]. A [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_WATERMILL]Watermill[\LINK] will increase the productivity of squares next to a river. And there are others, as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Buildings and Wonders[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Many buildings and wonders increase your productivity. For example, a [LINK=BUILDING_FORGE]Forge[\LINK] increases a city's productivity by 25%%, while the [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_DAM]Three Gorges Dam[\LINK] wonder increases all of your cities' productivity by 10%%.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The Great Engineer[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A [LINK=UNIT_ENGINEER]Great Engineer[\LINK] can be sacrificed for a large number of production points, but this act consumes the unit. Great Engineers are useful for rushing early wonders.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Specialists[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The Engineer [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Specialist[\LINK] increases his city's productivity by two hammers. Other specialists may increase productivity as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Civics[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Organized Religion:[\BOLD] The [LINK=CIVIC_ORGANIZED_RELIGION]Organized Religion[\LINK] civic increases a city's productivity by 25%%, but ONLY when that city is constructing a building and only if your state religion is present in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Universal Suffrage:[\BOLD] [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Universal Suffrage[\LINK] increases [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Town[\LINK] productivity by 1. It also allows you to spend gold to complete construction of a unit or building.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Bureaucracy:[\BOLD] [LINK=CIVIC_BUREAUCRACY]Bureaucracy[\LINK] increases the production (and commerce) in your capital by 50%%.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Slavery:[\BOLD] [LINK=CIVIC_SLAVERY]Slavery[\LINK] allows you to sacrifice a city's population to complete production on an item.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Nationhood:[\BOLD] [LINK=CIVIC_NATIONHOOD]Nationhood[\LINK] allows you to "draft" a city's population for military service. Drafting military units causes unhappiness and a reduction of population in the drafted city.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Îáúåêòû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Îñíîâà âûæèâàíèÿ ÷åëîâå÷åñêèõ ïîñåëåíèé - áëèçëåæàùèå ïðèðîäíûå ðåñóðñû. Ñíà÷àëà ïîñåëåíèå ïîëüçóåòñÿ èìè, íå ïðåîáðàçóÿ ìåñòíîñòü: æåíùèíû ñîáèðàþò îðåõè è ÿãîäû, ìóæ÷èíû îõîòÿòñÿ. Îäíàêî ðàíî èëè ïîçäíî ýòèõ ëåãêîäîñòóïíûõ ðåñóðñîâ íà÷èíàåò íå õâàòàòü, íàñåëåíèå ãîðîäà ðàñòåò è ëþäè îêàçûâàþòñÿ ïåðåä âûáîðîì: ðàçâèâàòüñÿ èëè óìèðàòü îò ãîëîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñî âðåìåíåì ÷åëîâåê èçîáðåòàë âñå íîâûå è íîâûå ñïîñîáû ïîëó÷åíèÿ îò ïðèðîäû ñðåäñòâ ê ïðîïèòàíèþ. Ïîÿâèëèñü ôåðìû, îáåñïå÷èâàþùèå ëþäåé ïèùåé, ïîÿâèëèñü ðóäíèêè, äàþùèå ìåòàëëû è òîïëèâî.
