Âîäÿíûå ìåëüíèöû ïîä÷èíèëè ÷åëîâå÷åñêèì íóæäàì ìîãó÷èå ðåêè. ×åëîâåê îñâàèâàåò çåìëþ, ïîêðûâàÿ åå ðóêîòâîðíûìè îáúåêòàìè, çàñòàâëÿåò åå ñëóæèòü ñâîåìó ïëåìåíè, êîòîðîå òåì âðåìåíåì ðàñòåò è ìíîæèòñÿ. Ñïîñîáíîñòü ïîëó÷àòü âñå áîëüøå áëàã âñå ìåíüøèìè óñèëèÿìè ôàêòè÷åñêè ëåãëà â îñíîâó ðàçâèòèÿ ÷åëîâå÷åñêîé öèâèëèçàöèè: åñëè îäèí ÷åëîâåê ñïîñîáåí ïðîèçâåñòè ïèùó íà äâîèõ, âòîðîé èñïîëüçóåò îñâîáîäèâøèåñÿ âðåìÿ è ñèëû íà ñîçäàíèå ðîìàíà, êàðòèíû èëè ãîòè÷åñêîãî ñîáîðà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàçìåùåíèå îáúåêòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Îáúåêòû, îáñëóæèâàþùèå îïðåäåëåííûé ãîðîä, ñëåäóåò ðàçìåùàòü â ïðåäåëàõ åãî [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]çîíû âëèÿíèÿ[\LINK]. Îáúåêòû, äàþùèå äåðæàâå äîñòóï ê îïðåäåëåííûì [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñàì[\LINK], ìîæíî ðàçìåùàòü ãäå óãîäíî âíóòðè [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]êóëüòóðíûõ ãðàíèö[\LINK] äåðæàâû. (Âïðî÷åì, åñëè åñòü âîçìîæíîñòü, òî ëó÷øå èõ òîæå ðàçìåùàòü â ãîðîäñêîé çîíå âëèÿíèÿ.) [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äîñòóïíîñòü îáúåêòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìíîãèå îáúåêòû ìîæíî ñòðîèòü òîëüêî â îïðåäåëåííûõ ìåñòàõ. Òàê, ðóäíèêè ðàçìåùàþòñÿ òîëüêî â õîëìàõ (èëè íà èñòî÷íèêàõ [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñîâ[\LINK]), òîãäà êàê ôåðìû ñëåäóåò ñòðîèòü íà ìåñòíîñòè ñ äîñòóïîì ê ïðåñíîé âîäå (äî ïðèíÿòèÿ ïàðàäèãìû [LINK=CIVIC_CIVIL_SERVICE]Ãðàæäàíñêàÿ ñëóæáà[\LINK]). Êðîìå òîãî, êàæäûé îáúåêò òðåáóåò íàëè÷èÿ îïðåäåëåííîé òåõíîëîãèè. Òàê, ôåðìû íåäîñòóïíû äî èçó÷åíèÿ [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]çåìëåäåëèÿ[\LINK]. Íàêîíåö, íåêîòîðûå îáúåêòû òðåáóþò äîñòóïà ê îïðåäåëåííûì ðåñóðñàì. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Æåëåçíûå äîðîãè[\LINK], íàïðèìåð, íåëüçÿ ñòðîèòü áåç óãëÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàáîòíèêè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â èãðå Civilization IV áîëüøèíñòâî îáúåêòîâ ñòðîÿò [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]ðàáîòíèêè[\LINK], êîòîðûõ âû ãîòîâèòå â ãîðîäàõ. Ýòè þíèòû íå óìåþò íè ñðàæàòüñÿ, íè ñòðîèòü íîâûå ãîðîäà, íî ñïîñîáíû ñîçäàâàòü ôåðìû, äîðîãè è ðóäíèêè, ÷òîáû ãîðîäà ðîñëè, ðàçâèâàëèñü è ìíîæèëèñü. Åñëè ðàáî÷èõ íåäîñòàòî÷íî, äåðæàâà íå ñìîæåò ðàñòè è ïðîöâåòàòü.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïðîìûøëåííûå ñóäà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]Ïðîìûøëåííûå ñóäà[\LINK] - ýòî âîäíûé àíàëîã ðàáîòíèêîâ: îíè ñòðîÿò âîäíûå îáúåêòû, ðûáîëîâíûå è êèòîáîéíûå ñóäà, à ïîçæå - ìîðñêèå íåôòåäîáûâàþùèå ïëàòôîðìû. Âàæíîå îòëè÷èå ïðîìûøëåííûõ ñóäîâ îò ðàáîòíèêîâ ñîñòîèò â òîì, ÷òî ñóäà èñ÷åçàþò, çàâåðøèâ ðàáîòó. Äëÿ êàæäîãî âîäíîãî îáúåêòà ïðèäåòñÿ ïîñòðîèòü íîâîå ñóäíî, òîãäà êàê ðàáîòíèê, çàâåðøèâ îäèí îáúåêò, ïðîñòî ïåðåõîäèò ê ñëåäóþùåìó. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñòðîèòåëüñòâî îáúåêòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû ïîñòðîèòü îáúåêò, ïåðåìåñòèòå íà íóæíîå ìåñòî ðàáîòíèêà. Äîñòóïíûå äëÿ ïîñòðîéêè îáúåêòû ïåðå÷èñëåíû íà åãî ïàíåëè êîìàíä. Åñëè âàøà äåðæàâà îáëàäàåò íóæíûìè òåõíîëîãèÿìè è ðåñóðñàìè è åñëè íóæíûé îáúåêò ìîæíî ñòðîèòü â ìåñòå, êîòîðîå âû óêàçàëè, òî ýòîò îáúåêò ïîÿâèòñÿ íà ïàíåëè êîìàíä. Ùåëêíèòå åãî, è ðàáî÷èé ïðèìåòñÿ çà ðàáîòó. Åñëè îáúåêò îòîáðàæåí íà ïàíåëè êàê íåäîñòóïíûé (òóñêëîå èçîáðàæåíèå), òî â äàííûé ìîìåíò åãî ïîñòðîèòü íåëüçÿ. ×òîáû âûÿñíèòü, êàêèå óñëîâèÿ íóæíî âûïîëíèòü äëÿ ïîñòðîéêè, çàäåðæèòå íà èçîáðàæåíèè îáúåêòà óêàçàòåëü ìûøè. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîñòðîéêà äîðîã è æåëåçíûõ äîðîã[\BOLD]. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Äîðîãè[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]æåëåçíûå äîðîãè[\LINK] ìîæíî ñòðîèòü äâóìÿ ñïîñîáàìè: âðó÷íóþ îòñòðîèòü äîðîãó êëåòêà çà êëåòêîé - èëè èñïîëüçîâàòü êîìàíäó "Ïðîêëàäêà ïóòè": ùåëêíóòü ñîîòâåòñòâóþùóþ êíîïêó íà ïàíåëè êîìàíä, à çàòåì - êâàäðàò, ê êîòîðîìó ñëåäóåò ïðîëîæèòü äîðîãó. Ðàáîòíèê àâòîìàòè÷åñêè âû÷èñëèò êðàò÷àéøèé ïóòü äî êîíå÷íîé òî÷êè è ïîñòðîèò äîðîãó, íå òðåáóÿ äàëüíåéøèõ óêàçàíèé. Ó÷òèòå, ÷òî ïðè âñåé ýêîíîìèè âàøåãî âðåìåíè ýòîò ñïîñîá ÷ðåâàò òåì, ÷òî âàøè ïðåäñòàâëåíèÿ îá îïòèìàëüíîì ìàðøðóòå ðàçîéäóòñÿ ñ ìíåíèåì ðàáîòíèêà. Ïîäðîáíåå î âëèÿíèè äîðîã íà ñêîðîñòü ïåðåìåùåíèÿ ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Äâèæåíèå[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñêîðîñòü ñòðîèòåëüñòâà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà ñîçäàíèå îáúåêòà ìîæåò óéòè îäèí èëè áîëåå õîäîâ. Ñêîðîñòü ñòðîèòåëüñòâà çàâèñèò îò ïðèíÿòûõ äåðæàâîé [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãì[\LINK], à òàêæå íåêîòîðûõ [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]òåõíîëîãèé[\LINK]. Åñëè îäèí îáúåêò ñòðîÿò äâîå èëè áîëüøå ðàáî÷èõ, ñêîðîñòü ñîêðàùàåòñÿ ïðèìåðíî âäâîå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïðåðûâàíèå ñòðîèòåëüñòâà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû ïðåðâàòü ñòðîèòåëüñòâî îáúåêòà íà ëþáîé ñòàäèè, äîñòàòî÷íî ùåëêíóòü ðàáîòíèêà è äàòü åìó íîâûå èíñòðóêöèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàçîðåíèå è ãðàáåæ îáúåêòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âîåííûå þíèòû ìîãóò óíè÷òîæàòü îáúåêòû íà íåéòðàëüíîé è âðàæåñêîé. Íàïðàâüòå þíèò ê îáúåêòó è íàæìèòå êíîïêó "Ãðàáèòü". Ó÷òèòå, ÷òî íà ýòî áóäóò ïîòðà÷åíà ÷àñòü åäèíèö äâèæåíèÿ. Çà ýòîò àêò âàíäàëèçìà âû ìîæåòå äàæå ïîëó÷èòü òðîôåè! Åñëè â êëåòêå ðàçìåùåíû íåñêîëüêî îáúåêòîâ (íàïðèìåð, äîðîãà è ðóäíèê), âàø þíèò óíè÷òîæèò èõ ïî îäíîìó çà õîä. Ó÷òèòå, ÷òî êî÷åâûå [LINK=CONCEPT_BARBARIANS]âàðâàðû[\LINK] ñ îãðîìíûì óäîâîëüñòâèåì ðàçãðàáÿò âàøè îáúåêòû, åñëè èì ïðåäñòàâèòñÿ òàêàÿ âîçìîæíîñòü.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Improvements[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Human settlements survive on the natural resources available to them from nearby terrain. At first they may do this without "working the land" - they may glean nearby forests for nuts and berries, while hunters bring in whatever local animals are at hand. However, these local resources tend to be finite, and as a settlement's population expands they must improve their ability to gather sustenance or starve.[PARAGRAPH:2]Over time, Man has developed sophisticated techniques for obtaining ever-increasing resources from the land. He builds farms to increase his food supply. He builds mines to obtain metals and fuels. He builds water mills to harness the power of rivers. He "improves" the land, making it capable of supporting ever-larger populations. In fact, Man's ability to gather greater resources with fewer people is the basis for all of civilization: if one man can create enough food for two, the second man is free to create writing, or paint a picture, or build a cathedral.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Location of Improvements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Improvements directly benefiting specific cities must be within that city's [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City Radius[\LINK], while improvements allowing your civilization access to certain [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK] can be anywhere within your civilization's [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Cultural Borders[\LINK] (though it is usually good if they are also within a city's radius).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Availability of Improvements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Many improvements can be built only in specific locations: mines, for instance, must be built on hills (or atop certain [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK]), while farms can be built only where fresh water is available (until researching [LINK=CIVIC_CIVIL_SERVICE]Civil Service[\LINK]). Further, all improvements have a technology requirement; for example, you cannot build farms until your civilization has discovered [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]Agriculture.[\LINK] Finally, some improvements require that you have access to specific resources. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Railroads[\LINK] require coal, for example.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Workers[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, most improvements are built by [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]Workers[\LINK] created in cities. These units cannot fight, nor can they create new cities, but they can build the farms, roads, and mines needed to support ever-bigger and more powerful cities. A civilization cannot flourish and grow without enough Workers.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Work Boats[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]Work Boats[\LINK] are similar to Workers in that they can construct improvements on water; they can build fishing boats, whaling boats, and, later on, offshore platforms. There is one major difference between Work Boats and Workers, however; a Work Boat is consumed when it creates an improvement. You'll need to build one Work Boat for every at sea improvement you wish to accomplish. (Workers are not consumed when building improvements.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Constructing Improvements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] To build an improvement, move a Worker to the space you want to improve. The actions available to that Worker are displayed in the "unit button" section of the main screen; if your civilization meets the technology and resource requirement for an improvement and if that improvement can be built on that space, it will appear in the Worker's unit button. Click on the improvement and your Worker will begin construction. (If the improvement is greyed-out, you cannot make that improvement at that time. Mouse over the improvement to see what you are missing.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Constructing Roads and Railroads:[\BOLD] You can build [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Roads[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Railroads[\LINK] in one of two ways: you can manually build the road one space at a time, or you can use the "Route To" command, in which you click on "Route To" and then on the target space. The Worker will figure out the shortest route to the target space and construct the road to that space without further orders. (Beware: this method requires less work from you, but your Workers sometimes may not choose what you would consider the most optimal route.) See [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Movement[\LINK] for the effects of roads on movement.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Time of Construction[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Improvements take one or more turns to complete. Time of construction varies, depending upon the [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] you have in place, and certain [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technologies[\LINK] will shorten construction time as well. Finally, two or more workers can construct the same improvement simultaneously, cutting the time of construction roughly in half.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Interrupting Construction[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can stop working on an improvement at any time: simply click on the Worker building the improvement and give him new orders.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Pillaging Improvements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Military units can destroy improvements in neutral territory or in the territory of a civilization you are at war with. To do so, move the unit to the target improvement and then click on the "Pillage" button (this will use up one of the unit's movement points). You may even be rewarded with plunder for your act of vandalism! If there are multiple improvements in a space (a road and a mine, for example) your unit will destroy one of them per turn. Note that roving [LINK=CONCEPT_BARBARIANS]Barbarians[\LINK] will happily pillage your improvements if they get the chance.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ëèäåðû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ êàæäîé äåðæàâû â èãðå ïðåäóñìîòðåí îäèí èëè äâà ëèäåðà. Ñíà÷àëà âû âûáèðàåòå äåðæàâó, çàòåì, åñëè ëèäåðîâ äâîå - îäíîãî èç íèõ. Ó äåðæàâ, çà êîòîðûõ èãðàåò êîìïüþòåð, òàêæå åñòü ëèäåðû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ëè÷íîñòü[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â âàøèõ ðóêàõ ëèäåð âåäåò ñåáÿ êàê çàõîòèòå: ÷åñòíî èëè âåðîëîìíî, äîâåð÷èâî èëè ñêðûòíî, âîèíñòâåííî èëè ìèðíî. Êîãäà çà ëèäåðà èãðàåò êîìïüþòåð, îí ñàì îïðåäåëÿåò ñâîéñòâà ëè÷íîñòè - îáû÷íî â ñîîòâåòñòâèè ñ èñòîðè÷åñêèì ïðîîáðàçîì, íî íå âñåãäà. Ãàíäè îáû÷íî ìèðîëþáèâ è ïðèâåòëèâ, íî âðåìåíàìè äàæå åìó ñëó÷àåòñÿ îêàçàòüñÿ êîâàðíûì àãðåññîðîì, òàê ÷òî ñìîòðèòå â îáà![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïåðåãîâîðû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Îò ëè÷íîñòè ëèäåðà è îò òîãî, êàê åìó âèäèòñÿ òåêóùàÿ ñèòóàöèÿ, çàâèñèò, êàê îí ïîâåäåò ñ âàìè ïåðåãîâîðû. Åùå ó ëèäåðîâ õîðîøàÿ ïàìÿòü: îíè ïîìíÿò óñëóãè, íî íå çàáûâàþò è îáìàíû. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Äèïëîìàòèÿ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]×åðòû õàðàêòåðà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ó ëèäåðîâ â èãðå åñòü ÷åðòû õàðàêòåðà, îò êîòîðûõ çàâèñèò, êàêîé äåðæàâîé èì ïðîùå óïðàâëÿòü. Êàæäûé íàäåëåí äâóìÿ èç ñëåäóþùèõ ÷åðò:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîëêîâîäåö[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Áåñïëàòíàÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]êâàëèôèêàöèÿ[\LINK] "Áîé I" äëÿ ïåõîòíûõ è îãíåñòðåëüíûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ìåöåíàò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 åäèíèöû [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]êóëüòóðû[\LINK] çà õîä â êàæäîì ãîðîäå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ýêñïàíñèîíèñò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 åäèíèöû [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]çäîðîâüÿ[\LINK] â êàæäîì ãîðîäå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ôèíàíñèñò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 åäèíèöà [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]êîììåðöèè[\LINK] äëÿ êàæäîé êëåòêè, êîòîðàÿ áåç ýòîé íàäáàâêè ïðîèçâîäèò íå ìåíåå äâóõ åäèíèö.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Õîçÿéñòâåííèê[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50% ê ñêîðîñòè ñîçäàíèÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDER]÷óäåñ ñâåòà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îðãàíèçàòîð[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-50% îò ðàñõîäîâ íà [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ôèëîñîô[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100% ê ÷àñòîòå ïîÿâëåíèÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]çíàìåíèòîñòåé[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ìèñòèê[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðè ñìåíå ïàðàäèãì íå âîçíèêàåò àíàðõèè.[PARAGRAPH:2]Êàæäàÿ ÷åðòà õàðàêòåðà òàêæå ïîçâîëÿåò ñîçäàâàòü îïðåäåëåííûé òèï ïîñòðîåê âäâîå áûñòðåå - íàïðèìåð, ëèäåðû-ôèëîñîôû áûñòðåå ñòðîÿò [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]óíèâåðñèòåòû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñïèñîê ëèäåðîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Èìååòñÿ ñïåöèàëüíûé [LINK=LEADER_ALEXANDER]ñïèñîê ëèäåðîâ[\LINK], ãäå îíè ïåðå÷èñëåíû âìåñòå ñî ñâîèìè ÷åðòàìè õàðàêòåðà è èñòîðè÷åñêîé ñïðàâêîé.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Leaders[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Each civilization in Civilization IV has one or two leaders available to lead it. When you start a game of Civ, you will pick which civilization you want to lead; if that civilization has two available leaders, you pick them which of them you want to play. Each computer-controlled civilization has a leader as well.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Leader Personalities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When you control a leader, you determine how your leader interacts with the world around him or her. Is the leader honest or shifty? Is the leader open, or paranoid? Is the leader aggressive or peaceful? It's up to you. When the computer controls a leader, the computer determines the leader's behavior. Often, the leader behaves like his or her historical counterparts - but don't count on it. Gandhi will USUALLY be peaceful and friendly, but he may from time to time turn out to be a warmongering backstabber. You have been warned!.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leaders and Diplomacy[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A leader's personality and his or her interpretation of the current game situation will determine how the leader negotiates with you. Further, leaders have long memories; if you deal fairly with them, they'll remember it. And if you betray them, they'll remember that, as well. Check out [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK] for more information on this topic.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leader Traits[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Leaders in Civilization have "traits" which help determine the kind of civilization they are best at running. Each leader has two of the following traits:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aggressive[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Free "Combat I" [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Promotion[\LINK] for melee and gunpowder units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Creative[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] per city per turn.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Expansive[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+2 [LINK=CONCEPT_HEALTH]Health Points[\LINK] per city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Financial[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+1 [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]Commerce[\LINK] on any squares which normally produce two or more commerce.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Industrious[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+50%% [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDER]Wonder[\LINK] production.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organized[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]-50%% [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civic Upkeep[\LINK] cost.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Philosophical[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]+100%% [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Person[\LINK] birth rate.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Spiritual[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]No anarchy from changing civics.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each trait also allows civilizations that possess it to construct some buildings at double speed; for example, leaders with the Philosophical trait build [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]Universities[\LINK] twice as fast.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Leader List[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Check out the [LINK=LEADER_ALEXANDER]Leader List[\LINK] for a complete list of the leaders in Civilization IV, their game traits, and historical backgrounds.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ñîäåðæàíèå ãîñàïïàðàòà[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]×åì êðóïíåå ñòàíîâèòñÿ äåðæàâà, òåì áîëåå ðàçâèòîé èíôðàñòðóêòóðû îíà òðåáóåò. Èìïåðèÿ íå ïðîñòî ðàñøèðÿåòñÿ - îíà òÿæåëååò, îáðàñòàÿ áþðîêðàòè÷åñêèì ñîñëîâèåì, íåïîâîðîòëèâûìè è ïðîäàæíûìè ÷èíîâíèêàìè. Â èãðå ýòîò ïðîöåññ ïðîÿâëÿåòñÿ êàê ðàñõîäû íà ñîäåðæàíèå ãîðîäîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñòîèìîñòü ñîäåðæàíèÿ ãîðîäà îïðåäåëÿåòñÿ äâóìÿ ôàêòîðàìè: îáùèì êîëè÷åñòâîì ãîðîäîâ è óäàëåííîñòüþ îò àäìèíèñòðàòèâíîãî öåíòðà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êîëè÷åñòâî ãîðîäîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×åì áîëüøå ãîðîäîâ, òåì äîðîæå îáõîäèòñÿ êàæäûé èç íèõ. Ðàçðàñòàÿñü, äåðæàâà áûñòðî îùóòèò ôèíàíñîâûå òðóäíîñòè. Ïóñòü ïåðâûé ãîðîä ñòîèë îäíó åäèíèöó çîëîòà, à êàæäûé ñëåäóþùèé äîáàâëÿåò åùå ïî åäèíèöå. Îäèí ãîðîä - îäíà åäèíèöà, äâà - äâå çà êàæäûé, èòîãî ÷åòûðå, òðè ãîðîäà - äåâÿòü, è òàê äàëåå (èìåéòå â âèäó, ÷òî ýòè öèôðû ïðèâåäåíû ëèøü äëÿ ïðèìåðà, íà ñàìîì äåëå ðàñõîäû ðàññ÷èòûâàþòñÿ ïî áîëåå ñëîæíûì çàêîíàì).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Óäàëåííîñòü îò öåíòðà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðàñõîäû íà ñîäåðæàíèå ãîðîäà òàêæå ñâÿçàíû ñ ðàññòîÿíèåì îò íåãî äî ñòîëèöû. Â íà÷àëå èãðû àäìèíèñòðàòèâíûé öåíòð âàøåé äåðæàâû - [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]äâîðåö[\LINK], êîòîðûé àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ â ïåðâîì ïîñòðîåííîì ãîðîäå. ×åì äàëüøå îò äâîðöà, òåì äîðîæå îáõîäèòñÿ ãîðîä.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê ñíèçèòü ðàñõîäû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñóäû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðàñõîäû íà ãîðîä ñíèæàþòñÿ íàïîëîâèíó, åñëè ïîñòðîèòü [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]ñóä[\LINK]. Êðîìå òîãî, ñóäû ïîçâîëÿþò ñîçäàòü Çàïðåòíûé ãîðîä (îá ýòîì ìàëîì ÷óäå ñâåòà ñì. äàëåå). Åñëè äåðæàâà èç-çà ÷ðåçìåðíîé ýêñïàíñèè âîò-âîò ðàçîðèòñÿ, íå òåðÿéòå âðåìåíè: ñòðîéòå ñóäû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïåðåíîñ äâîðöà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè äâîðåö îêàçàëñÿ íà îêðàèíå, ìîæíî ïåðåíåñòè åãî áëèæå ê öåíòðó ñòðàíû. Ïîìíèòå: êàê òîëüêî ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ íîâûé äâîðåö, ñòàðûé èñ÷åçàåò.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äîïîëíèòåëüíûå öåíòðû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Äâà ÷óäà ñâåòà, [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Çàïðåòíûé ãîðîä[\LINK] è [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Âåðñàëü[\LINK], ñëóæàò äîïîëíèòåëüíûìè àäìèíèñòðàòèâíûìè öåíòðàìè. Ñòîèìîñòü îïðåäåëÿåòñÿ ðàññòîÿíèåì äî áëèæàéøåãî öåíòðà, ïîýòîìó, ðàñêèäàâ èõ ïî ðàçíûì óãëàì èìïåðèè, ìîæíî î÷åíü ïðèëè÷íî ñýêîíîìèòü. Çàïðåòíûé ãîðîä - [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]ìàëîå ÷óäî ñâåòà[\LINK], êîòîðîå ìîæåò ïîñòðîèòü êàæäûé, à âîò Âåðñàëü óíèêàëåí, òàê ÷òî íå äàéòå ñåáÿ îïåðåäèòü.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãîñóäàðñòâåííàÿ ñîáñòâåííîñòü[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]Ãîñóäàðñòâåííàÿ ñîáñòâåííîñòü[\LINK] óñòðàíÿåò ðàñõîäû, âûçâàííûå ðàññòîÿíèåì îò àäìèíèñòðàòèâíîãî öåíòðà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Áîëüøå êàïèòàëà![\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñòü è åùå îäèí ñïîñîá áîðüáû ñ ðàñõîäàìè íà ãîðîäà: íå óìñòâîâàòü, à íàêîïèòü äåíåã. Êàê ýòî ñäåëàòü, ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Êàïèòàë[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Maintenance[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]As a civilization grows, it requires an ever-larger infrastructure to support it. Entire new layers of bureaucrats appear to handle the increasingly complex business of empire. And with every new layer of bureaucracy comes new inefficiencies, as well as increased opportunities for corruption. In Civilization IV, this is reflected in your civilization's "city maintenance cost."[PARAGRAPH:2]Two factors determine a civilization's basic city maintenance cost: the number of cities you possess, and the distance of individual cites from a seat of government.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Number of Cities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]As you add cities to your civilization, the cost of managing EVERY city increases. Thus, as your civilization grows, adding new cities will quickly drive up your city maintenance costs. For instance, let's assume that the first city costs one gold to manage, and every new city increases the cost of managing your cities by one. So you pay one gold in management expenses when you have one city. When you build another city, you are now paying two gold PER city, so your overall costs goes up to four. Adding a third city will increase your maintenance costs to nine, and so on. (Note that these numbers are for example only; the actual formula for determining maintenance is more complex.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Distance from Seat of Government[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city's maintenance cost is also affected by its distance from a "seat of government." At game start the [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]Palace[\LINK], which appears automatically in the first city you build, is your seat of government. Cities farther away from the palace are more expensive to maintain than closer cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Lowering Maintenance Costs[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Courthouses[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Building a [LINK=BUILDING_COURTHOUSE]Courthouse[\LINK] cuts a city's maintenance cost in half. Courthouses are also required to build the Forbidden Palace national wonder (see below). If your civ finds itself choking under high maintenance costs from expanding too far afield, make sure to build courthouses as quickly as possible.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Move Your Palace[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If your palace is out on the edge of your civilization, you can construct it in a more centralized position. Warning: the original palace disappears when the new one appears.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Add Seats of Government[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Two wonders, the [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Forbidden Palace[\LINK] and [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles,[\LINK] act as additional seats of government. Cities pay maintenance based upon their distance to the NEAREST seat of government, so spreading these about your empire will do wonders for lowering your maintenance costs. Although the Forbidden Palace is a [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]National Wonder[\LINK] and always available to your civ, be aware that only one civilization in the world will be able to construct Versailles.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]State Property[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CIVIC_STATE_PROPERTY]State Property[\LINK] civic removes all distance-based maintenance costs.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Make More Money![\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can, of course, counter the rising costs of city maintenance by simply making more money. See [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Wealth[\LINK] for further suggestions.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Êàðòû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Â èãðå åñòü òðè òèïà êàðò: îñíîâíàÿ, ìèíè-êàðòà è èãðîâûå êàðòû. Îñíîâíàÿ êàðòà è ìèíè-êàðòà âõîäÿò â èíòåðôåéñ; ñ íèìè âàñ çíàêîìèò îáó÷àþùàÿ èãðà. Äàííûé ðàçäåë ïîñâÿùåí òîëüêî èãðîâûì êàðòàì.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Èãðîâûå êàðòû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà èãðîâûõ êàðòàõ èçîáðàæåíû ôðàãìåíòû ìèðà. Ïîëó÷èòü èõ ìîæíî â äðóæåñòâåííûõ äåðåâíÿõ èëè îò äðóãèõ äåðæàâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Êàðòû èç äåðåâåíü[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ââåäÿ þíèò â òóçåìíóþ äåðåâíþ, ìîæíî ïîëó÷èòü â äàð êàðòó îêðåñòíîñòåé. Èçîáðàæåííàÿ íà íåé òåððèòîðèÿ äîáàâëÿåòñÿ íà âàøó îñíîâíóþ êàðòó êàê "îòêðûòàÿ" (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Èññëåäîâàíèå òåððèòîðèè[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îáìåí êàðòàìè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Òåõíîëîãèÿ [LINK=TECH_PAPER]Áóìàãà[\LINK] äàåò âîçìîæíîñòü îáìåíèâàòüñÿ êàðòàìè ñ äðóãèìè äåðæàâàìè. Ñ ïðèîáðåòåíèåì êàðòû âñÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]îòêðûòàÿ[\LINK] äàííîé äåðæàâå òåððèòîðèÿ äîáàâëÿåòñÿ íà âàøó îñíîâíóþ êàðòó. Òàê æå è âû îòäàåòå âìåñòå ñ êàðòîé ðåçóëüòàòû ñâîèõ èññëåäîâàíèé.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Maps[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are three different kinds of maps in Civilization IV: the main map, the mini map, and game maps. The main map and the mini map are sections of Civ IV's interface; see the manual for details on them. This entry deals specifically with game maps.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Game Maps[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Game maps are maps of portions of the world. You can acquire game maps from friendly villagers, or from other civilizations.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Maps from Villagers[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When one of your units enters a village, the villagers may respond by giving you a map of local territory. When they do so, your main map is updated to display the newly-revealed territory. This territory is "explored" (see [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploration[\LINK] for more details).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Trading Maps[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=TECH_PAPER]Paper[\LINK] technology allows you to trade maps with other civilizations. When a civilization trades you a map, all of the territory that civilization has [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]"Explored"[\LINK] is updated on your main map. When you trade another civilization your map, that civilization learns about all of the territory that you have explored.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Äâèæåíèå[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Çíà÷èòåëüíàÿ ÷àñòü èãðû ñîñòîèò â òîì, ÷òîáû ïåðåìåùàòü [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]þíèòû[\LINK] ïî êàðòå: îòïðàâëÿòü èõ [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]èññëåäîâàòü[\LINK] íîâûå òåððèòîðèè, âîåâàòü è òàê äàëåå. Â ñâîåé îñíîâå ìåõàíèçì äâèæåíèÿ ïðîñò: ó êàæäîãî þíèòà åñòü îïðåäåëåííîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö äâèæåíèÿ, êîòîðûå îí ìîæåò ïîòðàòèòü çà õîä. Åäèíèöû òðàòÿòñÿ, êîãäà þíèò âõîäèò íà íîâóþ êëåòêó; íåêîòîðûå ëàíäøàôòû ïðîõîäèìû ëåã÷å, äðóãèå - òðóäíåå (è çàáèðàþò áîëüøå åäèíèö), à íåêîòîðûå íåïðîõîäèìû âîîáùå. Åñòü [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]îáúåêòû[\LINK], êîòîðûå ïîçâîëÿþò, âõîäÿ íà êëåòêó, òðàòèòü ìåíüøå åäèíèö äâèæåíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèòû äåëÿòñÿ íà òðè áîëüøèõ êëàññà: ñóõîïóòíûå, âîäíûå è àâèàöèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äâèæåíèå ïî ñóøå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñóõîïóòíûå þíèòû ïåðåìåùàþòñÿ òîëüêî ïî ñóõîïóòíûì [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]ëàíäøàôòàì[\LINK]. Îíè íå ìîãóò äâèãàòüñÿ ïî âîäå (åñëè èõ íå [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]ïåðåâîçèò[\LINK] ñïåöèàëüíûé þíèò: âîäíûé òðàíñïîðò). Íåäîñòóïíû äëÿ íèõ òàêæå [LINK=TERRAIN_PEAK]ãîðíûå âåðøèíû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñêîðîñòü[\BOLD]. Ó ïåøèõ þíèòîâ îáû÷íî îäíà åäèíèöà äâèæåíèÿ, ó êîííûõ è ìîòîðèçîâàííûõ äâå. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Þíèòû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ëàíäøàôòû[\BOLD]. Âõîäÿ íà îòêðûòóþ ìåñòíîñòü - ëóãà, ðàâíèíû, ïóñòûíþ, òóíäðó èëè ëåäíèêè - þíèò òðàòèò îäíó åäèíèöó äâèæåíèÿ. Â õîëìàõ, äæóíãëÿõ è ëåñàõ ðàñõîäóþòñÿ äâå åäèíèöû.[PARAGRAPH:2]Âàæíîå óòî÷íåíèå: þíèò, ó êîòîðîãî åñòü õîòü îäíà åäèíèöà äâèæåíèÿ, âñåãäà ñìîæåò ïîïàñòü íà êëåòêó (íàïðèìåð, ñ îäíîé åäèíèöåé âîéòè â ëåñ), íî íå ñìîæåò äâèãàòüñÿ äàëüøå. (Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Ëàíäøàôò[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äîðîãè îáû÷íûå è æåëåçíûå[\BOLD]. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Äîðîãè[\LINK] óðàâíèâàþò âñå ëàíäøàôòû; ëþáàÿ êëåòêà îáõîäèòñÿ â ïîë-åäèíèöû äâèæåíèÿ (à ñ îñâîåíèåì [LINK=TECH_ENGINEERING]èíæåíåðíîãî äåëà[\LINK] öåíà ïàäàåò äî îäíîé òðåòè åäèíèöû). Ýòî ïîëîæèòåëüíîå äåéñòâèå ïðîÿâëÿåòñÿ òîëüêî ïîêà þíèò íå ñõîäèò ñ äîðîãè; íå ïîìîãàþò äîðîãè ïåðåäâèãàòüñÿ è â ïðåäåëàõ [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]ãðàíèö[\LINK] âðàæäåáíîãî ãîðîäà. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Æåëåçíûå äîðîãè[\LINK] äåéñòâóþò êàê îáû÷íûå, òîëüêî ïåðåõîä ñ îäíîé æåëåçíîäîðîæíîé êëåòêè íà äðóãóþ ñòîèò âñåãî îäíó äåñÿòóþ åäèíèöû äâèæåíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðåêè[\BOLD]. Ïåðåñåêàÿ ðåêè, äîðîãè òåðÿþò ñâîè ïðåèìóùåñòâà, ïîêà íå îñâîåíî [LINK=TECH_CONSTRUCTION]êîíñòðóèðîâàíèå[\LINK]; èíà÷å ãîâîðÿ, ïåðåïðàâà ÷åðåç ðåêó ïðîèñõîäèò êàê åñëè áû äîðîãè íå áûëî.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãîðîäà[\BOLD]. Êëåòêè ãîðîäîâ ôóíêöèîíèðóþò êàê äîðîãè, à ñ ïîÿâëåíèåì æåëåçíûõ äîðîã - êàê æåëåçíûå äîðîãè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äâèæåíèå ïî âîäå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âîäíûå þíèòû ìîãóò íàõîäèòüñÿ òîëüêî íà ìîðñêèõ, ïðèáðåæíûõ è ïîðòîâûõ êëåòêàõ. Îíè íå ìîãóò ïåðåäâèãàòüñÿ ïî ñóøå è ëåäíèêàì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]×åãî íå ìîãóò âîäíûå þíèòû[\BOLD]. Äëÿ ðàííèõ âîäíûõ þíèòîâ - ãàëåð è ïðîìûøëåííûõ ñóäîâ - íåäîñòóïíî ìîðå çà ïðåäåëàìè âëàäåíèé èõ äåðæàâû (èëè äðóãîé äåðæàâû, ñ êîòîðîé åñòü ñîãëàøåíèå îá [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ[\LINK]). Âíóòðè ãðàíèö îíè äâèæóòñÿ ïî ïðèáðåæíûì è ïîðòîâûì êëåòêàì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñêîðîñòü[\BOLD]. Ðàííèå âîäíûå þíèòû èìåþò ïî äâå åäèíèöû äâèæåíèÿ, íàèáîëåå áûñòðûå è ñîâðåìåííûå - äî âîñüìè. Òàêæå äåðæàâà, ïåðâîé îáîãíóâøàÿ çåìíîé øàð, ïîëó÷àåò íàäáàâêó â îäíó åäèíèöó äâèæåíèÿ äëÿ âñåõ ñâîèõ âîäíûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ëàíäøàôòû[\BOLD]. Âñå ïîãðàíè÷íûå è ìîðñêèå êëåòêè îáõîäÿòñÿ â îäíó åäèíèöó äâèæåíèÿ. Ëåäíèêè íåïðîõîäèìû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Àâèàöèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Àâèàöèè äîñòóïíû è ìîðå, è ñóøà, çà èñêëþ÷åíèåì íåïðîõîäèìûõ ëåäíèêîâ è ãîðíûõ âåðøèí. Êàæäàÿ êëåòêà îáõîäèòñÿ ýòèì þíèòàì â îäíó åäèíèöó äâèæåíèÿ. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Àâèàöèÿ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êâàëèôèêàöèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]êâàëèôèêàöèè[\LINK] äàþò þíèòàì ïðèáàâêó ê ñêîðîñòè - ïîñòîÿííóþ èëè íà îïðåäåëåííîì ëàíäøàôòå. Òàê, "Ìàíåâðåííîñòü" óñêîðÿåò äâèæåíèå êîííûõ è áðîíèðîâàííûõ þíèòîâ íà ïåðåñå÷åííîé ìåñòíîñòè, à "Íàâèãàöèÿ" äàåò âîäíûì þíèòàì äîïîëíèòåëüíûå åäèíèöû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äâèæåíèå è ãðàíèöû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèòû ìîãóò ñâîáîäíî ïåðåìåùàòüñÿ ïî ñâîåé è íåéòðàëüíîé òåððèòîðèè, à òàêæå ïî âëàäåíèÿì äåðæàâû, ñ êîòîðîé åñòü ñîãëàøåíèå îá [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ[\LINK]. Íàðóøèòü ãðàíèöû ãîñóäàðñòâà, ñ êîòîðûì òàêîãî ñîãëàøåíèÿ íåò, çíà÷èò îáúÿâèòü åìó âîéíó. Íà âðàæåñêîé çåìëå äîðîãè, â òîì ÷èñëå è æåëåçíûå, íå îáëåã÷àþò äâèæåíèå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äâèæåíèå è äðóãèå þíèòû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Äðóæåñòâåííûå è íåéòðàëüíûå þíèòû íèêàê íå âëèÿþò íà äâèæåíèå: ìîæíî çàéòè íà èõ êëåòêó, è ýòî íå áóäåò íàïàäåíèåì. Íî çàéòè íà êëåòêó, ãäå íàõîäèòñÿ þíèò ïðîòèâíèêà - çíà÷èò íà÷àòü ñ íèì [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]áîé[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê óïðàâëÿòü þíèòàìè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðåìåùàòü þíèòû ìîæíî ñ ïîìîùüþ ìûøè èëè êëàâèàòóðû. Âûäåëÿòü þíèòû è óêàçûâàòü èì, êóäà äâèãàòüñÿ, âàñ íàó÷èò îáó÷àþùàÿ èãðà.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Movement[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, much of your time is spent moving your [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Units[\LINK] around on the map - you send them out to [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Explore[\LINK] new territory; you march them off to battle; and so forth. The basic rules of movement are simple; each unit in the game has a certain number of "movement points" (MPs) which they can expend each turn. Units spend MPs entering a new square; some terrain is more difficult to move through (and thus costs more MPs to enter), some less so, and some is impassable. Certain [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvements[\LINK] cut down the cost of entering certain spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are three basic unit types in the game: land, sea, and air units.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Land Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Land units may move only onto land [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Terrain[\LINK]. They may not move onto water (unless [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]carried[\LINK] aboard a sea transport unit). Further, land units may not enter [LINK=TERRAIN_PEAK]Peak[\LINK] spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Movement Speed:[\BOLD] Generally, foot soldiers have 1 MP, while horses and powered units have 2 MPs or more. Workers and settlers have 2 MPs. See [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Units[\LINK] for details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Terrain Costs:[\BOLD] Open terrain - grassland, plains, desert, tundra and ice - cost 1 MP to enter. Hills, jungle, and forests cost 2 MP.[PARAGRAPH:2] Note: A unit can always enter a space if it has any MPs left. Thus, a 1 MP unit could enter a forest space, but its move would end there. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Terrain[\LINK] for details.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Roads and Railroads:[\BOLD] [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Roads[\LINK] negate the movement costs of terrain; all spaces cost 1/2 MP to enter. (When you acquire the [LINK=TECH_ENGINEERING]Engineering[\LINK] technology, the cost goes down to 1/3 MP.) This benefit occurs only when a unit is moving from one road square to another, and only when the square the unit is entering is not within a hostile civ's [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK]. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Railroads[\LINK] are similar to roads, except that railroad squares cost 1/10 MP to enter from other railroad squares.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Rivers:[\BOLD] Rivers negate the effects of roads until you get the [LINK=TECH_CONSTRUCTION]Construction[\LINK] technology; in other words, moving across a river will act the same as if a road is not there at all.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cities[\BOLD] All city spaces are considered to have roads in them. When you have acquired the ability to build railroads, city spaces will have railroads as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Water Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Water units can enter only ocean, coastal, and coastal city squares. They cannot move onto land spaces. Water units cannot enter ice spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Sea Unit Type Limitations:[\BOLD] Early water units - galleys and work boats - cannot enter ocean squares unless those squares are within your cultural borders (or another civilizations's cultural borders if you have an [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]"Open Borders"[\LINK] agreement). Otherwise they are limited to coastal and city spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Movement Speed:[\BOLD] Early water units have 2 MPs; the fastest and most modern water units have as many as 8 MPs. The first civilization to circumnavigate the globe will also receive a +1 MP bonus to all of its water units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Terrain Costs:[\BOLD] All coastal/ocean spaces cost 1 MP to enter. Ice spaces are impassable.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Air Units[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In general, air units can enter both land and water spaces, including impassable ice and peak spaces. All spaces cost 1 MP for air units to enter. See [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Air Units[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Promotions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Certain [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Promotions[\LINK] allow units to move faster through certain terrain types or grant them extra MPs altogether. For example, the Mobility promotion allows mounted and armored units to move faster through rough terrain and the Navigation promotions grant water units extra MPs.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Borders on Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Your units can move freely within your territory and unclaimed territory, as well as through territory of civilizations with whom you have an [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Open Borders[\LINK] treaty. If you enter territory of a civilization without such a treaty, you declare war on that civ. You do not get the benefits of roads or rails when moving into enemy territory.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Other Units on Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Other friendly or neutral units do not affect your units' movement at all; in other words, your units can move onto the same space as a foreign unit without attacking it. However, if your unit enters a space containing an enemy unit, your unit will initiate [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat[\LINK] with the enemy.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Controlling Your Units[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can use your mouse or keyboard to move your units. See the game controls section of the manual to learn how to "activate" units and tell them where you want them to go.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]ßäåðíîå îðóæèå[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]ßäåðíûå ðàêåòû, îíè æå "[LINK=UNIT_ICBM]ÌÁÐ[\LINK]" (ìåæêîíòèíåíòàëüíûå áàëëèñòè÷åñêèå ðàêåòû) - ñòðàøíûé ñîí ëþáîãî ëèäåðà. Â èãðå íåò îðóæèÿ ìîùíåå, è åñëè ïðèìåíèòü èõ, ìàëî íå ïîêàæåòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Èñòî÷íèêè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû ñîçäàòü ÿäåðíîå îðóæèå, òðåáóåòñÿ: [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïðîåêò "Ìàíõýòòåí"[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ó êîãî-íèáóäü, íå îáÿçàòåëüíî ó âàñ, äîëæåí èìåòüñÿ [LINK=PROJECT_MANHATTAN_PROJECT]ïðîåêò "Ìàíõýòòåí"[\LINK]. Îäíàæäû ïîÿâèâøèñü, ýòî ÷óäî ñâåòà ïîçâîëÿåò âñåì äåðæàâàì, ïðè âûïîëíåíèè ïðî÷èõ óñëîâèé, èçãîòîâëÿòü ðàêåòû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàêåòîñòðîåíèå è ðàñùåïëåíèå àòîìà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåîáõîäèìî îñâîèòü òåõíîëîãèè [LINK=TECH_ROCKETRY]ðàêåòîñòðîåíèÿ[\LINK] è [LINK=TECH_FISSION]ðàñùåïëåíèÿ àòîìà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Óðàí[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðåñóðñ, íåîáõîäèìûé äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ ðàêåò - [LINK=BONUS_URANIUM]óðàí[\LINK]. Îí ñòàíîâèòñÿ äîñòóïåí ïîñëå îñâîåíèÿ [LINK=TECH_PHYSICS]ôèçèêè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Èçãîòîâëåíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðàêåòû ñîçäàþòñÿ â ãîðîäàõ, êàê îáû÷íûå þíèòû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Çàïóñê[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Äàëüíîñòü ïîëåòà ðàêåò íå îãðàíè÷åíà: îíè ìîãóò ïîðàçèòü ëþáóþ [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]èçâåñòíóþ[\LINK] êëåòêó íà êàðòå. Ðàêåòà ïîïàäàåò â öåëü è âçðûâàåòñÿ íåìåäëåííî ïîñëå çàïóñêà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îáëàñòü ïîðàæåíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]ßäåðíûå ðàêåòû áüþò ïî ïëîùàäè: îíè ïîðàæàþò íå òîëüêî êëåòêó, ãäå âçîðâàëèñü, íî è âîñåìü ïðèëåãàþùèõ êëåòîê, ïðè÷åì ýòèì âîñüìè ïðèõîäèòñÿ íè÷óòü íå ëåã÷å.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Óùåðá[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîñòðîéêè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ðàêåòà ïîïàäàåò â ãîðîä èëè ïðèëåãàþùóþ ê íåìó êëåòêó, êîìïüþòåð ïðîâåðÿåò ïðî÷íîñòü êàæäîãî çäàíèÿ è îïðåäåëÿåò, âûñòîÿëî îíî áåç ïîâðåæäåíèé èëè ïîëíîñòüþ ðàçðóøèëîñü (òàêæå ñì. äàëåå î áîìáîóáåæèùàõ). ×óäåñà ñâåòà ðàêåò íå áîÿòñÿ![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Þíèòû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ þíèòîâ òîæå ïðîâåðÿåòñÿ ïðî÷íîñòü; ðåçóëüòàò ìîæåò áûòü îäèí èç òðåõ: þíèò óíè÷òîæåí, ïîâðåæäåí èëè óöåëåë ïîëíîñòüþ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îáúåêòû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ðàêåòà ïîïàäàåò â îáúåêò èëè ðÿäîì, äëÿ îáúåêòà òàêæå ïðîâåðÿåòñÿ ïðî÷íîñòü. Íèêîãäà íå ïîâðåæäàþòñÿ òîëüêî äîðîãè, îáû÷íûå è æåëåçíûå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàäèàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîñëå ÿäåðíîãî âçðûâà â ëþáîé èç ïîðàæåííûõ êëåòîê ìîæåò âîçíèêíóòü ðàäèîàêòèâíîå çàðàæåíèå. Ðàäèàöèÿ äåëàåò êëåòêó ïîëíîñòüþ íåïðèãîäíîé: ãîðîä íå ìîæåò ïîëó÷àòü ñ íåå ïèùó, äåíüãè, ïðîäóêöèþ èëè ðåñóðñû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Áîðüáà ñ ðàäèàöèåé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè îñâîåíà [LINK=TECH_ECOLOGY]ýêîëîãèÿ[\LINK], ðàáîòíèêè ìîãóò ðàñ÷èñòèòü çîíó ïîâûøåííîé ðàäèàöèè. ×òîáû ïðîöåññ øåë áûñòðåå, íàïðàâüòå íà íåãî íåñêîëüêèõ ðàáîòíèêîâ. Ðàñ÷èñòêó óñêîðÿþò òàêæå íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà ñâåòà[\LINK] è ïðî÷åå. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàêåòû è ÑÎÈ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðîåêò [LINK=PROJECT_SDI]ÑÎÈ[\LINK] íåïëîõî çàùèùàåò îò ðàêåò, ïóùåííûõ ïî âàøåé òåððèòîðèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàêåòû è áîìáîóáåæèùà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Áîìáîóáåæèùå â ïðåäåëàõ ãîðîäà ñíèæàåò óùåðá íà 75%.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèå ïîñëåäñòâèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Èñïîëüçîâàíèå ðàêåò âëå÷åò ñåðüåçíûå äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèå ïîñëåäñòâèÿ. Îòíîøåíèÿ ñ äðóãèìè äåðæàâàìè ïî÷òè íàâåðíÿêà ðåçêî èñïîðòÿòñÿ, è âû ðèñêóåòå ïðåâðàòèòüñÿ â ìèøåíü äëÿ ÷óæîãî ÿäåðíîãî óäàðà. Òàê ÷òî íå ñïåøèòå æàòü íà êíîïêó![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ãëîáàëüíîå ïîòåïëåíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñ ïåðâûì âçðûâîì ðàêåòû íà÷èíàåòñÿ ãëîáàëüíîå ïîòåïëåíèå; íåêîãäà ïëîäîðîäíûå êëåòêè ïîíåìíîãó ïðåâðàùàþòñÿ â áåñïîëåçíóþ ïóñòûíþ. Åñëè ÿäåðíàÿ âîéíà çàòÿíåòñÿ, íåïðèãîäíûì äëÿ æèçíè ñòàíåò âåñü ìèð.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Nukes[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]"Nukes," also known as "[LINK=UNIT_ICBM]ICBMs[\LINK]" (intercontinental ballistic missiles), can ruin a leader's whole day. These are the ultimate weapons available in Civilization IV, and they are extremely potent.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Acquiring Nukes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]To build nuclear weapons, you need the following: [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The Manhattan Project Wonder[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Someone in the game must have built the [LINK=PROJECT_MANHATTAN_PROJECT]Manhattan Project[\LINK] wonder. It needn't be you; once anybody has built the Manhattan Project, everyone can build nukes (if they meet the other requirements).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Rocketry and Fission[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You need to know the [LINK=TECH_ROCKETRY]Rocketry[\LINK] and [LINK=TECH_FISSION]Fission[\LINK] technologies before you can construct nukes.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Uranium[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You need access to the [LINK=BONUS_URANIUM]Uranium[\LINK] resource to build nukes. Uranium is uncovered by the [LINK=TECH_PHYSICS]Physics[\LINK] tech.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Constructing Nukes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You build nukes in a city, just like any other unit.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Launching a Nuke[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Nukes have unlimited range: they can reach any [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Explored[\LINK] space on the map. Once launched, nukes reach their target space and detonate immediately.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Area of Effect[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Nukes are "area of effect" weapons; when detonated they cause damage in their target square, but they also cause damage to the eight squares that are adjacent to the target square. In fact, the eight adjacent squares get hit just as hard as the target square.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Damage Effects[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Buildings[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If a nuke detonates in or adjacent to a city, the computer makes a "kill check" against each building; if the building passes the check, it emerges unharmed. If the target building fails, it is destroyed (but see "bomb shelters," below). Wonders cannot be destroyed by nukes![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The computer makes a "kill check" against each unit; if the unit fails, the check it is destroyed. If the unit passes the check, it may emerge damaged or unscathed. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Improvements[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If a nuke detonates on top of or adjacent to an improvement, that improvement too must go through a "kill check." (Exception: nukes never damage roads or rails.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Fallout[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A nuclear detonation may produce "fallout" - radioactive debris - in any of the target squares. Fallout makes the space totally unworkable; in other words, a nearby city cannot draw food, commerce, production, or resources from a square damaged by fallout.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Scrubbing Fallout[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Once you have discovered the [LINK=TECH_ECOLOGY]Ecology[\LINK] technology, your workers can "scrub" (or clean) fallout. Scrubbing fallout is like any other worker action; multiple workers can scrub a space simultaneously to speed the job up; certain [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] may cause workers to scrub fallout faster, and so forth. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]SDI and Nukes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=PROJECT_SDI]SDI[\LINK] project has an excellent chance of intercepting any nukes targeted at your territory.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Bomb Shelters and Nukes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] A bomb shelter in a city reduces damage by 75%%.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Diplomatic Penalties[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]There are serious diplomatic penalties attached to using nukes. Relations with other civilizations are almost certain to drop precipitously, and you may find yourself at the recieving end of someone else's nuclear arsenal. You have been warned![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Global Warming[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Use of nuclear weapons will cause Global Warming to begin, turning previously fertile tiles into useless desert. Prolonged nuclear exchanges will transform the world into an uninhabitable wasteland.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ïðîèçâîäñòâî[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Óðîâåíü ïðîèçâîäñòâà äëÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäà[\LINK] - òî åñòü ñêîðîñòü, ñ êîòîðîé îí ñîçäàåò çäàíèÿ è þíèòû, - çàâèñèò îò îêðóæàþùåãî [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]ëàíäøàôòà[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñîâ[\LINK]. Êàæäûé ðåñóðñ è òèï ëàíäøàôòà äàåò îïðåäåëåííîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö ïðîäóêöèè (îíè æå "ìîëîòêè", îíè æå, äëÿ çíàòîêîâ ñåðèè Civilization, "ùèòû"). Õîëìû è ðàâíèíû ïðîèçâîäÿò îäíó åäèíèöó çà õîä, ëåñà - äâå, ëóãà - íè îäíîé. Õîçÿéñòâåííóþ öåííîñòü êëåòêè ìîæíî ïîâûñèòü çà ñ÷åò [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]îáúåêòîâ[\LINK]. Òàê, ðóäíèê ïîâûøàåò öåííîñòü õîëìà äî òðåõ åäèíèö çà õîä.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñìåíà ïðîäóêöèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â îòëè÷èå îò ïðåäûäóùèõ èãð ñåðèè Civilization, ïðîèçâîäñòâî êàæäîãî þíèòà èëè çäàíèÿ, ñîçäàâàåìûõ â ãîðîäå, ó÷èòûâàåòñÿ îòäåëüíî. Åñëè ãîðîä ñòðîèë [LINK=BUILDING_GRANARY]àìáàð[\LINK], à ïîòîì äëÿ ñàìîîáîðîíû ðåøèë ïðèíÿòüñÿ çà [LINK=UNIT_ARCHER]ëó÷íèêà[\LINK], ëó÷íèêà ïðèäåòñÿ ñîçäàâàòü ñ íóëÿ: óðîâåíü ïðîèçâîäñòâà íå áóäåò ïåðåíåñåí ñ àìáàðà. Çàâåðøèâ ëó÷íèêà, ãîðîä ìîæåò âåðíóòüñÿ ê àìáàðó è äîâåñòè ðàáîòó äî êîíöà ñ òîãî ýòàïà, íà êîòîðîì îíà ïðåðâàëàñü.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ó÷òèòå: íåëüçÿ ñëèøêîì íàäîëãî îòêëàäûâàòü íåçàâåðøåííîå ïðîèçâîäñòâî, çà âðåìÿ ïðîñòîÿ ñ íåãî áóäóò ñíèìàòüñÿ î÷êè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Óñêîðåíèå ïðîèçâîäñòâà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Î òîì, êàê ïîâûñèòü â ãîðîäå ñêîðîñòü ïðîèçâîäñòâà, ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_HURRY_PRODUCTION]Óñêîðåíèå ïðîèçâîäñòâà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Production[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City's[\LINK] basic "productivity" - that is, the speed at which it constructs buildings and units - is determined by the [LINK=CONCEPT_TERRAIN]Terrain[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK] surrounding the city. Each terrain type and resource provides a certain amount of "production points" (a.k.a., "hammers" or also - to longtime Civilization fans - as "shields"). Hills and plains produce one production each turn, forests produce two, and grassland produces none. Various [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvements[\LINK] can increase a square's productivity. Mines, for instance, increase a hill's productivity to three per turn.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Changing Production[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Unlike previous Civilization games, production is saved separately for each item that a city chooses to build. If a city is building a [LINK=BUILDING_GRANARY]Granary[\LINK] and changes over to an [LINK=UNIT_ARCHER]Archer[\LINK] unit for defense, it must start production of the archer from the beginning; production does not "carry over" from the granary. After finishing the archer, the city could then go back to the granary and pick up where it left off before.[PARAGRAPH:2]Caution: If you wait too long to go back to a partially completed item, there will be a "decay" of production over time.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Hurrying Production[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]See [LINK=CONCEPT_HURRY_PRODUCTION]Hurry Production[\LINK] to learn how to speed up a city's production.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Êâàëèôèêàöèè[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàæäûé çíàåò, ÷òî ñòàðûé ñîëäàò â áîþ ñòîèò äâóõ íîâîáðàíöåâ: îí ëó÷øå óìååò æèòü è íå äàâàòü æèòü äðóãèì. Þíèòû â èãðå Civilization IV ñ îïûòîì ïîëó÷àþò êâàëèôèêàöèè, à ñ íèìè - ïðèáàâêè ê çàùèòå, íàïàäåíèþ, âîññòàíîâëåíèþ, äâèæåíèþ è ïðî÷èì âîåííûì íàâûêàì.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Åäèíèöû îïûòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Þíèò[\LINK] ïîëó÷àåò êâàëèôèêàöèþ, íàáðàâ îïðåäåëåííîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö îïûòà; â íèõ âûðàæàåòñÿ åãî ïîäãîòîâêà è ó÷àñòèå â áîåâûõ äåéñòâèÿõ. Îïûò íàáèðàþò òîëüêî ñóõîïóòíûå è ìîðñêèå þíèòû, íî íå àâèàöèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîäãîòîâêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ê ïîäãîòîâêå îòíîñèòñÿ íåñêîëüêî èñòî÷íèêîâ îïûòà. ×åòûðå åäèíèöû îïûòà àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ïîëó÷àåò þíèò, ñîçäàííûé â ãîðîäå, ãäå åñòü [LINK=BUILDING_BARRACKS]êàçàðìû[\LINK]. Äëÿ ìîðñêèõ þíèòîâ òàêîé æå ýôôåêò äàåò [LINK=BUILDING_DRYDOCK]ñóõîé äîê[\LINK]. Åñòü è äðóãèå [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]çäàíèÿ[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà ñâåòà[\LINK] ñ ïîäîáíûì äåéñòâèåì. Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_VASSALAGE]Âàññàëüíàÿ çàâèñèìîñòü[\LINK] äàåò ïî äâå åäèíèöû êàæäîìó íîâîìó þíèòó, ñòîëüêî æå äàåò [LINK=CIVIC_THEOCRACY]Òåîêðàòèÿ[\LINK] þíèòàì èç ãîðîäîâ ñ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèåé. Êðîìå òîãî, ïðèáàâêè áûâàþò ïðè íåêîòîðûõ [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]÷åðòàõ õàðàêòåðà[\LINK] ëèäåðà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Áîåâîé îïûò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Áîåâîé îïûò þíèòû ïîëó÷àþò, óíè÷òîæàÿ â ñðàæåíèè âðàæåñêèå þíèòû. Íå âàæíî, áûëà ýòî çàùèòà èëè íàïàäåíèå: ïîáåäèë âðàãà - ïîëó÷è åäèíèöó îïûòà. Ó÷òèòå, ÷òî åäèíèö íå äàåòñÿ çà [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]áîìáàðäèðîâêó[\LINK] óêðåïëåíèé, à òàêæå åñëè ïðîòèâíèê (èëè ñàì þíèò!) [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]îòñòóïèë[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê ïîëó÷èòü êâàëèôèêàöèþ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êâàëèôèêàöèè äàþòñÿ ïî ñêîëüçÿùåé øêàëå îïûòà. Ïåðâóþ êâàëèôèêàöèþ þíèò ïîëó÷àåò, íàáðàâ äâå åäèíèöû, âòîðóþ - åùå òðè (òî åñòü, èìåÿ â ñóììå ïÿòü), òðåòüþ - åùå çà ïÿòü (â ñóììå äåñÿòü) è òàê äàëåå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âûáîð êâàëèôèêàöèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êâàëèôèêàöèè çàâèñÿò îò òèïà þíèòà, à íåêîòîðûå äàþòñÿ òîëüêî ïðè íàëè÷èè äðóãèõ. Êîãäà þíèò íàêàïëèâàåò äîñòàòî÷íî îïûòà, âñå êâàëèôèêàöèè, íà êîòîðûå îí ìîæåò ïðåòåíäîâàòü, îòîáðàæàþòñÿ íà åãî ïàíåëè äåéñòâèé.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñïèñîê êâàëèôèêàöèé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â [LINK=PEDIA_MAIN_PROMOTION]ñïèñêå êâàëèôèêàöèé[\LINK] ïåðå÷èñëåíû âñå êâàëèôèêàöèè, êàêèå åñòü â èãðå. Ùåëêíèòå êâàëèôèêàöèþ, ÷òîáû óçíàòü, äëÿ êàêèõ þíèòîâ îíà äîñòóïíà, ïðè êàêèõ óñëîâèÿõ ïðèîáðåòàåòñÿ è ÷òî äàåò.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Promotions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]It's well known that in war battle-tested veterans are more successful than green troops. They are better at staying alive, and better at seeing that the enemy doesn't stay alive. In Civilization IV, experienced troops earn "promotions" which give them special bonuses on offense, defense, healing, movement, and other martial-related skills.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Experience Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Units[\LINK] gain promotions by acquiring "experience points" (or XPs) representing their training and practical battlefield experience. Only land and naval units get experience points; air units do not.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Training Experience Points[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Training XPs come from several sources. A land unit built in a city with a [LINK=BUILDING_BARRACKS]Barracks[\LINK] automatically receives 4 XPs. [LINK=BUILDING_DRYDOCK]Drydocks[\LINK] do the same for naval units. Various other [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] provide training XPs too. The civic [LINK=CIVIC_VASSALAGE]Vassalage[\LINK] gives all new units 2 XPs, and the [LINK=CIVIC_THEOCRACY]Theocracy[\LINK] civic also grants 2 XPs for units built in cities with your state religion. Finally, certain civilization [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Leader Traits[\LINK] give bonuses also.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Combat Experience Points[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Units gain combat experience points by destroying an enemy unit in battle. It doesn't matter if the unit attacked or defended; as long as its enemy is destroyed, it gets an XP. Units DO NOT gain XPs for [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Bombarding[\LINK] fortifications, nor do they get them if the enemy unit [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Withdraws[\LINK] from combat (or if they themselves withdraw!).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Getting Promotions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Promotions occur on a sliding scale of experience points. A unit gets its first promotion upon achieving 2 XPs. The second promotion requires 3 additional XPs (for a total of 5), the third 4 more XP (10 total), etc.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Promotion Choice[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Not all promotions are available to all units, and some promotions require that a unit have already gotten a specific previous promotion. When the unit is due for a promotion, the available promotions are displayed in the unit's "action box."[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Promotions List[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Look at the [LINK=PEDIA_MAIN_PROMOTION]Promotions List[\LINK] page to see all the promotions available in the game. Click on a promotion to discover which units can get it, its requirements, and its effects.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ðåëèãèÿ[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðåëèãèÿ âñåãäà èãðàëà êëþ÷åâóþ ðîëü â èñòîðèè. ×åðåç íåå ÷åëîâåê ïîñòèãàë ñâîå ìåñòî â ìèðå è ñìûñë æèçíè, ñòðåìèëñÿ ê âîçâûøåííîìó, ñòàíîâèëñÿ ìóäðåå; âî èìÿ âåðû ïîñòðîåíû ïðåêðàñíûå ñîîðóæåíèÿ, íàïèñàíû âåëèêèå êíèãè è ïðåêðàñíàÿ ìóçûêà. Âî èìÿ òîé æå âåðû ëþäè óáèâàëè è ïîðàáîùàëè äðóã äðóãà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðåëèãèÿ â èãðå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìû çíàåì, ÷òî ðåëèãèÿ - îïàñíàÿ òåìà; èç-çà íåñîãëàñèé íà åå ñ÷åò íà÷àëîñü íåìàëî âîéí. Êîìïàíèÿ Firaxis íå õî÷åò íèêîãî îáèäåòü, íî, ó÷èòûâàÿ âàæíóþ ðîëü ðåëèãèé â ðàçâèòèè öèâèëèçàöèè, ìû ðåøèëè íå âûáðàñûâàòü èõ èç èãðû, à ïîñòàðàëèñü ïîäîéòè ê íèì ìàêñèìàëüíî óâàæèòåëüíî, ÷åñòíî è áåç ëèöåìåðèÿ. Â èãðå îíè âñå äàþò îäèíàêîâûé ýôôåêò è ðàçëè÷àþòñÿ ëèøü èñõîäíûìè òðåáîâàíèÿìè.[PARAGRAPH:2]Â èãðå ñåìü ðåëèãèé (èìåííî ýòî êîëè÷åñòâî îêàçàëîñü óäîáíûì äëÿ èãðîâîãî ïðîöåññà); ìû îòîáðàëè òå, êîòîðûå ñî÷ëè ñàìûìè èçâåñòíûìè, íå èìåÿ â âèäó, ÷òî îíè âàæíåå, ëó÷øå èëè õóæå äðóãèõ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ìû âîçäåðæèâàåìñÿ îò îöåíîê è óâàæàåì âåðó êàæäîãî. Íàøå äåëî - èãðû, à íå áîãîñëîâèå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê îñíîâàòü ðåëèãèþ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðåëèãèþ îñíîâûâàåò â îäíîì èç ñâîèõ ãîðîäîâ äåðæàâà, êîòîðàÿ ïåðâîé îñâîèëà íåîáõîäèìóþ òåõíîëîãèþ. Èìåòü òàêîé ãîðîä î÷åíü ïîëåçíî; ïðîðîê ìîæåò ñîçäàòü òàì ñâÿòèëèùå (ñì. íèæå).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ãîñóäàðñòâåííûå ðåëèãèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êîãäà ñðåäè âàøèõ ïîääàííûõ ïîëó÷àåò ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèå îäíà èëè íåñêîëüêî ðåëèãèé, îäíó èç íèõ ìîæíî ñäåëàòü ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé. Â ãîðîäàõ, ãäå îíà ïðèíÿòà, ïîâûøàåòñÿ íàñòðîåíèå è ïðîèçâîäñòâî. Êðîìå òîãî, óñèëèâàåòñÿ ýôôåêò îò ìíîãèõ ðåëèãèîçíûõ ïîñòðîåê è ïàðàäèãì.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðåëèãèè çàèìñòâóþòñÿ èç îäíîãî ãîðîäà â äðóãîé ñëó÷àéíûì îáðàçîì - ÷àùå â ñîñåäíèå ãîðîäà è â òå, êîòîðûå ñâÿçàíû òîðãîâûìè ïóòÿìè. Ýòîò ïðîöåññ óñêîðÿþò íåêîòîðûå çäàíèÿ (ñì. íèæå); íà íåãî òàêæå ñóùåñòâåííî âëèÿåò ðåëèãèîçíàÿ ïàðàäèãìà äåðæàâû (ñì. íèæå). Ðåãóëèðîâàòü ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèå ðåëèãèé ïîçâîëÿþò [LINK=UNIT_BUDDHIST_MISSIONARY]ìèññèîíåðû[\LINK], ñì. ñëåäóþùèé ðàçäåë.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ìèññèîíåðû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèÿ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèè ìîæíî ñîçäàâàòü þíèòû îñîáîãî òèïà: ýòî ìèññèîíåðû. Èõ êîëè÷åñòâî îãðàíè÷åíî, êàæäûé îáõîäèòñÿ çà õîä â äâå åäèíèöû çîëîòà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñîçäàíèå ìèññèîíåðîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Äåðæàâû ñ ïàðàäèãìîé [LINK=CIVIC_ORGANIZED_RELIGION]Îðãàíèçîâàííàÿ ðåëèãèÿ[\LINK] ìîãóò ñîçäàâàòü ìèññèîíåðîâ â ëþáîì ãîðîäå, èñïîâåäóþùåì ãîñóäàðñòâåííóþ ðåëèãèþ; ïðè äðóãèõ ïàðàäèãìàõ îíè ñîçäàþòñÿ ëèøü â ìîíàñòûðÿõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äâèæåíèå ìèññèîíåðîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìèññèîíåðû äâèæóòñÿ ïî êàðòå òàê æå, êàê äðóãèå þíèòû: ñâîáîäíî ïåðåìåùàþòñÿ ïî ñâîåé èëè íåéòðàëüíîé òåððèòîðèè, íî íå ìîãóò çàõîäèòü íà òåððèòîðèþ ãîñóäàðñòâà, ñ êîòîðûì íåò ñîãëàøåíèÿ îá [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äåÿòåëüíîñòü ìèññèîíåðîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðåìåñòèâ ìèññèîíåðà â íóæíûé ãîðîä, ùåëêíèòå íà åãî ïàíåëè ïðèêàç "Ïðîïîâåäü" (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Þíèòû[\LINK]); â ñëó÷àå óäà÷è ðåëèãèÿ ïîÿâèòñÿ â ãîðîäå. Ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèå ðåëèãèè ïðîùå ñðåäè ñîîòå÷åñòâåííèêîâ, à òàêæå â ãîðîäàõ, ãäå ìàëî äðóãèõ ðåëèãèé: ÷åì ìåíüøå, òåì ëåã÷å. Êîëè÷åñòâî ðåëèãèé â ãîðîäå íå îãðàíè÷åíî, áîê î áîê ìîãóò ñîñóùåñòâîâàòü âñå ñåìü. Íåçàâèñèìî îò ðåçóëüòàòà ïðîïîâåäè ìèññèîíåð èñ÷åçíåò.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîëîæèòåëüíûå ýôôåêòû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîëüçà äëÿ ãîðîäîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Âñå ãîðîäà, ãäå ïðåäñòàâëåíà ãîñóäàðñòâåííàÿ ðåëèãèÿ, ïîëó÷àþò îäíó äîïîëíèòåëüíóþ åäèíèöó íàñòðîåíèÿ è äàþò îäíó åäèíèöó êóëüòóðû çà õîä. Òàêèì îáðàçîì, ðàñïðîñòðàíÿÿ ãîñóäàðñòâåííóþ ðåëèãèþ, óäîáíî ðàñøèðÿòü çîíó êóëüòóðíîãî âëèÿíèÿ íà ðàííèõ ýòàïàõ èãðû. Ãîðîä, ñâÿùåííûé äëÿ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèè, ïîëó÷àåò ïÿòü äîïîëíèòåëüíûõ åäèíèö êóëüòóðû çà õîä, òàê ÷òî åãî çîíà âëèÿíèÿ ðàñòåò åùå áûñòðåå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîñòðîéêè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ãîðîä, ãäå íåò ðåëèãèé, íå ìîæåò ñòðîèòü õðàìîâ, ñîáîðîâ è ïðî÷èõ ðåëèãèîçíûõ çäàíèé (ñì. íèæå); íå ñîçäàþòñÿ òàì è ñïåöèàëèñòû-[LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Øïèîíàæ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Èìåÿ â ñâîåì ðàñïîðÿæåíèè ñâÿùåííûé ãîðîä, âû ïîëó÷àåòå âîçìîæíîñòü âèäåòü ÷óæèå ãîðîäà, ãäå ïðåäñòàâëåíà ñîîòâåòñòâóþùàÿ ðåëèãèÿ. Âñå, ÷òî äåëàþò ñîñåäè, - êàê íà ëàäîíè, ïðè÷åì áåñïëàòíî.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äîõîä îò ñâÿòûíè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ó âàñ åñòü ñâÿùåííûé ãîðîä è Âåëèêèé ïðîðîê, ìîæíî ïîñòðîèòü äëÿ ñîîòâåòñòâóþùåé ðåëèãèè ñâÿòûíþ, è îíà áóäåò ïðèíîñèòü äîõîä ïî ÷èñëó ãîðîäîâ, ñâîèõ è ÷óæèõ, ãäå ïðåäñòàâëåíà ýòà ðåëèãèÿ (ñì. íèæå).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàðàäèãìû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðåëèãèîçíûå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK] îïèñûâàþò îòíîøåíèÿ ðåëèãèè è íàðîäà. Èõ ïÿòü; â íà÷àëå èãðû èçâåñòíî òîëüêî ÿçû÷åñòâî, ñëåäóþùèå ÷åòûðå ïîÿâëÿþòñÿ ïî ìåðå îñâîåíèÿ íåîáõîäèìûõ òåõíîëîãèé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]ßçû÷åñòâî[\BOLD]. Íèêàêèõ òåõíîëîãèé íå òðåáóåòñÿ. Íà÷àëüíàÿ, ïðîñòåéøàÿ ðåëèãèîçíàÿ ïàðàäèãìà. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Îðãàíèçîâàííàÿ ðåëèãèÿ[\BOLD]. Òðåáóåòñÿ [LINK=TECH_MONOTHEISM]ìîíîòåèçì[\LINK]. Óñêîðÿåò ïðîèçâîäñòâî ïîñòðîåê â ãîðîäàõ ñ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèåé è ïîçâîëÿåò ñîçäàâàòü ìèññèîíåðîâ áåç ìîíàñòûðåé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Òåîêðàòèÿ[\BOLD]. Òðåáóåòñÿ [LINK=TECH_THEOLOGY]áîãîñëîâèå[\LINK]. Òåîêðàòèÿ äîáàâëÿåò äâå åäèíèöû îïûòà þíèòàì, ïîäãîòîâëåííûì â ãîðîäàõ ñ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèåé, è íå äàåò íåãîñóäàðñòâåííûì ðåëèãèÿì ðàñïðîñòðàíÿòüñÿ â âàøèõ âëàäåíèÿõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïàöèôèçì[\BOLD]. Òðåáóåòñÿ [LINK=TECH_PHILOSOPHY]ôèëîñîôèÿ[\LINK]. Ðåçêî ïîâûøàåò ÷àñòîòó ïîÿâëåíèÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]çíàìåíèòîñòåé[\LINK] â ãîðîäàõ ñ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèåé, íî ïîâûøàåò çàòðàòû íà ñîäåðæàíèå âîåííûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñâîáîäà ñîâåñòè[\BOLD]. Òðåáóåòñÿ [LINK=TECH_LIBERALISM]ëèáåðàëèçì[\LINK]. Ó äåðæàâû ñ äàííîé ïàðàäèãìîé íåò ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèè. Âñå ãîðîäà ïîëó÷àþò åäèíèöû íàñòðîåíèÿ çà êàæäóþ íåãîñóäàðñòâåííóþ ðåëèãèþ, à òàêæå 10% ïðèáàâêè ê [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]èññëåäîâàíèÿì[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êóëüòîâûå çäàíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñòü íåñêîëüêî âèäîâ êóëüòîâûõ ïîñòðîåê. Îíè ïðèíàäëåæàò îïðåäåëåííîé âåðå è ìîãóò ñòðîèòüñÿ òîëüêî â ãîðîäàõ, ãäå îíà ïðåäñòàâëåíà. Â ãîðîäå, ãäå ðåëèãèé íåñêîëüêî, ìîæíî èìåòü çäàíèÿ äëÿ êàæäîé - ñêàæåì, â ãîðîäå ñ èóäàèçìîì è êîíôóöèàíñòâîì ìîæíî ïîñòðîèòü è èóäåéñêèé, è êîíôóöèàíñêèé õðàì.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Õðàìû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îíè æå "ìàëûå õðàìû". Ïðîñòåéøèå êóëüòîâûå ïîñòðîéêè. Ïîâûøàþò â ãîðîäå [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]íàñòðîåíèå[\LINK]. Ïîçâîëÿþò ïåðåâåñòè îäíó åäèíèöó íàñåëåíèÿ â [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]ñïåöèàëèñòû[\LINK]-ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ìîíàñòûðè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìîíàñòûðè íåìíîãî óñêîðÿþò èññëåäîâàíèÿ â ãîðîäå. ×òî áîëåå âàæíî, îíè ïîçâîëÿþò ñîçäàâàòü ìèññèîíåðîâ, ÷òîáû ðàñïðîñòðàíÿòü ðåëèãèþ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñîáîðû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îíè æå "áîëüøèå õðàìû". Ñîáîðû ñóùåñòâåííî óâåëè÷èâàþò êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü â ãîðîäå. Åñëè îíè ïðèíàäëåæàò ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèè, òî ïîâûøàþò íàñòðîåíèå. Ïîçâîëÿþò ïåðåâåñòè äâå åäèíèöû íàñåëåíèÿ â ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëè. Îáðàòèòå âíèìàíèå, ÷òî òåðìèí "ñîáîð" èñïîëüçóåòñÿ ñîáèðàòåëüíî: ñèíàãîãè, ìå÷åòè, õðèñòèàíñêèå ñîáîðû è ò.ï. äàþò îäèíàêîâûé ýôôåêò. Ñîáîð ìîæíî èìåòü òîëüêî îäèí íà êàæäûå òðè õðàìà; òàê, äåðæàâà, âëàäåþùàÿ ñåìüþ õðàìàìè, ìîæåò ïîñòðîèòü äâà ñîáîðà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñâÿòûíè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñâÿòûíþ ìîæíî ñòðîèòü òîëüêî â òîì ãîðîäå, ãäå ðåëèãèÿ áûëà îñíîâàíà. Èõ ñîçäàþò [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Âåëèêèå ïðîðîêè[\LINK]: òîëüêî ýòîò þíèò ìîæåò ñîçäàòü ñâÿòûíþ, ïîñëå ÷åãî èñ÷åçàåò. Ñâÿòûíè ñïîñîáñòâóþò ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèþ ðåëèãèè è ïîâûøàþò êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü ãîðîäà, ãäå îíè ðàñïîëîæåíû. Îíè ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî â ýòîì ãîðîäå ïîÿâèòñÿ ïðîðîê, è ïîçâîëÿþò ïåðåâåñòè òðè åäèíèöû íàñåëåíèÿ â ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëåé. Îñîáåííî âàæíî, ÷òî êàæäûé õîä îíè äàþò ïî îäíîé åäèíèöå çîëîòà çà êàæäûé ãîðîä íà êàðòå, ãäå èñïîâåäóåòñÿ òà æå ðåëèãèÿ (âîò ïî÷åìó òàê íåîáõîäèìî ðàññûëàòü ìèññèîíåðîâ è âåñòè ïðîïîâåäè). Ñâÿòûíÿ è ñîáîðû íàçûâàþòñÿ ïî-ðàçíîìó äëÿ ðàçíûõ ðåëèãèé.
TEXT.English: [H1]Religion[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Religion has always played a critical part in human history. Through religion, man has sought to make sense of the universe around him and to determine his place in it. Religion has inspired, enlightened and ennobled man; in its name men have erected beautiful buildings, written books of great wisdom, and made music of surpassing beauty. In its name men have also murdered and enslaved their fellows.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Religion in this Game[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]We know that people have extremely strong opinions about religions - in fact, many a war has arisen when these beliefs collide. We at Firaxis have no desire to offend anyone. However, given the importance that religions have had in human development, we didn't want to simply leave them out of the game altogether; instead we have tried to handle them in as respectful, fair and even-handed manner as possible. In fact, all religions in the game have the same effects, the only difference being their requirements.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are seven religions in Civilization IV (testing having determined that seven was the optimal number for gameplay). When determining which seven to include, we picked those religions that we thought would be most familiar to our audience. We do not mean to imply that these religions are more important, better or worse than any other religions.[PARAGRAPH:2]We offer no value judgments on religion; we mean no disrespect to anyone's beliefs. We're game designers, not theologians.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Founding a Religion[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If you are the first civilization to discover the associated technology, the religion is founded in one of your cities. It is extremely useful to have a city where a religion has been founded; it allows a prophet to create a "shrine" in that city (see below).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]State Religions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When any cities in your civilization possess one or more religions, you may choose to assign one as the "state" religion. Having a state religion tends to make your cities possessing that religion happier and more productive; it also increases the effects of many religious buildings and religious civics.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Spreading Religions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Religions spread randomly from city to city. Religions tend to spread from a city possessing the religion to nearby cities as well as to cities the possessing city has trade routes with. Some religious buildings (see below) increase the speed at which a religion will spread, and a civilization's religious civic (see below) can have a great effect upon the spread of religions, as well. [LINK=UNIT_BUDDHIST_MISSIONARY]Missionaries[\LINK] allow you to control the spread of religion; see the following section.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Missionaries[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Civilizations can construct special "missionary" units to spread the civilization's state religion. Each civilization may have only a limited number of missionary units in play at any one time, and each costs two gold per turn to maintain.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Building Missionaries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2] Civilizations using the [LINK=CIVIC_ORGANIZED_RELIGION]Organized Religion[\LINK] civic can construct missionaries in any city with the state religion; if a civilization is not following Organized Religion, it can build missionaries only in cities with Monasteries.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Moving Missionaries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Once constructed, missionaries can move about the map like any other unit. Your missionaries can freely enter your territory or neutral territory; they cannot enter another civilization's territory until you have an [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Open Borders[\LINK] agreement with that civ. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How Missionaries Spread Religion[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When the missionary is in the target city, click on the "spread religion" order in the missionary's unit box (see [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Units[\LINK]); if the attempt is successful the missionary's religion is now in the target city. Religions spread more easily into other cities within the missionary's civilization. Further, it is easier to spread a religion into a city with few or no religions already present; each resident religion decreases the odds of success. There is no limit to how many religions may be present in a single city; all seven religions can coexist in the same city. The missionary is consumed in the conversion attempt, successful or not.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Benefits of Religion[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]City Benefits[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]All cities that possess your state religion receive one extra happy face and produce one culture per turn. Spreading your state religion is thus a good way to expand cultural borders in the early stages of your civilization. The holy city for your state religion also receives an additional bonus of five culture per turn, allowing it to expand its borders very quickly.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Buildings[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Without a religion in a city, that city cannot construct religious buildings like Temples and Cathedrals (see below). Cities without religions also cannot create Priest [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Specialists[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Espionage[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If you control the holy city for a religion, you gain line-of-sight benefits in all foreign cities sharing your religion. This allows you to spy on what enemy cities are doing at no cost.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Shrine Income[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If you control the holy city for a religion and generate a Great Prophet, you can build the Shrine for that religion to generate income for every city in the world that possesses your religion (see below).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Religious Civics[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The religious [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] describe how religion affects your civilization. There are five religious civics in the game. You begin the game knowing only paganism; the other four become available when you learn their associated technologies.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Paganism:[\BOLD] No technology requirement. The basic religious civic. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Organized Religion:[\BOLD] Requires [LINK=TECH_MONOTHEISM]Monotheism[\LINK]. Increases production of buildings in cities with the state religion, and allows you to build missionaries without first constructing monasteries.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Theocracy:[\BOLD] Requires [LINK=TECH_THEOLOGY]Theology[\LINK]. Theocracy grants two additional experience points to units trained within cities with the state religion, and it stops the spread of non-state religions within the civilization.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Pacifism:[\BOLD] Requires [LINK=TECH_PHILOSOPHY]Philosophy[\LINK]. Greatly increases the [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Person[\LINK] birth rate in cities with the state religion, and it increases the support cost of military units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Free Religion:[\BOLD] Requires [LINK=TECH_LIBERALISM]Liberalism[\LINK]. A civilization with Free Religion has no state religion. Each city gets happiness for each non-state religion in the city; also, all cities get a 10%% boost in scientific [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Research[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Religious Buildings[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]There are a number of religious buildings available to be constructed. Religious buildings are dedicated to specific religions and can only be built in cities which have that religion. A city with more than one religion can have religious buildings for each religion: for example, a city with Judaism and Confucianism could construct both a Jewish Temple and a Confucian Temple.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Temples[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The most primitive religious building. Temples boost a city's [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]Happiness[\LINK]. They allow 1 population point to be turned into a priest [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Specialist[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Monasteries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Monasteries increase a city's research by a small amount. More importantly, they allow the city to build missionaries to spread your religion.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cathedrals[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Cathedrals drastically increase a city's culture. They increase happiness if their religion is the civilization's state religion. They allow two population points to be turned into priests. Note that "Cathedral" is a generic name for a religion's grander houses of worship - Jewish synagogues, Islamic mosques, Christian cathedrals, etc., all have the same effects. Your civilization can only build one cathedral for every three temples that your civilization possesses; for example, a civilization with seven temples could build two cathedrals. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Shrines[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Shrines can be built only in cities in which a religion has been founded. Shrines are constructed by [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Prophets[\LINK]; a great prophet is the only unit that can build a shrine, and the prophet is consumed in the process. Shrines increase the spread of the religion, as well as the home city's culture. They increase the city's chance of generating prophets and allow the city to assign three population as priests. Most importantly, shrines generate one gold each turn for every city on the map that has the shrine's religion (thus explaining the importance of creating missionaries to spread the word). Each religion has a different name for its cathedral and shrine.

Êòî íå ðàçâèâàåò òåõíîëîãèè, íå ñìîæåò ðàñøèðÿòü òåððèòîðèþ è íàðàùèâàòü íàñåëåíèå, òîò ïðîèãðàåò â ôèíàíñàõ, ïðîèçâîäñòâå è, ðàçóìååòñÿ, â óðîâíå âîîðóæåíèÿ. Ìîæíî èìåòü âîéñêî â äåñÿòü ðàç áîëüøå, ÷åì ó ïðîòèâíèêà, íî åñëè ó âàñ ëó÷íèêè è êîïåéùèêè, à ó íåãî ìóøêåòåðû è áóëàâîíîñöû, âàì ïðèäåòñÿ íåñëàäêî. [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Òåõíîëîãèÿ[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2]Çà êàæäûé õîä äåðæàâà ïðèîáðåòàåò íåñêîëüêî òàê íàçûâàåìûõ åäèíèö èññëåäîâàíèÿ, çà ñ÷åò êîòîðûõ îñâàèâàþòñÿ íîâûå òåõíîëîãèè. ×åì áîëüøå ýòèõ åäèíèö, òåì áûñòðåå ïðîãðåññ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Åäèíèöû èññëåäîâàíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö èññëåäîâàíèÿ çà õîä çàâèñèò îò êîëè÷åñòâà [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]äåíåã[\LINK], ïðîèçâîäèìûõ ãîðîäîì. Ãîðîäà ïîëó÷àþò îò îêðóæàþùåé ìåñòíîñòè ïèùó, ïðîäóêöèþ è äåíüãè, à êíîïêè ôèíàíñèðîâàíèÿ èññëåäîâàíèé ïîçâîëÿþò óêàçàòü, êàêóþ äîëþ äîõîäîâ íàïðàâëÿòü íà èññëåäîâàíèÿ, à êàêóþ îáðàùàòü â çîëîòî (ñì. äàëåå). Èññëåäîâàíèÿ ôèíàíñèðóþòñÿ òîëüêî äåíüãàìè, ïðè÷åì èñòî÷íèêîì ñðåäñòâ íå ìîæåò áûòü îáìåí, ãðàáåæ, äåÿòåëüíîñòü òîðãîâöåâ è ïðî÷åå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êíîïêè ôèíàíñèðîâàíèÿ èññëåäîâàíèé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êíîïêè ôèíàíñèðîâàíèÿ èññëåäîâàíèé íà îñíîâíîì ýêðàíå ïîêàçûâàþò, êàêîé ïðîöåíò äîõîäîâ òðàòèòñÿ íà èññëåäîâàíèÿ. Â íà÷àëå èãðû ýòî 100%, íî âåëè÷èíó â ëþáîé ìîìåíò ìîæíî èçìåíèòü. Êîãäà äåíåã íå õâàòàåò, ôèíàíñèðîâàíèå èññëåäîâàíèé àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ñíèæàåòñÿ äî ìàêñèìàëüíî âîçìîæíîãî ïðè òåêóùåì äîõîäå óðîâíÿ (ðàçóìååòñÿ, ìîæíî óðåçàòü åãî åùå ñèëüíåå âðó÷íóþ). À âîò óâåëè÷èâàòü ýòó ñóììó ìîæíî òîëüêî âðó÷íóþ, è çà ýòèì íàäî ñëåäèòü.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê ïîâûñèòü óðîâåíü[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðâîå, ÷òî íàäî ñäåëàòü, ÷òîáû ïîëó÷èòü ìàêñèìóì åäèíèö èññëåäîâàíèÿ - íàïðàâèòü íà íèõ ñêîëüêî ìîæíî ñðåäñòâ (òîëüêî íå ðàçîðèòåñü). Çàòåì åñòü åùå íåñêîëüêî ñïîñîáîâ:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñîçäàíèå áèáëèîòåê è äðóãèõ ïîñòðîåê[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]çäàíèÿ[\LINK], íàïðèìåð [LINK=BUILDING_LIBRARY]áèáëèîòåêè[\LINK] è [LINK=SPECIALBUILDING_MONASTARY]ìîíàñòûðè[\LINK], äàþò åäèíèöû èññëåäîâàíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñîçäàíèå ñïåöèàëèñòîâ-ó÷åíûõ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðåâåäèòå ÷àñòü æèòåëåé â [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]ñïåöèàëèñòû-ó÷åíûå [\LINK]. Íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà ñâåòà[\LINK], íàïðèìåð, [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_LIBRARY]Àëåêñàíäðèéñêàÿ áèáëèîòåêà[\LINK], ïîçâîëÿþò èìåòü èõ â áîëüøåì êîëè÷åñòâå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïàðàäèãìû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Òàêèå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK] êàê [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_RELIGION]Ñâîáîäà ñîâåñòè[\LINK] è [LINK=CIVIC_REPRESENTATION]Ïðåäñòàâèòåëüíîå ïðàâëåíèå[\LINK] ïîâûøàþò óðîâåíü èññëåäîâàíèé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàçâèòèå êîììåðöèè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Èññëåäîâàíèÿ ïîéäóò áûñòðåå, åñëè ãîðîäà íà÷íóò äàâàòü áîëüøå äåíåã. ×òîáû ðàçâèòü êîììåðöèþ, ñòðîéòå [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COTTAGE]äîìà[\LINK], ïîðòîâûå ãîðîäà è çàêëþ÷àéòå ñ ñîñåäÿìè ñîãëàøåíèÿ îá [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Óâåëè÷åíèå êàïèòàëà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàê íè ñòðàííî, íà ïîëüçó èññëåäîâàíèÿì èäåò è ïðèðîñò êàïèòàëà. Ñòðîéòå [LINK=BUILDING_MARKETPLACE]ðûíêè[\LINK] è [LINK=BUILDING_BANK]áàíêè[\LINK]; ãîðîä ñòàíåò ïðîèçâîäèòü áîëüøå çîëîòà, ÷òî îáû÷íî âëèÿåò íà êíîïêó èññëåäîâàíèé (ñì. âûøå), à çíà÷èò, íà îáùóþ ñêîðîñòü èññëåäîâàíèé. Î ïîëó÷åíèè äåíåã ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Êàïèòàë[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê òðàòèòü[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âñå åäèíèöû èññëåäîâàíèÿ òðàòÿòñÿ íà ðàçâèòèå [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]òåõíîëîãèé[\LINK]. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. â ñîîòâåòñòâóþùåì ðàçäåëå.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Research[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]To survive, your civilization must advance and grow technologically. Being backwards is suicide; advanced civilizations have huge advantages in expansion, growth, commerce, production, and, of course, in military units available to them. Your army may outnumber mine by ten to one, but if your army consists of archers and spearmen and mine of musketmen and macemen, you are going to get your butt seriously kicked. A small technological edge is powerful, while a large one is killer. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technology[\LINK] for more information on this important subject.)[PARAGRAPH:2]Each turn your civilization generates "research points" which go toward acquiring new technologies. The more research points generated, the faster your civilization will learn new technologies.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Generating Research Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The number of "research points" that you create each turn is determined by the amount of [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]Commerce[\LINK] the laborers in your cities generate. As your cities work the land around them, they earn food, production, and commerce. You use the "research button" to determine how much of that commerce you want to turn into research and how much you want in gold (see following). Only commerce generated by your cities can be turned into research: monies you earn from trading, pillaging and looting, merchant activities, and so forth are not available for this purpose.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]The Research Button[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The research button on the game's main screen displays the current percentage of your commerce you are dedicating to research. At game start it is set at 100%%; you can change this at any time. [PARAGRAPH:2]If your treasury is running low and your current research percentage would cost more commerce than you can spend, the game automatically lowers your research percentage to the highest percentage that you can afford. (You can manually adjust it even lower, of course.) Note that the game does not ever INCREASE your research percentage; any increases must be made manually by you.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Increasing Research Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]To get the maximum possible research points, first turn your research percentage up as far as it will go without bankrupting yourself. After that, there are a number of other things you can do. These include:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Construct Libraries and Other Buildings[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] such as [LINK=BUILDING_LIBRARY]Libraries[\LINK] and Monasteries will increase a city's research.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Assign Scientist Specialists[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Change some of your city's populace into [LINK=CONCEPT_SPECIALISTS]Scientist Specialists[\LINK]. [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] such as the [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_LIBRARY]Great Library[\LINK] allow you to change more of your populace into scientists.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civics[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] like [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_RELIGION]Free Religion[\LINK] and [LINK=CIVIC_REPRESENTATION]Representation[\LINK] increase your civilization's research.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Increase Commerce[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Another way to speed up research is to increase the amount of commerce that your cities are generating. Building [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COTTAGE]Cottages[\LINK] with workers, settling more cities on the coast, and signing [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Open Borders[\LINK] agreements with other civilizations will all generate more commerce in your cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Increase Wealth[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ironically, you can also increase the amount of research your civ is producing by generating more gold. Building [LINK=BUILDING_MARKETPLACE]Markets[\LINK] and [LINK=BUILDING_BANK]Banks[\LINK] will increase the amount of gold your civ is producing, which will usually allow you to increase the research button (see above) and thus generate more overall research! See the [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Wealth[\LINK] entry for more information on generating gold.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Expending Research Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]All research points are used to acquire [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technology[\LINK]. See that subject for more information.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ñîïðîòèâëåíèå[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Çàõâàòèâ [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîä[\LINK], ó÷òèòå: æèòåëè íå âñåãäà ñðàçó ïîíèìàþò, íàñêîëüêî èì ïîâåçëî ïîïàñòü â òàêèå äîáðûå è çàáîòëèâûå ðóêè. Íà ïåðâûõ ïîðàõ âîçìîæíî ñîïðîòèâëåíèå. Òàê æå âåäóò ñåáÿ ãîðîäà, êîãäà èñïûòûâàþò ñèëüíîå êóëüòóðíîå äàâëåíèå - äàëüøå ñëåäóåò áóíò è ñìåíà ïîääàíñòâà (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Ãðàíèöû[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]×òî ïðîèñõîäèò[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íè ïðîäóêöèè, íè êîììåðöèè, íè ïèùè[\BOLD]. Íà âñå âðåìÿ ñîïðîòèâëåíèÿ ðàáîòà â ãîðîäå çàìèðàåò; ïðåêðàùàåòñÿ ïðîèçâîäñòâî ïèùè è ïðîäóêöèè, îñòàíàâëèâàåòñÿ êîììåðöèÿ. Â ðåçóëüòàòå ìîæåò íà÷àòüñÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]ãîëîä[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íóëåâàÿ çîíà âëèÿíèÿ[\BOLD]. Ó ãîðîäà èñ÷åçàåò [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]çîíà âëèÿíèÿ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íóëåâîé áîíóñ ê çàùèòå[\BOLD]. Ðàçìåð è êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü ïåðåñòàþò äàâàòü ãîðîäó áîíóñ ê çàùèòå (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Ãîðîäà[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïðîäîëæèòåëüíîñòü [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðîäîëæèòåëüíîñòü ñîïðîòèâëåíèÿ çàâèñèò îò òîãî, íàñêîëüêî êóëüòóðà çàõâà÷åííîãî ãîðîäà áëèçêà ê âàøåé. Îòáèâ ãîðîä, íåäàâíî çàíÿòûé âðàãîì, ñîïðîòèâëåíèÿ ìîæíî ïðàêòè÷åñêè íå áîÿòüñÿ; ÷óæîé ãîðîä, èñïûòàâøèé ñèëüíîå âëèÿíèå âàøåé äåðæàâû èëè èñïîâåäóþùèé òó æå ðåëèãèþ, ñìèðèòñÿ ñî ñìåíîé âëàñòè äîâîëüíî ñêîðî. Êðóïíûé ãîðîä ñ äîëãîé èñòîðèåé, çíà÷èòåëüíûì êóëüòóðíûì óðîâíåì è äðóãîé ðåëèãèåé áóäåò ñîïðîòèâëÿòüñÿ äîëãî.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñîêðàòèòü âðåìÿ ñîïðîòèâëåíèÿ òðóäíî, íî ìîæíî ïðåäîòâðàòèòü ïîâòîðíûå âñïûøêè, åñëè âíåäðèòü â ãîðîäå ãîñóäàðñòâåííóþ ðåëèãèþ, ïîñòðîèòü õðàìû è ò.ï., ïîäíÿòü êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü è îáåçîïàñèòüñÿ îò âëèÿíèÿ ñîñåäåé. Íå ïîìåøàåò òàêæå ââåñòè â ñîïðîòèâëÿþùèéñÿ ãîðîä ïàðó âîåííûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñîïðîòèâëåíèå íåìåäëåííî ïðåêðàòèòñÿ, åñëè [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Âåëèêèé òàëàíò[\LINK] ñîçäàñò â ãîðîäå øåäåâð - íî ó÷òèòå, ÷òî â ïðîöåññå òàëàíò èñ÷åçíåò.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Resistance[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]After you capture a [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK], it may be a while before its citizens recognize their good fortune in having gained such a wise and benevolent leader as yourself. In the meantime, they may "resist" your rule. Further, cities under great cultural pressure may go into resistance before revolting and "flipping" to another civilization's control (see [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Resistance[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Production, Commerce or Food:[\BOLD] If a city is in resistance, its population refuses to work. Thus the city produces no food, production, or commerce for the duration of the resistance. This may lead to [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Starvation[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Cultural Radius:[\BOLD] The city has no [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Cultural Radius[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Defensive Bonus:[\BOLD] The city receives no defensive bonus for size or culture (see [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of Resistance[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The duration of a city's resistance is based upon its similarity or dissimilarity to your civilization. If you recapture one of your own cities shortly after it was taken from you, you'll see little or no resistance. A foreign city that has been under a lot of cultural pressure from your civilization will tend to spend less time in resistance, as will a city that shares your civilization's religion. A big, old foreign city with a lot of culture and a different religion will tend to resist longer.[PARAGRAPH:2]You cannot do much to shorten the duration of resistance once it is in progress. However you can lessen the chances of the city returning to resistance by passing your state religion to that city and building temples and such, and by raising the city's culture and reducing any outside cultural pressure on that city. It is also a good idea to have one or two units garrisoning a city in resistance.[PARAGRAPH:2]A [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Artist[\LINK] can instantly end resistance in a city by creating a Great Work in it - but be warned that this will consume the Artist.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ðåñóðñû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Â ìèðå èãðû Civilization IV íåìàëî ïîëåçíûõ ïðèðîäíûõ ðåñóðñîâ. Íåêîòîðûå ïîìîãàþò â âîåííîì äåëå: òàê, ëîøàäè ïîçâîëÿþò ñîçäàâàòü íà ðàííèõ ýòàïàõ [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]êîëåñíèöû[\LINK] è ïðî÷èå êîííûå þíèòû, à â ýïîõó Âîçðîæäåíèÿ - [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]êàâàëåðèñòîâ[\LINK]. Äðóãèå èìåþò õîçÿéñòâåííóþ öåííîñòü. Ìðàìîð, íàïðèìåð, óñêîðÿåò ïîñòðîéêó [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Ïàðôåíîíà[\LINK]. Òðåòüè óëó÷øàþò çäîðîâüå è íàñòðîåíèå, áëàãîäàðÿ èì ðàñòóò è êðåïíóò ãîðîäà.
