Äåðæàâà, â ðàñïîðÿæåíèè êîòîðîé îáøèðíûå è ðàçíîîáðàçíûå ðåñóðñû, ïîëó÷àåò áîëüøîå ïðåèìóùåñòâî ïåðåä òåìè, ó êîãî èõ íåò; ýòî îäèí èç âàæíåéøèõ ôàêòîðîâ, êîòîðûå íàäî ó÷èòûâàòü ïðè âûáîðå ìåñòà äëÿ íîâûõ ãîðîäîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîèñêè ðåñóðñîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×àñòü ðåñóðñîâ - ëîøàäè, ðèñ, çîëîòî è ò.ï. - ÿâëÿþòñÿ âèäèìûìè ñ ñàìîãî íà÷àëà èãðû: èõ âèäíî âìåñòå ñ êëåòêîé (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Èññëåäîâàíèå òåððèòîðèè[\LINK]). Îñòàëüíûå ñïåðâà ñêðûòû è îáíàðóæèâàþòñÿ òîëüêî ñ ïðèîáðåòåíèåì òåõ èëè èíûõ [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]òåõíîëîãèé[\LINK]. Õîðîøèé ïðèìåð ñêðûòîãî ðåñóðñà - ìåäü: êîãäà èãðà íà÷èíàåòñÿ, ìåäè íèãäå íå âèäíî, íî ñòîèò îñâîèòü [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]áðîíçîâîå ëèòüå[\LINK], îíà ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ìåñòîíàõîæäåíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Òîëüêî ðåñóðñû â ïðåäåëàõ [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]êóëüòóðíûõ ãðàíèö[\LINK] âàøåé äåðæàâû ìîæíî ïîäêëþ÷èòü ê [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]òîðãîâîé ñåòè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàçðàáîòêà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîìèìî îñîáûõ ýôôåêòîâ, ðåñóðñû îáû÷íî ïîâûøàþò íà ñâîåé êëåòêå ïîêàçàòåëè ïèùè, êîììåðöèè èëè ïðîäóêöèè. Íàïðèìåð, êëåòêà ñ ïøåíèöåé ïðîèçâîäèò çíà÷èòåëüíî áîëüøå ïèùè. Åñëè ðåñóðñ îêàçûâàåòñÿ â çîíå âëèÿíèÿ ãîðîäà, èì ìîãóò çàíèìàòüñÿ ðàáîòíèêè, êàê ëþáîé äðóãîé êëåòêîé - è âðÿä ëè îíè ïðîéäóò ìèìî; îáû÷íî ýòî ñàìûå ëàêîìûå êóñî÷êè ìåñòíîñòè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðåñóðñû è îáúåêòû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû ðåñóðñ íà÷àë îêàçûâàòü ñâîå îñîáîå ïîëîæèòåëüíîå âëèÿíèå, íà åãî êëåòêå íóæåí ñîîòâåòñòâóþùèé îáúåêò (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Îáúåêòû[\LINK]). Îáúåêòû ñîçäàþòñÿ [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]ðàáîòíèêàìè[\LINK] (äëÿ âîäíûõ ðåñóðñîâ - [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]ïðîìûøëåííûìè ñóäàìè[\LINK]). Åñëè îáúåêò ðàçãðàáëåí èëè ðàçðóøåí, äåéñòâèå ðåñóðñà ïðåêðàùàåòñÿ, ïîêà îáúåêò íå âîññòàíîâÿò.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðåñóðñû-äóáëåòû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â âàøèõ ãðàíèöàõ âïîëíå ìîæåò îêàçàòüñÿ íåñêîëüêî îäèíàêîâûõ ðåñóðñîâ. Êàæäûé äàåò äîïîëíèòåëüíóþ ïðîäóêöèþ, êîììåðöèþ è ïèùó íà ñâîåé êëåòêå (ñì. âûøå ðàçäåë "Ðàçðàáîòêà"), íî â îñòàëüíîì îäèí ðåñóðñ ïîëíîñòüþ óäîâëåòâîðÿåò ïîòðåáíîñòè äåðæàâû. Äóáëåòû ìîæíî îñòàâèòü ñåáå íà ñëó÷àé, åñëè îäèí çàõâàòÿò âðàãè, à ìîæíî îáìåíÿòü - ó ñîñåäåé òîæå áûâàþò èçëèøêè (ñì. íèæå).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îáìåí[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Îáìåíÿòü ìîæíî ðåñóðñ, ñíàáæåííûé îáúåêòîì è ïîäêëþ÷åííûé ÷åðåç [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]ñåòü ãîðîäîâ[\LINK] ê ñòîëèöå (ïîäðîáíåå îá îáìåíå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Ïåðåãîâîðû[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Resources[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The world of Civilization IV contain various "natural resources" that have benefits for the civilizations which possess them. Some provide military benefits - the "horse" resource allows the creation of mounted units such as the [LINK=UNIT_CHARIOT]Chariot[\LINK] early on and [LINK=UNIT_CAVALRY]Cavalry[\LINK] in the Renaissance period. Some provide productivity benefits - marble decreases the labor required to construct the [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] wonder, for example. Other resources provide health and happiness to your cities, allowing them to grow to larger sizes and increase in power. A civilization that possesses a variety of resources will have a distinct advantage over one that possesses few or no resources, and resources are one of the most important factors to keep in mind when choosing city sites with settlers.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Discovering Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Some resources - rice, gold, etc. - begin the game visible. You will be able to see these resources as soon as their space is visible (see [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Exploration[\LINK]). Other resources are hidden at the start of play: they are not uncovered until you have acquired specific [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technologies[\LINK]. Copper is a good example of such a hidden resource; at game start no copper is visible anywhere on the map, but once you acquire the [LINK=TECH_BRONZE_WORKING]Bronze Working[\LINK] technology, copper is revealed.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Resource Locations[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Resources must be within your civilization's [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Cultural Borders[\LINK] in order to be connected to your [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]City Network[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Working Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to resources' special abilities, they also usually provide some kind of food, commerce, or production bonus to their space. For example, a wheat resource adds a significant amount of food to the tile on which it is located. If a resource space is within a city radius, that city's laborers can work that space like any other - and they will almost certainly want to, since resources are usually highly desirable tiles.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Resources and Improvements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Resources require that "improvements" be made to their spaces before you can access their special bonuses (see [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvements[\LINK] for more details). Improvements are constructed by [LINK=UNIT_WORKER]Workers[\LINK] (except for water resources, which are improved by [LINK=UNIT_WORKBOAT]Work Boats[\LINK]). If an improvement is pillaged or otherwise destroyed, you lose the resource's benefits until the improvement is reconstructed.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duplicate Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]It is quite possible to have two or more of the same resource within your borders. Except for each space's production, commerce, and food value (see "Working Resources" above), you gain no additional benefit from multiple resources; a single resource is enough to take care of all of your civilization's needs. You may wish to hold onto the extras in case one is captured by an enemy, or you may want to trade the extras to other civilizations in exchange for their extra resources (see below).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Trading Resources[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can trade any resource to other civilizations if that resource has been improved, and if it is connected by your [LINK=CONCEPT_CITY_NETWORK]City Network[\LINK] to your capital city (see [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK] for more details on trading).[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ïåðåâîðîò[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðåâîðîò ïðîèñõîäèò ïðè ñìåíå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK] èëè [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]ðåëèãèè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]×òî ïðîèñõîäèò[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîñëå ïåðåâîðîòà íà îäèí èëè íåñêîëüêî õîäîâ âîöàðÿåòñÿ àíàðõèÿ. Äåðæàâà ïåðåñòàåò ïðîèçâîäèòü ïèùó è ïðîäóêöèþ, îñòàíàâëèâàåòñÿ ïðèòîê äåíåã, ïðåðûâàåòñÿ ðàáîòà íàä çäàíèÿìè, þíèòàìè è ïðîåêòàìè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïðîäîëæèòåëüíîñòü[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðîäîëæèòåëüíîñòü àíàðõèè çàâèñèò îò òîãî, ñêîëüêî ïàðàäèãì âû èçìåíèòå: îäíà-äâå îáû÷íî âûçûâàþò àíàðõèþ íà îäèí õîä, òðè è áîëåå ìîãóò äàòü äâà õîäà è áîëüøå. Ñêîëüêî è ïðè êàêèõ èçìåíåíèÿõ áóäåò äåðæàòüñÿ àíàðõèÿ, ñîîáùàåòñÿ íà ïàíåëè ïàðàäèãì; åñëè ñëèøêîì äîëãî, òî ëèáî ñîêðàòèòå ïðåîáðàçîâàíèÿ, ëèáî âîîáùå äîæäèòåñü áîëåå ñïîêîéíûõ âðåìåí. Ñìåíà ðåëèãèè âñåãäà äàåò àíàðõèþ äëèíîé â îäèí õîä.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Íåïîäâåðæåííîñòü ïåðåâîðîòàì[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Äåðæàâû, [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]ëèäåðû[\LINK] êîòîðûõ ÿâëÿþòñÿ ìèñòèêàìè, âîîáùå íå çíàþò ïåðåâîðîòîâ è àíàðõèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàóçà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîñëå ïåðåâîðîòà ïðîèñõîäèò êîðîòêàÿ ïàóçà, íà ïðîòÿæåíèè êîòîðîé ïðåîáðàçîâàíèÿ íåâîçìîæíû. Êîãäà íà ïàíåëè ïàðàäèãì ñíîâà ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ êíîïêà "Ïåðåâîðîò", ýòî çíà÷èò, ÷òî äåðæàâà îïðàâèëàñü îò ïðîøëîé àíàðõèè è îïÿòü ãîòîâà ê ïåðåìåíàì.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Revolution[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A "revolution" occurs when you change your civilization's [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] or [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]Religion[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of a Revolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During a revolution your civilization descends into one or more turns of "anarchy." A civilization in anarchy produces no food, commerce, or production! Any progress towards completing buildings, units, or projects is stopped until the revolution is over.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of a Revolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The duration of a revolt depends upon the number of civics that you change: one or two civics will usually result in one turn of anarchy, while three or more civics may cause two or more turns of anarchy. The civics screen tells you how many turns of anarchy you may look forward to after you choose which civics to change. If the length of time is too long, either make fewer changes or cancel them altogether until you can spare the time. Religions always have one turn of revolution.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Immunity to Revolution[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Civilizations with [LINK=CONCEPT_LEADERS]Leaders[\LINK] possessing the "Spiritual" trait do not suffer the effects of revolution or anarchy at all.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Delay Period[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]After a revolution has taken place, there is a short period of delay before another revolution can be carried out. When the "Revolution" button appears once again on the civics screen, your citizens have recovered enough from the previous anarchy to carry out another revolution.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Âûõîä â êîñìîñ[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Îäèí èç ñïîñîáîâ äîñòè÷ü ïîáåäû - ïîñòðîèòü êîñìè÷åñêèé êîðàáëü è óñïåøíî çàïóñòèòü åãî ê Àëüôå Öåíòàâðà. Àëüôà Öåíòàâðà - áëèæàéøàÿ çâåçäà, â ñèñòåìå êîòîðîé ìîæåò îáíàðóæèòüñÿ ïëàíåòà çåìíîãî òèïà, è ôàíòàñòû èçäàâíà èìåííî òàì ïðåäðåêàþò âñòðå÷ó ñ ðàçóìíûìè ñóùåñòâàìè. Íå âñÿêîé äåðæàâå ïî ïëå÷ó íàïðàâèòü òóäà êîñìè÷åñêèé êîðàáëü; ýòî ëó÷øåå äîêàçàòåëüñòâî áåñïðèìåðíîé ýêîíîìè÷åñêîé è íàó÷íîé ìîùè.[PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ äåòàëåé êîðàáëÿ äîëæíà áûòü îñâîåíà áîëüøàÿ ÷àñòü ñîâðåìåííûõ òåõíîëîãèé. Íè îäíó äåòàëü [BOLD]íåâîçìîæíî[\BOLD] èçãîòîâèòü, íå èìåÿ [LINK=PROJECT_APOLLO_PROGRAM]ïðîãðàììû "Àïîëëîí"[\LINK]. Ñêîðîñòü èçãîòîâëåíèÿ çàâèñèò îò ðÿäà ôàêòîðîâ. Äëÿ íåêîòîðûõ äåòàëåé îíà ïîâûøàåòñÿ, åñëè åñòü äîñòóï ê òåì èëè èíûì [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñàì[\LINK] (îñîáåííî ê àëþìèíèþ). Åñëè â ãîðîäå, ãäå ñîçäàåòñÿ äåòàëü, åñòü [LINK=BUILDING_LABORATORY]ëàáîðàòîðèÿ[\LINK], ñêîðîñòü ïðîèçâîäñòâà âñåãäà âîçðàñòàåò íà 50%%. È, íàêîíåö, ÷óäî ñâåòà [LINK=BUILDING_SPACE_ELEVATOR]êîñìè÷åñêèé ëèôò[\LINK] óâåëè÷èâàåò ñêîðîñòü èçãîòîâëåíèÿ äåòàëåé êîñìè÷åñêîãî êîðàáëÿ íà 50%% [BOLD]äëÿ âñåõ ãîðîäîâ[\BOLD].[PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîäðîáíåå î ïîáåäå çà ñ÷åò âûõîäà â êîñìîñ ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY]Ïîáåäà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Spaceship[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Constructing a spaceship and sending it on a successful journey to Alpha Centauri is one of the paths to victory. Alpha Centauri is the closest location of a potentially habitable world, so it has long been fantasized as the place most likely to contain other forms of intelligent life. Blasting into space with a ship capable of traveling to Alpha Centauri is a clear demonstration of the greatness of your civilization. Only an economical and scientific powerhouse could pull off such a feat.[PARAGRAPH:2]The spaceship components can only be built after discoverying most of the modern era technologies. In order to construct any of the spaceship components, you [BOLD]must[\BOLD] have first built the [LINK=PROJECT_APOLLO_PROGRAM]Apollo Program[\LINK]. Each component's production speed can be affected by several factors. Access to certain [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK] (most notably Aluminum) can provide production increases for certain components. A [LINK=BUILDING_LABORATORY]Laboratory[\LINK] in the city that is building the component always grants a 50%% increase in production speed. Finally, the [LINK=BUILDING_SPACE_ELEVATOR]Space Elevator[\LINK] wonder grants a 50%% increase in production on spaceship components [BOLD]for all cities[\BOLD].[PARAGRAPH:2]For more information about winning the game via the Spaceship, see the [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY]Victory[\LINK] Civilopedia entry.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ñïåöèàëèñòû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñðàçó ïîñëå îñíîâàíèÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäà[\LINK] ó åãî æèòåëåé îäíà çàáîòà - íå óìåðåòü ñ ãîëîäó: îíè îõîòÿòñÿ, ëîâÿò ðûáó, ïàøóò çåìëþ è òàê äàëåå. Íî ïîñòåïåííî ãîðîä ðàñòåò, áîãàòååò, è íàñòóïàåò âðåìÿ, êîãäà íåñêîëüêî ÷åëîâåê ìîæíî âûäåëèòü äëÿ áîëåå âûãîäíûõ çàíÿòèé. Ýòè ïîëåçíûå þíèòû îáîçíà÷àþòñÿ òåðìèíîì "ñïåöèàëèñòû".[PARAGRAPH:2]Åñòü øåñòü òèïîâ ñïåöèàëèñòîâ: èíæåíåðû, òîðãîâöû, ó÷åíûå, õóäîæíèêè, ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëè è ñïåöèàëèñòû îáùåãî ïðîôèëÿ - ïðîñòî ãðàæäàíå. Îò êàæäîãî ãîðîä èìååò îïðåäåëåííûå áëàãà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]×òî òðåáóåòñÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â íà÷àëå èãðû ìîæíî ñîçäàâàòü òîëüêî ãðàæäàí - íàèìåíåå ýôôåêòèâíûõ ñïåöèàëèñòîâ. Äëÿ âñåõ îñòàëüíûõ òèïîâ òðåáóþòñÿ òå èëè èíûå [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]çäàíèÿ[\LINK] èëè [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà ñâåòà[\LINK]. Íî è òîãäà êîëè÷åñòâî ñïåöèàëèñòîâ áóäåò îãðàíè÷åíî. Òàê, åñëè ïîñòðîèòü õðàì, ìîæíî çàâåñòè â ýòîì ãîðîäå îäíîãî (è òîëüêî îäíîãî) ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëÿ. Åñëè çàòåì âîçâåñòè òàì ñîáîð, ìîæíî äîáàâèòü åùå äâîèõ, è âñåãî ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëåé ñòàíåò òðîå.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_CASTE_SYSTEM]Êàñòîâàÿ ñèñòåìà[\LINK] ïîçâîëÿåò ñîçäàâàòü â ëþáîì êîëè÷åñòâå òîðãîâöåâ, ó÷åíûõ è õóäîæíèêîâ íåçàâèñèìî îò òîãî, åñòü ëè çäàíèÿ, íåîáõîäèìûå äëÿ íèõ ïðè äðóãèõ ïàðàäèãìàõ. ×òî æå êàñàåòñÿ èíæåíåðîâ è ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëåé, èõ ÷èñëî âñåãäà îãðàíè÷åíî æåñòêî; íóæíû ëèáî çäàíèÿ, ëèáî ÷óäåñà ñâåòà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñïåöèàëèñòû è ðîñò íàñåëåíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êîãäà â ãîðîäå ïîÿâëÿþòñÿ íîâûå æèòåëè, îíè ñíà÷àëà ïûòàþòñÿ óñòðîèòüñÿ âîçäåëûâàòü îêðóæàþùóþ çåìëþ (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Ãîðîäà[\LINK]). Åñëè åñòü ñâîáîäíûå êëåòêè ñóøè, ãîðîä ïî ñâîåìó óñìîòðåíèþ íàïðàâëÿåò íîâûé þíèò òóäà, ãäå ïðåäñòàâëÿåòñÿ, ÷òî îí ïðèíåñåò áîëüøå ïîëüçû. Ìàêñèìàëüíûé ðàçìåð ãîðîäñêèõ óãîäèé - 20 êëåòîê èëè ìåíüøå, åñëè â [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]çîíó âëèÿíèÿ[\LINK] ïîïàäàþò ïóñòûíè èëè ãîðíûå âåðøèíû. Ïðåâðàòèâ òàêîãî çåìëåäåëüöà â ñïåöèàëèñòà, âû îòîðâåòå åãî îò ïðîèçâîäñòâà ïèùè; îäíàêî ñàìîìó åìó åñòü ïî-ïðåæíåìó íàäî, òàê ÷òî îñòàëüíîå íàñåëåíèå äîëæíî áûòü â ñîñòîÿíèè ïðîêîðìèòü âñåõ, èëè íà÷íåòñÿ ãîëîä. Ïîýòîìó, êàê ïðàâèëî, ñïåöèàëèñòîâ áîëüøå òàì, ãäå áîëüøå ïèùè. Ãäå ïèùà â äåôèöèòå, ïåðâîî÷åðåäíàÿ çàäà÷à - áîðüáà ñ ãîëîäîì.[PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè âñå óãîäüÿ çàíÿòû, íîâûå þíèòû àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ñòàíóò ñïåöèàëèñòàìè (ó÷òèòå, ÷òî òàêîå îáû÷íî ñëó÷àåòñÿ ëèøü ïîä êîíåö èãðû!). Ãîðîä ñàì âûáèðàåò íàèáîëåå ïîëåçíûé òèï; åñëè íåò äðóãèõ âàêàíñèé, áóäåò ñîçäàí ãðàæäàíèí. Êðîìå òîãî, ìîæíî âðó÷íóþ ïåðåâåñòè çåìëåäåëüöà â ñïåöèàëèñòû (ñì. íèæå). Êîãäà ãîðîä ïðèáëèæàåòñÿ ê ðàçìåðàì, çà êîòîðûìè òðóäíî ïîääåðæèâàòü [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]íàñòðîåíèå[\LINK], ëó÷øå ñäåëàòü ÷àñòü æèòåëåé ñïåöèàëèñòàìè, ÷åì äàòü ãîðîäó ðàñòè äàëüøå è âïàäàòü â íåäîâîëüñòâî.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñïåöèàëèñòû è çíàìåíèòîñòè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîìèìî äðóãèõ ôóíêöèé, îïèñàííûõ íèæå, êàæäûé ñïåöèàëèñò äîáàâëÿåò 3 åäèíèöû, êîãäà ãîðîä ïðîèçâîäèò çíàìåíèòîñòåé. Ñïåöèàëèñòû òàêæå âëèÿþò íà èõ ðîä çàíÿòèé. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Çíàìåíèòîñòè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Êàê ñîçäàòü ñïåöèàëèñòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñïåöèàëèñòà ìîæíî ñîçäàòü íà ïàíåëè ãîðîäà; øåñòü òèïîâ ïîêàçàíû íà åå ïðàâîì êðàþ. ×åðíî-áåëîå èçîáðàæåíèå çíà÷èò, ÷òî òèï ïîêà íåäîñòóïåí. Åñëè èçîáðàæåíèå öâåòíîå, ùåëêíèòå çíàê ïëþñ (+) ðÿäîì ñ íèì, ÷òîáû ñîçäàòü ñïåöèàëèñòà, è çíàê ìèíóñ (-), ÷òîáû åãî óáðàòü. Êîãäà ñîçäàåòñÿ ñïåöèàëèñò, îäíà èç åäèíèö íàñåëåíèÿ ïðåêðàùàåò îáðàáàòûâàòü êëåòêó â çîíå âëèÿíèÿ ãîðîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû ëè÷íî âûáðàòü, êàêóþ êëåòêó îñâîáîäèòü, ñíà÷àëà ùåëêíèòå ýòó êëåòêó (âîêðóã íåå äîëæíî èñ÷åçíóòü áåëîå êîëüöî). Áóäåò ñîçäàí ãðàæäàíèí. Çàòåì ùåëêíèòå çíàê ïëþñ (+) ðÿäîì ñ òðåáóåìûì òèïîì ñïåöèàëèñòà, è ãðàæäàíèí çàìåíèòñÿ íà íåãî.[PARAGRAPH:2]Îáðàòèòå âíèìàíèå, ÷òî íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñà ñâåòà[\LINK] àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ïîðîæäàþò îäíîãî èëè íåñêîëüêèõ ñïåöèàëèñòîâ îïðåäåëåííîãî òèïà; èõ íåëüçÿ íè óáðàòü, íè ïåðåâåñòè â äðóãîé òèï. Åñòü ÷óäåñà ñâåòà è ïàðàäèãìû, êîòîðûå ñîçäàþò â êàæäîì ãîðîäå ïî îäíîìó áåñïëàòíîìó ñïåöèàëèñòó; äëÿ íèõ ìîæíî âûáèðàòü òèï, íî óáðàòü èõ íåëüçÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òèïû ñïåöèàëèñòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Èíæåíåð[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Èíæåíåðû äîáàâëÿþò äâå åäèíèöû ê óðîâíþ ïðîèçâîäñòâà â ãîðîäå, òðè åäèíèöû ê ñêîðîñòè ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé è ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî ïîÿâèòñÿ Âåëèêèé èíæåíåð. Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ èíæåíåðîâ íåîáõîäèìû [LINK=BUILDING_FORGE]êóçíèöû[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_FACTORY]ôàáðèêè[\LINK] èëè äðóãèå ïðîìûøëåííûå çäàíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Òîðãîâåö[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Òîðãîâöû óâåëè÷èâàþò êàïèòàë íà òðè åäèíèöû, íàñòîëüêî æå ñêîðîñòü ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé è ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî â ãîðîäå ïîÿâèòñÿ Âåëèêèé òîðãîâåö. Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ òîðãîâöåâ íåîáõîäèìû [LINK=BUILDING_MARKET]ðûíêè[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_BANK]áàíêè[\LINK] èëè äðóãèå çäàíèÿ, ñâÿçàííûå ñ êîììåðöèåé.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ó÷åíûé[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ó÷åíûå äîáàâëÿþò òðè åäèíèöû ê ñêîðîñòè èññëåäîâàíèé â ãîðîäå, ñòîëüêî æå ê ñêîðîñòè ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé è ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî ïîÿâèòñÿ Âåëèêèé ó÷åíûé. Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ ó÷åíûõ íåîáõîäèìû [LINK=BUILDING_LIBRARY]áèáëèîòåêè[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]óíèâåðñèòåòû[\LINK] èëè äðóãèå çäàíèÿ, ñâÿçàííûå ñ èññëåäîâàíèÿìè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Õóäîæíèê[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Õóäîæíèêè óâåëè÷èâàþò êàïèòàë ãîðîäà íà îäíó åäèíèöó, êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü íà ÷åòûðå, à ñêîðîñòü ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé íà òðè è ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî ïîÿâèòñÿ Âåëèêèé òàëàíò. Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ ó÷åíûõ íåîáõîäèìû [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]òåàòðû[\LINK] èëè äðóãèå êóëüòóðíûå ó÷ðåæäåíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëü[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëè äîáàâëÿþò ïî îäíîé åäèíèöå ê óðîâíÿì êîììåðöèè è ïðîèçâîäñòâà, óâåëè÷èâàþò ñêîðîñòü ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé â ãîðîäå íà òðè åäèíèöû è ïîâûøàþò âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî ïîÿâèòñÿ Âåëèêèé ïðîðîê. Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëåé íåîáõîäèìû [LINK=SPECIALBUILDING_TEMPLE]õðàìû[\LINK], [LINK=SPECIALBUILDING_CATHEDRAL]ñîáîðû[\LINK] è äðóãèå êóëüòîâûå çäàíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãðàæäàíèí[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ãðàæäàíå äîáàâëÿþò îäíó åäèíèöó ê óðîâíþ ïðîèçâîäñòâà. Ñêîðîñòü ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé îíè íå óâåëè÷èâàþò è íå âëèÿþò íà èõ ðîä çàíÿòèé. Äëÿ ñîçäàíèÿ ãðàæäàí íå òðåáóåòñÿ íè ïîñòðîåê, íè ÷óäåñ ñâåòà, è èõ ÷èñëåííîñòü íå îãðàíè÷åíà. Îäíàêî çàâîäèòü òîëïû ãðàæäàí îáû÷íî íåöåëåñîîáðàçíî: îíè íå îêóïàþòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàðàäèãìû è ÷óäåñà ñâåòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìíîãèå ÷óäåñà ñâåòà è ïàðàäèãìû óñèëèâàþò âëèÿíèå ñïåöèàëèñòîâ, à òàêæå èìåþò äðóãèå ýôôåêòû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Åùå áîëüøå åäèíèö íà çíàìåíèòîñòåé[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñòü íåñêîëüêî ïàðàäèãì è ÷óäåñ ñâåòà, ïðè êîòîðûõ ñïåöèàëèñòû åùå ñèëüíåå óâåëè÷èâàþò ñêîðîñòü ïîÿâëåíèÿ çíàìåíèòîñòåé. [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Ïàðôåíîí[\LINK] ïîâûøàåò ýòó ñêîðîñòü íà 50% âî âñåõ ãîðîäàõ, à [LINK=BUILDING_NATIONAL_EPIC]íàöèîíàëüíûé ýïîñ[\LINK] - íà 100% â òîì ãîðîäå, ãäå ñîçäàí. Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_PACIFISM]Ïàöèôèçì[\LINK] óâåëè÷èâàåò åå íà 100% âî âñåõ ãîðîäàõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äðóãèå ýôôåêòû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Äðóãèå ýôôåêòû êàñàþòñÿ äåÿòåëüíîñòè ñàìèõ ñïåöèàëèñòîâ. Òàê, ÷óäî ñâåòà [LINK=BUILDING_ANGKOR_WAT]Àíãêîð-Âàò[\LINK] äîáàâëÿåò ïî îäíîé åäèíèöå íà êàæäîãî ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëÿ ê óðîâíþ ïðîèçâîäñòâà, à [LINK=BUILDING_SISTINE_CHAPEL]Ñèêñòèíñêàÿ êàïåëëà[\LINK] - ïî äâå åäèíèöû íà êàæäîãî ñïåöèàëèñòà ê êóëüòóðíîìó óðîâíþ. Ïàðàäèãìà [LINK=CIVIC_REPRESENTATION]Ïðåäñòàâèòåëüíîå ïðàâëåíèå[\LINK] äîáàâëÿåò ïî òðè åäèíèöû íà ñïåöèàëèñòà ê òåìïàì èññëåäîâàíèé. Ïîñêîëüêó ýôôåêòû ïàðàäèãì ñêëàäûâàþòñÿ, ïðè äîëæíîì óñåðäèè ìîæíî ïîëó÷èòü âåñüìà ìîùíûõ ñïåöèàëèñòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Specialists[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]When a [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK] is first founded, all of its citizens are bound in the various requirements of day-to-day survival: hunting, fishing, tilling the land, and so forth. This may continue for some time, but eventually the city may grow large and prosperous enough that it can afford to dedicate some of its population to more rewarding pursuits. In Civilization IV, these more useful citizens are called "Specialists."[PARAGRAPH:2]There are six categories of specialists in Civilization IV: Engineer, Merchant, Scientist, Artist, Priest, and the default "Citizen" specialist. Each provides a city certain benefits.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Requirements for Employing Specialists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]At the start of the game, you may only create one kind of specialist: the Citizen, who is the least useful of all of them. Each of the other specialist types requires certain [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] or [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] to be created. Further, each building or wonder will allow a limited number of specialists. For example, building a Temple allows you to create one (and only one) Priest in its city. But if you subsequently build a Cathedral there, you can create an additional two priests, for a total of three.[PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CIVIC_CASTE_SYSTEM]Caste System[\LINK] civic allows you to create as many Merchant, Scientist, and Artist specialists in a city as you desire, regardless of whether or not you have the buildings that would normally be needed to create them. Be aware, however, that there is no way to get around the limitation on the number of Engineers and Priests that a city can support; you must have either the buildings or wonders necessary to create these specialists.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Turning City Population into Specialists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When a city increases its population, it first seeks to employ that new population working the land around the city. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK].) If any land spaces are yet unworked, the city puts the new civilian on the space it thinks will do the most good. A city can work up to 20 spaces - fewer if the city contains deserts or peaks in its [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City Radius[\LINK]. If you turn one of those working populations into a specialist, it no longer works the land. It still must eat, however, so the city's remaining working population must provide enough food for everybody. If not, the city will begin to starve. As a general rule, therefore, cities with more food will be able to create more specialists; cities that are food-poor will need all of their citizens to work the land just to prevent starvation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once a city is working all available land, it automatically turns any additional population into specialists (keep in mind this usually will not take place until very late in the game!). It attempts to create the most useful specialist available; if no other slots are open, it creates a citizen specialist. You can also manually create specialists yourself by removing citizens from working the land (see below). When a city is about to grow past the level of [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]Happiness[\LINK] that it can support, it is often a good idea to turn some of the population into specialists and halt growth rather than let the city increase in size and produce useless unhappy citizens.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Specialists and Great People[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to their other functions described below, specialists increase a city's generation of "Great People Points" by +3 each. Specialists also help determine what kind of great person the city will generate. See [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]How to Create a Specialist[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can create a specialist on the city screen. The six types are visible on the right-hand edge of the screen. If a specialist type is grayed-out, you cannot build one. If a specialist is in full color, however, you can: click on the plus (+) sign next to the specialist you want to create. If you want to remove a specialist, click on the minus (-) sign. Creating a specialist removes one of your population points from working a tile in the City Radius.[PARAGRAPH:2]In order to manually select which tile to remove, first click on the tile that you want removed (the white circle around it should disappear). This creates a Citizen specialist. Then click on the plus (+) sign next to the specialist you want to employ, and the Citizen specialist will be replaced with the one you desire.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note that some [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] automatically give you one or more specialists of a specific type; you can't remove or repurpose them at all. Some wonders and civics may also provide you with a free specialist in each city; in this case, you can choose which specialist to employ in each city, but cannot remove the specialist altogether.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Specialist Types[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Engineer[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Engineers increase a city's production by +2. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Engineer. [LINK=BUILDING_FORGE]Forges[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_FACTORY]Factories[\LINK], and similar industrial buildings are needed to create Engineers.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Merchant[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Merchants increase gold by +3. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Merchant. [LINK=BUILDING_MARKET]Markets[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_BANK]Banks[\LINK], and similar commercial buildings are needed to create Merchants.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Scientist[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Scientists increase a city's research rate by +3. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Scientist. [LINK=BUILDING_LIBRARY]Libraries[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]Universities[\LINK], and similar research institutions are needed to create Scientists.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Artist[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Artists increase a city's gold by +1, and its culture by +4. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Artist. [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]Theatres[\LINK] and other centers of the arts are needed to create Artists.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Priest[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Priests increase a city's commerce and production by +1 each. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Prophet. Temples, Cathedrals, and other religious buildings are needed to create Priests.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Citizen[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Citizens increase a city's production by +1. They do not provide great person generation points, nor do they affect what kind of great person the city generates. Citizens require the construction of no buildings or wonders, and an unlimited number can always be employed. However, it is rarely worthwhile to create large numbers of Citizen specialists![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Wonders and Civics[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Many wonders and civics can increase the power of specialists even further, with a variety of different effects.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Increased Great Person Points[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Several different wonders and civics increase the rate at which specialists create Great People. The [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] wonder increases the production of great person points by 50%% in all cities, and the [LINK=BUILDING_NATIONAL_EPIC]National Epic[\LINK] national wonder increases the rate by 100%% in the city in which it is built. The [LINK=CIVIC_PACIFISM]Pacifism[\LINK] civic also increases great person generation by 100%% in all cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Other Effects[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Other effects include increasing the output of the specialists themselves. For example, the [LINK=BUILDING_ANGKOR_WAT]Angkor Wat[\LINK] wonder adds +1 production to all Priest specialists, and the [LINK=BUILDING_SISTINE_CHAPEL]Sistine Chapel[\LINK] adds +2 culture to all specialists. The [LINK=CIVIC_REPRESENTATION]Representation[\LINK] civic also adds +3 research to all specialists. Since all of these effects are cumulative, specialists can become very powerful if enough attention is paid to them.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Øïèîíû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Øïèîíû - òèï "íåâèäèìûõ" þíèòîâ ñ îñîáûìè âîçìîæíîñòÿìè. Îíè íåçàìåòíî áðîäÿò ïî êàðòå, à òàêæå âûïîëíÿþò çàùèòíóþ ôóíêöèþ: ïîìîãàþò âûÿâëÿòü âðàæåñêèõ øïèîíîâ, åñëè òå çàòåâàþò äèâåðñèþ íà ñîñåäíèõ êëåòêàõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñîçäàíèå øïèîíîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Øïèîíû ñîçäàþòñÿ òîëüêî â ãîðîäàõ, ãäå èìååòñÿ ìàëîå ÷óäî ñâåòà [LINK=BUILDING_SCOTLAND_YARD]Ñêîòëàíä-ßðä[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Íåâèäèìîñòü[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèòû-øïèîíû íåâèäèìû è íåäîñòóïíû, íà íèõ íåëüçÿ íàïàñòü.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Äâèæåíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Øïèîíû ïåðåìåùàþòñÿ êàê îáû÷íûå þíèòû, íî ïåðåõîäÿò ÷óæèå [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]ãðàíèöû[\LINK], íå âûçûâàÿ âîéíû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Çàäàíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Øïèîíû âûïîëíÿþò ðÿä çàäàíèé, èç êîòîðûõ îäíè çàêàí÷èâàþòñÿ ïîòåðåé þíèòà, à äðóãèå ÷ðåâàòû ðèñêîì. Çàäàíèÿ ìîãóò âûïîëíÿòüñÿ â ëþáîé òî÷êå êàðòû, âêëþ÷àÿ âëàäåíèÿ ñîþçíèêîâ è âðàæåñêèé òûë âî âðåìÿ âîéíû. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Èññëåäîâàíèå òåððèòîðèè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîñêîëüêó øïèîíû íåâèäèìû, îíè ìîãóò ñâîáîäíî õîäèòü ïî ñîþçíîé, íåéòðàëüíîé è âðàæåñêîé òåððèòîðèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Èçó÷åíèå ãîðîäà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Çàéäÿ â ÷óæîé ãîðîä, øïèîí ìîæåò çàãëÿíóòü íà åãî ïàíåëü è óçíàòü ìíîãî ñóùåñòâåííîãî: íàïðèìåð, êàêèå òàì óêðåïëåíèÿ è ÷òî ñòðîèòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äèâåðñèÿ íà ïðîèçâîäñòâå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îñóùåñòâëÿåòñÿ â ãîðîäå. Â ñëó÷àå óñïåõà øïèîí îñòàåòñÿ æèâ, à òî, ÷òî â äàííûé ìîìåíò ñòðîèòñÿ â ãîðîäå, òåðÿåò ïîëîâèíó åäèíèö ïðîäóêöèè. Óäàð ìîæåò îêàçàòüñÿ âåñüìà ñåðüåçíûì, åñëè ãîðîäó, ñêàæåì, îñòàâàëàñü ïàðà õîäîâ äî ïîñòðîéêè ÷óäà ñâåòà. Â ñëó÷àå íåóäà÷è øïèîí ãèáíåò, à ïðîäóêöèÿ íå ïîâðåæäàåòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äèâåðñèÿ íà îáúåêòå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îñóùåñòâëÿåòñÿ íà ëþáîé êëåòêå ñ [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]îáúåêòîì[\LINK]. Â ñëó÷àå óñïåõà îáúåêò óíè÷òîæàåòñÿ, à øïèîí îñòàåòñÿ æèâ. Â ñëó÷àå íåóäà÷è øïèîí ãèáíåò, à îáúåêò íå ïîâðåæäàåòñÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Êðàæà ïëàíîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ýòî çàäàíèå áîëüøå øàíñîâ âûïîëíèòü â îäíîì èç àäìèíèñòðàòèâíûõ öåíòðîâ - â ãîðîäå, ãäå ðàñïîëîæåí [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]äâîðåö[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_FORBIDDEN_PALACE]Çàïðåòíûé ãîðîä[\LINK] èëè [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Âåðñàëü[\LINK]. Â ñëó÷àå óñïåõà øïèîí îñòàåòñÿ æèâ, à âàì ñòàíîâèòñÿ âèäíî âñå, ÷òî íàõîäèòñÿ â ïîëå çðåíèÿ îãðàáëåííîé äåðæàâû: åãî âëàäåíèÿ è ìåñòíîñòü â ïðåäåëàõ âèäèìîñòè åãî ãðàíèö è þíèòîâ. Â ñëó÷àå íåóäà÷è øïèîí ãèáíåò, íå äàâàÿ èíôîðìàöèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Îò ÷åãî çàâèñèò óñïåõ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âåðîÿòíîñòü òîãî, ÷òî øïèîí óñïåøíî âûïîëíèò çàäàíèå íà íåêîòîðîé êëåòêå, çàâèñèò îò òîãî, ñêîëüêî ÷óæèõ þíèòîâ òàì íàõîäèòñÿ. Åñëè êëåòêà ïóñòà, øàíñû âåñüìà íåïëîõè, íî ñ êàæäûì ñëåäóþùèì þíèòîì âîçðàñòàåò îïàñíîñòü ïðîâàëà. Åùå áîëüøå ðèñê, åñëè ðÿäîì åñòü âðàæåñêèå øïèîíû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âëèÿíèå íà ìåæäóíàðîäíóþ îáñòàíîâêó[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â ñëó÷àå óñïåõà ïîñòðàäàâøàÿ äåðæàâà íå áóäåò çíàòü, êòî ïðèñëàë øïèîíà, è ïîýòîìó íå ñìîæåò âàñ îáâèíÿòü (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Ïåðåãîâîðû[\LINK]). Åñëè æå øïèîí áóäåò ðàñêðûò, ïîñòðàäàâøèå èçìåíÿò î âàñ ìíåíèå, è íå â ëó÷øóþ ñòîðîíó. Øïèîíñêèé ñêàíäàë âïîëíå ìîæåò ñòàòü äàæå ïðè÷èíîé âîéíû![PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Spies[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies are special "invisible" units which can sneak around the map and have a variety of special abilities. Spies also function defensively by increasing the odds of an enemy spy being exposed if it performs a mission in a nearby tiles.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Constructing Spies[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies may be built only in a city with the [LINK=BUILDING_SCOTLAND_YARD]Scotland Yard[\LINK] national wonder.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Invisible[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spy units are invisible. They cannot be seen, attacked, or otherwise interacted with.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies move like other units, except that they do not cause an automatic declaration of war when crossing foreign [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Spy Missions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies may perform a variety of missions, some of which are automatically fatal and others of which contain a chance of destruction. Spies can perform these missions anywhere on the map, including in territory belonging to allies or to civilizations you are at war with.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Exploration[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Being invisible, spies can move through neutral, friendly and enemy territory without risk.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Investigate City[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Upon entering a foreign city, a spy may look at it's City Screen and thus know important things, like what defenses the city contains, what it is currently building, and so forth.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Destroy Production[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A spy performs this in a city. If successful, the spy survives and the city loses half of the production points towards whatever it is currently producing. For example, this can be quite devastating if the city is just a couple of turns from completing construction of a wonder. If the mission is unsuccessful, no production is lost and the spy is destroyed.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Sabotage Improvement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This is performed on any space containing an [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvement[\LINK]. If successful, the improvement is destroyed and the spy survives. If unsuccessful, the spy is destroyed and the improvement survives.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Steal Plans[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This mission has a much higher chance of success in one of a civilization's "centers of government" - a city containing the [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]Palace[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_GREAT_PALACE]Forbidden Palace[\LINK] or [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles[\LINK] wonder. If successful, the spy survives and you get to see everything that is visible to the foreign civilization. This includes everything in its territory or within sight of its units and borders. If unsuccessful, the spy dies and you don't get to see anything.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Determining Success or Failure of a Spy Mission[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The odds of success or failure of a spy's mission depend upon the number of units the other player has in the space the mission takes place. If a space is unoccupied, the chances of success are quite high. The chances of detection and failure increase with each unit in the target space. Further, nearby enemy spies significantly increase the chances of being caught.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Diplomatic Effects of Missions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If a mission is successful, the target civilization will not know who performed the mission; thus that civilization's opinion of you will not change (see [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK]). If the mission is a failure, the target civilization will know exactly who is responsible for the outrage and will adjust its opinion of you appropriately. It is quite possible for a failed spy mission to cause the victim civilization to declare war on your civilization![PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Òåõíîëîãèè[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïî ñâîèì ôèçè÷åñêèì äàííûì ÷åëîâåê ïðîèãðûâàåò áîëüøèíñòâó æèâîòíûõ - îäíèì â ñèëå è ëîâêîñòè, äðóãèì â îñòðîì ÷óòüå èëè ñëóõå, òðåòüèì â ìîùè êëûêîâ è êîãòåé. Íî íè îäíî ñóùåñòâî íå ñðàâíèòñÿ ñ ëþäüìè â òåõíîëîãèè: â óìåíèè, èçó÷èâ ñðåäó, ñîçäàâàòü ïîëåçíûå ïðèñïîñîáëåíèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Âîçüìåì, ê ïðèìåðó, êîëåñî. Ìíîãèå æèâîòíûå - ñêàæåì, ãîðíûå êîçû, - íàâåðíÿêà îòëè÷íî çíàþò, ÷òî êðóãëûå êàìíè êàòÿòñÿ ëó÷øå, ÷åì ïëîñêèå. Íî êîçû äåëàþò èç ýòîãî òîëüêî îäèí âûâîä: íå ïðûãàé íà êðóãëûé êàìåíü - øåþ ñâåðíåøü. ×åëîâåê æå, íàïðîòèâ, èçâëåê îòñþäà íåìàëóþ âûãîäó: èçîáðåë êîëåñî.[PARAGRAPH:2]Â èãðå Civilization IV áîëåå 80 òåõíîëîãèé, è êàæäàÿ îòðàæàåò âàæíûé øàã â ïîêîðåíèè ïðèðîäû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Íîâûå òåõíîëîãèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â íà÷àëå èãðû âñå äåðæàâû âëàäåþò íåñêîëüêèìè ïðîñòåéøèìè òåõíîëîãèÿìè, êàæäàÿ ñâîèìè - êîìó-òî çíàêîìû [LINK=TECH_THE_WHEEL]êîëåñî[\LINK] è [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]çåìëåäåëèå[\LINK], êîìó-òî - [LINK=TECH_MYSTICISM]ìèñòèöèçì[\LINK] è [LINK=TECH_FISHING]ðûáíàÿ ëîâëÿ[\LINK]. Åñòü íåñêîëüêî èñòî÷íèêîâ íîâûõ òåõíîëîãèé:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äðóæåñòâåííûå äåðåâíè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Èññëåäóÿ[\LINK] ìèð, âàøè þíèòû ìîãóò íàáðåñòè íà òóçåìíûå äåðåâíè. Íà íèõ òàì ëèáî íàïàäóò, ëèáî ïîäàðÿò êàðòû, çîëîòî èëè êàêóþ-íèáóäü òåõíîëîãèþ. Ñ èññëåäîâàíèÿìè íàäî ñïåøèòü: òóçåìíûõ äåðåâåíü íà êàðòå ìàëî, è òóäà ñòðåìÿòñÿ âñå äåðæàâû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïåðåãîâîðû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïî õîäó èãðû ïîÿâèòñÿ âîçìîæíîñòü âûìåíèâàòü òåõíîëîãèè ó äðóãèõ äåðæàâ. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Ïåðåãîâîðû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Èññëåäîâàíèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Íîâûå òåõíîëîãèè ìîæíî èçîáðåòàòü ñàìîñòîÿòåëüíî, âåäÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]èññëåäîâàíèÿ[\LINK]. Ýòî íàèáîëåå îáû÷íûé ñïîñîá. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. â ñîîòâåòñòâóþùåì ðàçäåëå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âûáîð òåõíîëîãèé [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êîãäà èññëåäîâàíèå çàâåðøèëîñü, ïîäàðèâ âàì íîâóþ òåõíîëîãèþ, ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ ìåíþ, â êîòîðîì íàäî âûáðàòü, íà ÷òî íàïðàâèòü èññëåäîâàíèÿ äàëüøå. Â íåì áóäåò ñïèñîê âñåõ òåõíîëîãèé, äîñòóïíûõ íà äàííûé ìîìåíò. Ìíîãèå íåëüçÿ îñâîèòü áåç äðóãèõ òåõíîëîãèé; íàïðèìåð, [LINK=TECH_ANIMAL_HUSBANDRY]æèâîòíîâîäñòâî[\LINK] íåîáõîäèìî, ÷òîáû îâëàäåòü [LINK=TECH_HORSEBACK_RIDING]âåðõîâîé åçäîé[\LINK] è ïîëó÷èòü ìîùíûé è áûñòðûé òèï þíèòîâ - [LINK=UNIT_HORSE_ARCHER]êîííûõ ëó÷íèêîâ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]Åñòü òåõíîëîãèè, îñíîâàííûå íà íåñêîëüêèõ ñðàçó; ó äðóãèõ íåñêîëüêî âàðèàíòîâ îòïðàâíîé òî÷êè. Ê ïåðâîé ãðóïïå îòíîñèòñÿ [LINK=TECH_MONOTHEISM]ìîíîòåèçì[\LINK], äëÿ êîòîðîãî íåîáõîäèìî ñî÷åòàíèå [LINK=TECH_POLYTHEISM]ïîëèòåèçìà[\LINK] è [LINK=TECH_MASONRY]êàìåííîé êëàäêè[\LINK], êî âòîðîé ãðóïïå - [LINK=TECH_ANIMAL_HUSBANDRY]æèâîòíîâîäñòâî[\LINK], äëÿ êîòîðîãî äîñòàòî÷íî ëèáî îäíîé [LINK=TECH_HUNTING]îõîòû[\LINK], ëèáî îäíîãî [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]çåìëåäåëèÿ[\LINK]. Â ñïèñêå íå áóäåò òåõíîëîãèé, äëÿ êîòîðûõ åùå íå îñâîåíû èñõîäíûå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äåðåâî òåõíîëîãèé[\BOLD]: Âñå òåõíîëîãèè â èõ âçàèìîñâÿçè ïðåäñòàâëåíû â âèäå óäîáíîé ñõåìû - Äåðåâà òåõíîëîãèé (F6). Äåðåâî ïîçâîëÿåò âûáðàòü íàïðàâëåíèå èññëåäîâàíèé èëè óòî÷íèòü ïóòü ê òåõíîëîãèè, êîòîðàÿ ïîêà íåäîñòóïíà (äëÿ ýòîãî åå íàäî ùåëêíóòü, è àâòîìàòè÷åñêè áóäåò âûáðàí êðàò÷àéøèé ìàðøðóò ê íåé).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïðîäîëæèòåëüíîñòü èññëåäîâàíèé[\BOLD]. Íà îñâîåíèå êàæäîé òåõíîëîãèè òðàòèòñÿ îïðåäåëåííîå êîëè÷åñòâî åäèíèö èññëåäîâàíèÿ. Â ìåíþ âûáîðà äëÿ êàæäîé òåõíîëîãèè óêàçàíî, ñêîëüêî õîäîâ íà íåå óéäåò ïðè òåêóùåé ñêîðîñòè èññëåäîâàíèé. Î òîì, êàê ïîâûñèòü ýòó ñêîðîñòü è áûñòðåå ïîëó÷àòü íîâûå òåõíîëîãèè ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Èññëåäîâàíèÿ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñìåíà íàïðàâëåíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íàïðàâëåíèå èññëåäîâàíèé ìîæíî â ëþáîé ìîìåíò èçìåíèòü. Äëÿ ýòîãî ùåëêíèòå øêàëó èññëåäîâàíèé ââåðõó îñíîâíîãî ýêðàíà èëè îòêðîéòå Äåðåâî òåõíîëîãèé (ñì. âûøå) è âûáåðèòå â íåì äðóãóþ òåõíîëîãèþ. Â îòëè÷èå îò ïðåäûäóùèõ èãð ñåðèè Civilization, íàïðàâëåíèå èññëåäîâàíèé ìîæíî ìåíÿòü, íè÷åãî íå òåðÿÿ. Ìîæíî îñâîèòü îäíó òåõíîëîãèþ íàïîëîâèíó, ïåðåêëþ÷èòüñÿ íà äðóãóþ, îñâîèòü åå ïîëíîñòüþ, à ïîòîì âåðíóòüñÿ è ïðîäîëæèòü ðàáîòó íàä ïåðâîé.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ôóíêöèè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Òåõíîëîãèè - î÷åíü ïîëåçíàÿ âåùü: îíè ïîçâîëÿþò ñîçäàâàòü íîâûå þíèòû, çäàíèÿ è ÷óäåñà ñâåòà, ìåíÿòü ïàðàäèãìû, îòêðûâàòü íîâûå ðåëèãèè, îáìåíèâàòüñÿ ñ äðóãèìè äåðæàâàìè è òàê äàëåå. Ïåðâîîòêðûâàòåëü íåêîòîðûõ òåõíîëîãèé ïîëó÷àåò îñîáûå áëàãà. Ó÷òèòå, ÷òî ñ îñâîåíèåì òîé èëè èíîé òåõíîëîãèè ìîæåò óñòàðåòü ÷àñòü [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]÷óäåñ ñâåòà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Technology[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Judged strictly upon his physical capabilities, man is not a particularly well-designed animal. Other animals are faster and stronger, others have keener senses, and others are far better equipped for combat. None, however, is as good as man at "technology" - the ability to create practical applications based upon knowledge of his environment.[PARAGRAPH:2]Take the wheel, for example. Many creatures - mountain goats, for instance - are probably well aware that round rocks move more easily than do flat ones. But beyond figuring out that leaping onto round rocks is a good way to break their neck, goats have not otherwise exploited that knowledge. Man, on the other hand, figured out a way to use that knowledge to his great advantage: he created the technology of the wheel.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are over 80 technologies available in Civilization IV, each representing an important advance in mankind's ability to manipulate the environment.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Acquiring Technology[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Each civilization begins the game with knowledge of several primitive technologies. This list varies from civilization to civilization: one may know [LINK=TECH_THE_WHEEL]The Wheel[\LINK] and [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]Agriculture[\LINK], while another may know [LINK=TECH_MYSTICISM]Mysticism[\LINK] and [LINK=TECH_FISHING]Fishing[\LINK]. Beyond the known technologies, there are a number of ways to acquire new ones:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Friendly Villages[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]As your units [LINK=CONCEPT_EXPLORATION]Explore[\LINK] the world, they may encounter tribal villages. These villages may attack your explorers, or they may give them maps, money, or new technology. You need to find them quickly, however; there are only a limited number of tribal villages on the map, and all civilizations want them.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomacy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]As the game progresses, you will be able to acquire technologies from other civilizations through trade. See [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK] for details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Research[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You can discover new technologies on your own, through [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Research[\LINK]. This is the most common way to acquire technologies. See that section for details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Choosing Techs to Research[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When you have completed research and learned a new technology, the "choose a technology" menu appears and you must choose another technology to begin researching. At that time the game will provide a list of available technologies for you to choose from. Many techs have "prerequisite technologies" that you must know before you can learn the new technology - for instance, you need to know the [LINK=TECH_ANIMAL_HUSBANDRY]Animal Husbandry[\LINK] tech before you can study [LINK=TECH_HORSEBACK_RIDING]Horseback Riding[\LINK] and get the versatile [LINK=UNIT_HORSE_ARCHER]Horse Archer[\LINK] units.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some technologies may have multiple prerequisites to begin researching them; other technologies require one tech OR another tech to research. [LINK=TECH_MONOTHEISM]Monotheism[\LINK] is an example of the first group; it requires [LINK=TECH_POLYTHEISM]Polytheism[\LINK] AND [LINK=TECH_MASONRY]Masonry[\LINK]. [LINK=TECH_ANIMAL_HUSBANDRY]Animal Husbandry[\LINK] is an example of the second group; it requires [LINK=TECH_HUNTING]Hunting[\LINK] OR [LINK=TECH_AGRICULTURE]Agriculture[\LINK], but not both. A tech will appear on your list only when you have learned the necessary prerequisite technologies.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The Tech Tree[\BOLD]: The extremely useful Technology Tree (F6) displays all of the technologies in the game and how they are interrelated. You can select which tech to research from the tree, or choose a research path by clicking on a tech that you want which is not currently available to be researched. The game will choose the shortest possible path to reach the tech you have selected.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Time to Research[\BOLD]: Each technology requires a certain number of "research points" to learn. The "choose a technology" screen lists the number of turns it will take to learn each technology - at your CURRENT research rate. See [LINK=CONCEPT_RESEARCH]Research[\LINK] to learn how to increase your research rate and thus shorten the time it takes to learn new technologies.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Changing Research[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You are free to change what your civilization is researching at any point in time. You can do this by clicking on the research bar at the top of the main game screen, or by opening up the Tech Tree (see above) and selecting a different tech there. Unlike previous Civilization games, there is no penalty for changing research paths. You can research half of one technology, change to a second technology and finish it, then return to the first one and pick up right where you left off before.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Technology[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Technologies allow you to do cool stuff: build new units, wonders and buildings, change your civics, discover a new religion, trade different stuff with other civilizations, and so forth. Some techs give special bonuses to the civilization that first discovers them. Note that some techs render some [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] obsolete.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ëàíäøàôò[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìèð â èãðå Civilization IV ñîñòîèò èç âîäíûõ êëåòîê è êëåòîê ñóøè. Êàæäàÿ êëåòêà îòíîñèòñÿ ê îäíîìó èç òèïîâ ëàíäøàôòà - ïóñòûíÿ, õîëìû, ðàâíèíû, ïîáåðåæüå, ìîðå è ò.ï. Íà íåé ìîãóò òàêæå íàõîäèòüñÿ äîïîëíèòåëüíûå ýëåìåíòû: ëåñà, äæóíãëè, îàçèñû è ïðî÷åå. Ïî êðàþ íåêîòîðûõ êëåòîê ïðîòåêàþò ðåêè. Îò âñåãî ýòîãî çàâèñèò, íàñêîëüêî óäîáíî ñòðîèòü íà äàííîé êëåòêå ãîðîä, òàêæå íàñêîëüêî ëåãêî ïî íåé ïåðåäâèãàòüñÿ è, êîíå÷íî, êàê òàì áóäóò âåñòèñü áîè. Íèæå ïîêàçàíî âëèÿíèå ëàíäøàôòà íà âñå àñïåêòû èãðû.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñóøà è ìîðå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âñå êëåòêè äåëÿòñÿ íà âîäó è ñóøó. Ìîðñêèå þíèòû íå ìîãóò çàõîäèòü íà ñóøó (êðîìå ïîðòîâ), à ñóõîïóòíûå - â âîäó (èõ ïåðåâîçèò [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]âîäíûé òðàíñïîðò[\LINK]). Þíèòû, ñïîñîáíûå çàõîäèòü íà êëåòêè îáîèõ òèïîâ, åñòü â àâèàöèè (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Àâèàöèÿ[\LINK]) .[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ëàíäøàôò è äâèæåíèå [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íåêîòîðûå âèäû ëàíäøàôòà çàìåäëÿþò ïåðåìåùåíèå. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Äâèæåíèå[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ëàíäøàôò è áîé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Íà îòêðûòîé ìåñòíîñòè äâà þíèòà ñõîäÿòñÿ ñî ñâîåé îáû÷íîé [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]áîåâîé ìîùüþ[\LINK], à íåêîòîðûå ëàíäøàôòû ïîìîãàþò îáîðîíÿþùèìñÿ. Òàê, áîëüøèíñòâî þíèòîâ ïîëó÷àþò áîíóñ ê çàùèòå, íàõîäÿñü íà õîëìàõ èëè â ëåñó. Áîíóñ - ýòî âðåìåííàÿ, íà òåêóùèé áîé, ïðèáàâêà ê ñèëå îáîðîíÿþùåãîñÿ. Íàïðèìåð, ïèêèíåð ñ ìàêñèìàëüíîé ñèëîé (ðàâíîé 4), íà êîòîðîãî íàïàëè â ëåñó, ïîëó÷àåò áîíóñ ê çàùèòå â 25%, òàê ÷òî â ýòîì áîþ åãî ñèëà óâåëè÷èâàåòñÿ äî 5. Íî åñëè áû åìó ñàìîìó ïðèøëîñü íàïàäàòü, ëåñ áû åìó íå ïîìîã: áîíóñ ïîëó÷àåò ëèøü òîò, êòî çàùèùàåòñÿ. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Áîé[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Õîçÿéñòâåííàÿ öåííîñòü ëàíäøàôòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ãîðîäà êîðìÿòñÿ çà ñ÷åò êëåòîê, íà êîòîðûõ îíè ðàñïîëîæåíû, è ïðèëåãàþùåé ìåñòíîñòè, ïîëó÷àÿ îò êàæäîãî òèïà è ýëåìåíòà ëàíäøàôòà îïðåäåëåííûé îáúåì [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]ïèùè[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]äåíåã[\LINK] è [LINK=CONCEPT_PRODUCTION]ïðîäóêöèè[\LINK]; ÷åì áîëüøå ýòîò îáúåì, òåì ëó÷øå äëÿ ãîðîäà. Êðîìå òîãî, öåííîñòü êëåòêè ïîâûøàþò [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñû[\LINK] è ñîçäàííûå ðàáîòíèêàìè [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]îáúåêòû[\LINK]. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Ãîðîäà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðåêè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ðåêè, â îòëè÷èå îò äðóãèõ ýëåìåíòîâ ëàíäøàôòà, òåêóò íå ïî êëåòêàì, à ìåæäó íèìè è âëèÿþò íà âñå ïðèëåãàþùèå êëåòêè. ×åðåç ðåêó íåëüçÿ ïðîâåñòè äîðîãó, ïîêà íåò òåõíîëîãèè [LINK=TECH_CONSTRUCTION]Êîíñòðóèðîâàíèå[\LINK]. Â áîþ ïðè àòàêå ÷åðåç ðåêó óìåíüøàåòñÿ ñèëà íàïàäàþùåãî. Êðîìå òîãî, êëåòêè ïî áåðåãàì ðåê èìåþò áîëåå âûñîêóþ öåííîñòü ñ òî÷êè çðåíèÿ êîììåðöèè.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Terrain[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, the world is made up of land and water "squares." Each square is designated as a specific "terrain type": for example, desert, hills, plains, coast, ocean, etc. Each may contain additional "features": forest, jungle, oasis, and so forth. A river may run along the edge of the square as well. All of these elements help determine the usefulness of the square as a place to build a city, as well as how easy or difficult it is to move through the square. And, of course, terrain may have important effects on any combat taking place in a square. The charts below display all of the effects of terrain on the game.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Land and Sea[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]All squares are either land or water squares. Water units cannot enter land spaces (except for coastal cities), and land units cannot enter water squares (unless carried aboard [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]Transport Vessels[\LINK]). Some air units can enter both types. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Air Units[\LINK] for details on air units.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Terrain Effects on Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Some terrain is more difficult to move through than others. See [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Movement[\LINK] for details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Combat Effects of Terrain[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When two units fight each other in open terrain, both fight at their standard [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat Strength[\LINK]. Some terrain gives benefits to the defender - for example, most units get "defensive bonuses" when they are occupying hills or forests. Such bonuses serve to temporarily increase the defender's strength for that battle. For example, a spearman at full strength (with a strength of 4) who is attacked while in a forest, gets a 25%% defensive bonus; for that battle, his strength is increased to 5. However, if that spearman were to attack, he would get no bonus from the forest - defensive bonuses only go to the defender. See the [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat[\LINK] entry for more information.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Terrain Productivity[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Cities draw sustenance from the squares they occupy, and from nearby surrounding squares. Each terrain-type and feature provides a certain amount of [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]Food[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_COMMERCE]Commerce[\LINK], and [LINK=CONCEPT_PRODUCTION]Production[\LINK] to cities; the higher these values, the better for the city. Note that [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK] will further increase a square's value, as will various worker [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvements[\LINK]. See [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Rivers[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Unlike other terrain features, rivers run alongside land squares, not in them. Rivers can affect all squares they run adjacent to. Rivers negate the movement benefit of roads until you acquire the [LINK=TECH_CONSTRUCTION]Construction[\LINK] technology. Rivers also reduce an attacker's combat strength when the target is on the other side of the river. Rivers improve the commerce value of adjacent squares as well.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Òîðãîâëÿ è îáìåí[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñ äðóãèìè äåðæàâàìè ìîæíî îáìåíèâàòüñÿ ìàññîé ïîëåçíûõ âåùåé: [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñàìè[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]òåõíîëîãèÿìè[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]çîëîòîì[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_MAPS]êàðòàìè[\LINK] è äàæå [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîäàìè[\LINK]. Íåâîçìîæåí îáìåí ñ äåðæàâàìè, ñ êîòîðûìè íå áûëî êîíòàêòîâ; íåêîòîðûìè âåùàìè íåëüçÿ îáìåíèâàòüñÿ, íå çíàÿ îïðåäåëåííûõ òåõíîëîãèé. Ïîäðîáíåå îá îáìåíå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Ïåðåãîâîðû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Trade[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]You can trade a number of useful things with other civilizations: [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technologies[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Gold[\LINK], [LINK=CONCEPT_MAPS]Maps[\LINK], and even [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK]. You can only trade with civilizations that you have met, and you need certain technologies in order to trade certain items. See [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK] for detailed information on trade.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Âîäíûé òðàíñïîðò[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Íå âñÿ ñóøà â ìèðå ñîîáùàåòñÿ. Îñòðîâà è ìàòåðèêè áûâàþò ðàçäåëåíû êèëîìåòðàìè âîäû, à ñóõîïóòíûå þíèòû, ñàìî ñîáîé, ïî âîäå íå ïåðåìåùàþòñÿ. Èì íóæåí âîäíûé òðàíñïîðò.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âèäû âîäíîãî òðàíñïîðòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ê âîäíîìó òðàíñïîðòó îòíîñÿòñÿ øåñòü òèïîâ þíèòîâ. Íåêîòîðûå èç íèõ ñïîñîáíû ïåðåâîçèòü òîëüêî îïðåäåëåííûå þíèòû, äðóãèå íå ìîãóò îòîéòè îò áåðåãîâ èëè ïîêèíóòü [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]êóëüòóðíûå ãðàíèöû[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãàëåðà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñàìûé ðàííèé âèä âîäíîãî òðàíñïîðòà - [LINK=UNIT_GALLEY]ãàëåðà[\LINK]. Îíà ïåðåâîçèò íå áîëåå äâóõ ëþáûõ ñóõîïóòíûõ þíèòîâ è äåðæèòñÿ â ïðèáðåæíûõ êëåòêàõ èëè â êóëüòóðíûõ ãðàíèöàõ âàøåé äåðæàâû (à òàêæå äåðæàâ, ñ êîòîðûìè ó âàñ ñîãëàøåíèå îá [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Êàðàâåëëà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðâûé âèä âîäíîãî òðàíñïîðòà, êîòîðîìó äîñòóïíû âñå ìîðñêèå êëåòêè, [LINK=UNIT_CARAVEL]êàðàâåëëà[\LINK] ñïîñîáíà ïåðåâîçèòü îäíó [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]çíàìåíèòîñòü[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_BUDDHIST_MISSIONARY]ìèññèîíåðà[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]ðàçâåä÷èêà[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_EXPLORER]ïóòåøåñòâåííèêà[\LINK] èëè [LINK=UNIT_SPY]øïèîíà[\LINK]. Â îòëè÷èå îò áîëüøèíñòâà þíèòîâ, âîéäÿ âî âëàäåíèÿ äðóãîé äåðæàâû, êàðàâåëëà íå âûçûâàåò âîéíû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãàëåîí [\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_GALLEON]Ãàëåîí[\LINK] ïåðåâîçèò äî òðåõ ëþáûõ ñóõîïóòíûõ þíèòîâ. Åìó äîñòóïíû âñå ìîðñêèå êëåòêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Òðàíñïîðò[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]Äåñàíòíûé êîðàáëü[\LINK] ïåðåâîçèò äî ÷åòûðåõ ëþáûõ ñóõîïóòíûõ þíèòîâ. Åìó äîñòóïíû âñå ìîðñêèå êëåòêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ïîäâîäíàÿ ëîäêà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ áîëüøèíñòâà þíèòîâ [LINK=UNIT_SUBMARINE]ïîäâîäíàÿ ëîäêà[\LINK] íåâèäèìà. Îíà ìîæåò ïåðåâîçèòü îäíó [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]çíàìåíèòîñòü[\LINK], îäíîãî [LINK=UNIT_BUDDHIST_MISSIONARY]ìèññèîíåðà[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]ðàçâåä÷èêà[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_EXPLORER]ïóòåøåñòâåííèêà[\LINK] èëè [LINK=UNIT_SPY]øïèîíà[\LINK]. Äëÿ ïîäâîäíûõ ëîäîê äîñòóïíû âñå ìîðñêèå êëåòêè, à â ÷óæèõ âëàäåíèÿõ îíè íå âûçûâàþò âîéíû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Àâèàíîñåö[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_CARRIER]Àâèàíîñåö[\LINK] ìîæåò ïåðåâîçèòü òðè èñòðåáèòåëÿ, [LINK=UNIT_FIGHTER]ïðîñòûõ[\LINK] è/èëè [LINK=UNIT_JET_FIGHTER]ðåàêòèâíûõ[\LINK]. Åìó äîñòóïíû âñå âîäíûå êëåòêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîãðóçêà ñóõîïóòíûõ þíèòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè þíèò è òðàíñïîðò íàõîäÿòñÿ â îäíîì ïîðòó, âûäåëèòå þíèò è ùåëêíèòå êíîïêó äåéñòâèÿ "Ïîãðóçèòüñÿ". Åñëè òðàíñïîðò â ïðèáðåæíîé êëåòêå, ïåðåìåñòèòå òóäà þíèò, è îí ïîãðóçèòñÿ àâòîìàòè÷åñêè. Ïîãðóçêà íå ïðîèçîéäåò, åñëè òðàíñïîðò ïîëîí èëè íå ìîæåò ïåðåâîçèòü þíèòû ýòîãî òèïà. Ïîñëå ïîãðóçêè ó þíèòà íå îñòàåòñÿ åäèíèö äâèæåíèÿ äî êîíöà õîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ðàçãðóçêà òðàíñïîðòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè òðàíñïîðò íàõîäèòñÿ â ãîðîäå, ùåëêíèòå þíèò, êîòîðûé õîòèòå âûñàäèòü, è ùåëêíèòå êíîïêó äåéñòâèÿ "Âûãðóçèòüñÿ". Åñëè òðàíñïîðò â ïðèáðåæíîé êëåòêå, ìîæíî îòäàòü åìó êîìàíäó ïåðåìåñòèòüñÿ íà ñóøó, è âñå þíèòû âûñàäÿòñÿ â óêàçàííóþ êëåòêó. ×òîáû âûñàäèòü òîëüêî îäèí þíèò, âûäåëèòå åãî è ïåðåìåñòèòå íà ñîñåäíþþ êëåòêó ñóøè. Ïîñëå âûñàäêè ó þíèòà íå îñòàåòñÿ åäèíèö äâèæåíèÿ äî êîíöà õîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîãðóçêà è ðàçãðóçêà àâèàíîñöåâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]×òîáû çàãðóçèòü èñòðåáèòåëü íà àâèàíîñåö, âûäåëèòå åãî, çàòåì ùåëêíèòå àâèàíîñåö ïðàâîé êíîïêîé ìûøè. ×òîáû ñíÿòü èñòðåáèòåëü ñ àâèàíîñöà, âûäåëèòå èñòðåáèòåëü è ùåëêíèòå ïðàâîé êíîïêîé ìûøè äðóæåñòâåííûé ãîðîä.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Óíè÷òîæåíèå òðàíñïîðòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Òðàíñïîðòû, êàê è äðóãèå âîåííûå ñóäà, ñïîñîáíû âåñòè áîé. Ïåðåâîçèìûå þíèòû òîíóò âìåñòå ñ òðàíñïîðòîì. Íà áîðòó òðàíñïîðòà ñóõîïóòíûå þíèòû íå ìîãóò ñðàæàòüñÿ; èñêëþ÷åíèå - èñòðåáèòåëè ñ ñîîòâåòñòâóþùèì çàäàíèåì (ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Àâèàöèÿ[\LINK]).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïåðåâîçêà áîåâûõ âåðòîëåòîâ [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_GUNSHIP]Áîåâûå âåðòîëåòû[\LINK] íå îòëè÷àþòñÿ îò äðóãèõ ñóõîïóòíûõ þíèòîâ: èõ ìîæíî ãðóçèòü íà ãàëåðû, ãàëåîíû è äåñàíòíûå êîðàáëè. Íà àâèàíîñöàõ èõ ïåðåâîçèòü ÍÅËÜÇß.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Transport[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In the world, all land masses are not linked together. Islands and continents may be separated from each other by miles and miles of ocean. Needless to say, land units cannot walk on water: they need "naval transports" to carry them.[PARAGRAPH:2] [H2]Transport Types[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]There are six naval transport units in the game. Some may carry only specific types of units, while others may not leave the coastline or waters inside their [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Cultural Borders[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Galley[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=UNIT_GALLEY]Galley[\LINK] is the earliest transport unit. It can carry up to two land units of any type. The galley must remain in coastal spaces or spaces within your cultural borders (or within the cultural borders of civilizations you have [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Open Borders[\LINK] agreements with).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Caravel[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=UNIT_CARAVEL]Caravel[\LINK] may carry one [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Person[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_BUDDHIST_MISSIONARY]Missionary[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]Scout[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_EXPLORER]Explorer[\LINK], or [LINK=UNIT_SPY]Spy[\LINK]. The caravel is the first naval unit that can enter all ocean spaces. Unlike most units, Caravels do not trigger war when entering other civilizations' territories.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Galleon[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=UNIT_GALLEON]Galleon[\LINK] can carry three land units of any type. It can enter all ocean spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Transport[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]Transport[\LINK] can carry four land units of any type. It can enter all ocean spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Submarine[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=UNIT_SUBMARINE]Submarine[\LINK] is invisible to most units. It can carry one [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great Person[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_BUDDHIST_MISSIONARY]Missionary[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]Scout[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_EXPLORER]Explorer[\LINK], or [LINK=UNIT_SPY]Spy[\LINK]. Submarines can enter all ocean spaces. Subs do not trigger war when entering other civilizations' territories.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Aircraft Carrier[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=UNIT_CARRIER]Aircraft Carrier[\LINK] can carry three [LINK=UNIT_FIGHTER]Fighters[\LINK] and/or [LINK=UNIT_JET_FIGHTER]Jet Fighters[\LINK]. It can enter all water spaces.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Loading Land Units onto Transports[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If a unit is in a coastal city that is also occupied by a transport that can carry that unit, activate the unit and click on the "board transport" action button. If a transport is in a coastal space, direct the unit to move into the transport's space and it will load automatically. A unit will not board a transport if the transport is full or if it is not allowed aboard that type of vessel. Loading a unit onto a transport uses up any remaining movement points that unit may have had that turn.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Unloading Transports[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If a transport is in a city, click on the unit you want to unload and then click on the "exit transport" action button. If the transport is in a coastal square, you can order the transport to move onto a land square and all units aboard will exit onto that space. If you wish to unload just one of the transported units, activate the specific unit and order it to move to an adjacent land space. Unloading a unit uses up all of the unit's movement points for that turn.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Loading and Offloading Carriers[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]To load a fighter onto a carrier, activate the fighter and then right-click on the carrier. To offload a fighter from a carrier, activate the fighter and then right-click on a friendly city.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Sinking Transports[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Transports can fight like any other naval vessels. If a transport is sunk, all of the units it carries go down with the ship. Land units cannot fight when loaded aboard transports; fighters can, if given the appropriate mission (see [LINK=CONCEPT_AIR_UNITS]Air Units[\LINK] for details).[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Transporting Gunships[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_GUNSHIP]Gunships[\LINK] (combat helicopters) can be transported by galleys, galleons, and transports and are treated just like other land units. They CANNOT ride on carriers.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Êàçíà[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàçíà - ýòî êàïèòàë äåðæàâû. Åñëè åå îáúåì óïàë íèæå íóëÿ, äåðæàâà íà÷èíàåò ïðîäàâàòü þíèòû è çäàíèÿ, ÷òîáû ïîêðûòü äåôèöèò. Î ôèíàíñàõ è èõ èñïîëüçîâàíèè ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Êàïèòàë[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Treasury[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Your treasury shows how much wealth your civilization possesses. This must be a positive number or zero, or else your civilization will start selling off units and buildings to pay the costs. See [LINK=CONCEPT_WEALTH]Wealth[\LINK] for information on money and its many uses in the game.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]ÎÎÍ[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Îðãàíèçàöèÿ Îáúåäèíåííûõ Íàöèé - íåìàëîâàæíîå âåëèêîå ÷óäî ñâåòà, êîòîðîå ìîæíî ïîñòðîèòü áëèæå ê êîíöó èãðû, êîãäà ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ òåõíîëîãèÿ [LINK=TECH_MASS_MEDIA]ÑÌÈ[\LINK]. Ñ åãî ñîçäàíèåì ñòàíîâèòñÿ âîçìîæíîé [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY]äèïëîìàòè÷åñêàÿ ïîáåäà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ãîëîñîâàíèÿ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â êàêîé-íèáóäü òî÷êå ìèðà ñòðîèòñÿ ÎÎÍ, è ðàç â íåñêîëüêî õîäîâ íà÷èíàþò ïðîâîäèòüñÿ ãîëîñîâàíèÿ. Â íèõ ó÷àñòâóþò âñå äåðæàâû, êàêèå ñóùåñòâóþò íà äàííûé ìîìåíò, íåçàâèñèìî îò èõ ñèëû. ×åì ìíîãî÷èñëåííåå äåðæàâà, òåì áîëüøèì êîëè÷åñòâîì ãîëîñîâ ðàñïîëàãàåò â ÎÎÍ åå ëèäåð.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âèäû ãîëîñîâàíèé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âûáîðû ãåíåðàëüíîãî ñåêðåòàðÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïåðâîå çàñåäàíèå âñåãäà ïîñâÿùåíî âûáîðàì ãåíåðàëüíîãî ñåêðåòàðÿ (ñì. íèæå î åãî ïðàâàõ). Îäíó èç äâóõ êàíäèäàòóð âûäâèãàåò äåðæàâà, ïîñòðîèâøàÿ çäàíèå ÎÎÍ; âòîðûì êàíäèäàòîì ñòàíîâèòñÿ ëèäåð íàèáîëåå ìíîãî÷èñëåííîé èç ïðî÷èõ äåðæàâ. Âñå äåðæàâû ãîëîñóþò - ëèáî çà îäíîãî èç êàíäèäàòîâ, ëèáî âîçäåðæèâàþòñÿ. Ãåíåðàëüíûì ñåêðåòàðåì ñòàíîâèòñÿ êàíäèäàò, íàáðàâøèé áîëüøèíñòâî ãîëîñîâ (âêëþ÷àÿ âîçäåðæàâøèõñÿ); åñëè íèêòî íå íàáèðàåò áîëüøèíñòâà, ÷åðåç íåñêîëüêî õîäîâ ïðîèñõîäÿò ïîâòîðíûå âûáîðû. Ïîêà ãåíåðàëüíûé ñåêðåòàðü íå âûáðàí, ÎÎÍ íå çàíèìàåòñÿ äðóãèìè âîïðîñàìè.[PARAGRAPH:2]Âñòóïèâ â äîëæíîñòü, ãåíåðàëüíûé ñåêðåòàðü ìîæåò ñòàâèòü íà ãîëîñîâàíèå îïðåäåëåííûå ðåçîëþöèè. ×åðåç òðè çàñåäàíèÿ åãî ïåðåèçáèðàþò, è ïðîöåññ ïîâòîðÿåòñÿ. Â îòëè÷èå îò âûáîðîâ ãåíåðàëüíîãî ñåêðåòàðÿ, ãäå äîñòàòî÷íî ïðîñòîãî áîëüøèíñòâà, ðåçîëþöèè ïðèíèìàþòñÿ íå ìåíåå ÷åì 60 ïðîöåíòàìè ãîëîñîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Åäèíàÿ âàëþòà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ââåäåíèå åäèíîé ìèðîâîé âàëþòû, åñòåñòâåííî, àêòèâèçèðóåò êîììåðöèþ. Â êàæäîì ãîðîäå ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ äîïîëíèòåëüíûé òîðãîâûé ïóòü.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñâîáîäíàÿ òîðãîâëÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðèíÿòèå ýòîé ðåçîëþöèè ñíèìàåò âñå îãðàíè÷åíèÿ íà òîðãîâëþ. Íåçàâèñèìî îò äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèõ îòíîøåíèé ìåæäó äåðæàâàìè, òîðãîâûå ïóòè äåéñòâóþò, êàê åñëè áû âñå çàêëþ÷èëè äðóã ñ äðóãîì ñîãëàøåíèå îá îòêðûòûõ ãðàíèöàõ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Çàïðåò ÿäåðíîãî îðóæèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðåêðàùàåòñÿ ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèå ÿäåðíîãî îðóæèÿ: íè îäíà äåðæàâà áîëüøå íå ìîæåò åãî ïðîèçâîäèòü (õîòÿ ñóùåñòâóþùèå ðàêåòû íå èñ÷åçàþò).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âñåîáùåå èçáèðàòåëüíîå ïðàâî[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ýòà ðåçîëþöèÿ îáÿçûâàåò âñå äåðæàâû ââåñòè ïàðàäèãìó [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Âñåîáùåå èçáèðàòåëüíîå ïðàâî[\LINK], âíå çàâèñèìîñòè îò òîãî, ãîòîâû ëè îíè ê ýòîìó òåõíîëîãè÷åñêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñâîáîäà ñëîâà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ýòà ðåçîëþöèÿ îáÿçûâàåò âñå äåðæàâû ââåñòè ïàðàäèãìó [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_SPEECH]Ñâîáîäà ñëîâà[\LINK], íåçàâèñèìî îò òîãî, ãîòîâû ëè îíè ê ýòîìó òåõíîëîãè÷åñêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàâíîïðàâèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ýòà ðåçîëþöèÿ îáÿçûâàåò âñå äåðæàâû ââåñòè ïàðàäèãìó [LINK=CIVIC_EMANCIPATION]Ðàâíîïðàâèå[\LINK], íåçàâèñèìî îò òîãî, ãîòîâû ëè îíè ê ýòîìó òåõíîëîãè÷åñêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Çàùèòà îêðóæàþùåé ñðåäû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2] Ýòà ðåçîëþöèÿ îáÿçûâàåò âñå äåðæàâû ïðèíÿòü [LINK=CIVIC_ENVIRONMENTALISM]çàêîí î çàùèòå îêðóæàþùåé ñðåäû[\LINK], íåçàâèñèìî îò òîãî, ãîòîâû ëè îíè ê ýòîìó òåõíîëîãè÷åñêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñâîáîäà ñîâåñòè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2] Ýòà ðåçîëþöèÿ îáÿçûâàåò âñå äåðæàâû ââåñòè ïàðàäèãìó [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_RELIGION]Ñâîáîäà ñîâåñòè[\LINK], íåçàâèñèìî îò òîãî, ãîòîâû ëè îíè ê ýòîìó òåõíîëîãè÷åñêè.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äèïëîìàòè÷åñêàÿ ïîáåäà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ãåíåðàëüíûé ñåêðåòàðü ìîæåò òàêæå áîðîòüñÿ çà äèïëîìàòè÷åñêóþ ïîáåäó: íàáðàòü äîñòàòî÷íî ãîëîñîâ äðóãèõ äåðæàâ è ñäåëàòüñÿ áåññïîðíûì ðóêîâîäèòåëåì ÎÎÍ. Ïóñêàé çàâîåâàòåëè ñìîòðÿò è çàâèäóþò![PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]United Nations[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The United Nations is an important great wonder that can be built at the end of the game after a civilization discovers the [LINK=TECH_MASS_MEDIA]Mass Media[\LINK] technology. The construction of the United Nations opens up the possibility of a [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY]Diplomatic Victory[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Voting[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Once the United Nations has been built anywhere in the world, votes will begin being held every few turns. Every civilization that is still alive participates in these votes, regardless of how strong or weak they may be. The number of votes that a civilization receives is determined by population; the larger the population of a civilization, the more votes that its leader casts in United Nations elections.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Types of Votes[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Secretary General Elections[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The first United Nations vote will always be to determine which leader will be selected as Secretary General (see below for more information on the powers granted to the Secretary General). The civilization that builds the United Nations will always be one of the two candidates to stand for Secretary General; the other candidate for Secretary General will be the leader whose civilization has the highest population (or second-highest if that is the civilization who builds the United Nations). When voting for the Secretary General, each civilization will choose one of the two candidates to cast their votes in favor of, or can choose to abstain altogether. If one of the two candidates receives a majority of the total votes (including the civilizations who abstain), that candidate becomes the Secretary General. If there is no majority, the election is inconclusive and there will be another election for Secretary General again a few turns later. Nothing else may be accomplished until the United Nations selects a Secretary General.[PARAGRAPH:2]When a Secretary General has been chosen, he or she can choose from a list of the following resolutions to put to a vote. After three such resolutions have been voted upon, there is a new election for Secretary General, and the process repeats. Unlike the simple majority vote to determine the Secretary General, all of the following resolutions require 60 percent or greater of the total votes to be adopted.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Single Currency[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting a Single Currency for the entire globe will naturally increase trade and commerce. Every city in the world receives an extra trade route.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Free Trade[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting the Free Trade resolution removes all barriers to trade everywhere in the world. Trade routes function as though all civs have Open Borders with one another regardless of what their diplomatic situation may be.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]No Nukes[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting this resolution causes an end to the proliferation of nuclear weapons. No civilizations anywhere in the world can construct nuclear weapons (although existing nukes do not disappear).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Universal Suffrage[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting this resolution forces all civilizations to change to the civic [LINK=CIVIC_UNIVERSAL_SUFFRAGE]Universal Suffrage[\LINK], regardless of whether or not they possess the technology to do so normally.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Free Speech[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting this resolution forces all civilizations to change to the civic [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_SPEECH]Free Speech[\LINK], regardless of whether or not they possess the technology to do so normally.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Emancipation[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting this resolution forces all civilizations to change to the civic [LINK=CIVIC_EMANCIPATION]Emancipation[\LINK], regardless of whether or not they possess the technology to do so normally.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Environmentalism[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting this resolution forces all civilizations to change to the civic [LINK=CIVIC_ENVIRONMENTALISM]Environmentalism[\LINK], regardless of whether or not they possess the technology to do so normally.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Free Religion[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Adopting this resolution forces all civilizations to change to the civic [LINK=CIVIC_FREE_RELIGION]Free Religion[\LINK], regardless of whether or not they possess the technology to do so normally.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomatic Victory[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The Secretary General may also put him or herself up for a Diplomatic Victory. With enough votes from the other civilizations of the world, he or she can win the game through becoming the undisputed leader of the United Nations. Who said nice guys finish last?[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Þíèòû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñëîâîì "þíèò" â èãðå Civilization IV íàçûâàåòñÿ âñå, ÷òî äâèæåòñÿ ïî êàðòå. Áûâàþò þíèòû-âîåííûå, ðàáîòíèêè, ìèññèîíåðû, çíàìåíèòîñòè è ïðî÷èå, ïðè÷åì âîåííûõ áîëüøèíñòâî.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàðàìåòðû [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ó þíèòà äâà îñíîâíûõ ïàðàìåòðà: ñêîðîñòü äâèæåíèÿ è áîåâàÿ ìîùü.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñêîðîñòü äâèæåíèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îò ñêîðîñòè äâèæåíèÿ çàâèñèò, íàñêîëüêî áûñòðî þíèò ïåðåìåùàåòñÿ ïî êàðòå. Îáû÷íî îíà ñîñòàâëÿåò îò 1 äî 8. Åñòü þíèòû ñ íóëåâîé ñêîðîñòüþ, èõ äâèæåíèå ïîä÷èíÿåòñÿ îñîáûì ïðàâèëàì. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Äâèæåíèå[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Áîåâàÿ ìîùü[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Îò áîåâîé ìîùè çàâèñèò, íàñêîëüêî óñïåøíî þíèò ìîæåò ïðîòèâîñòîÿòü âðàæåñêîìó þíèòó. Ìîùü ñîñòàâëÿåò îò 1 äî 40, íî íà ýòî çíà÷åíèå íàêëàäûâàåòñÿ ìíîãî äîïîëíèòåëüíûõ ôàêòîðîâ (ñì. ðàçäåë [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Áîé[\LINK]). Åñòü þíèòû ñ íóëåâîé ìîùüþ, îíè ëèáî íå ñïîñîáíû ñðàæàòüñÿ, ëèáî ïîä÷èíÿþòñÿ îñîáûì ïðàâèëàì. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Áîé[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïîëó÷åíèå þíèòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñòü íåñêîëüêî èñòî÷íèêîâ þíèòîâ:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Íà÷àëî èãðû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Èãðà íà÷èíàåòñÿ íå ìåíüøå ÷åì ñ äâóìÿ þíèòàìè â âàøåì ðàñïîðÿæåíèè. Èç íèõ õîòÿ áû îäèí - ïîñåëåíåö, îñòàëüíûå - ðàáîòíèêè èëè âîåííûå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Òóçåìíûå äåðåâíè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Âîéäÿ â òóçåìíóþ äåðåâíþ, âàø þíèò ìîæåò ïîëó÷èòü åùå îäèí þíèò (èëè çîëîòî, òåõíîëîãèþ èëè îïûò, à åñëè äåðåâíÿ îêàæåòñÿ âðàæäåáíîé - ïîäâåðãíóòüñÿ íàïàäåíèþ âàðâàðîâ.)[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Çàõâàò þíèòîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_WORKER]Ðàáîòíèêè[\LINK] è [LINK=UNIT_SETTLER]ïîñåëåíöû[\LINK] ïåðåõîäÿò ê ïîáåäèòåëþ ïðè çàõâàòå èõ ãîðîäà èëè ñòîëêíóâøèñü ñ âîåííûì þíèòîì. (Âàæíàÿ äåòàëü: çàõâà÷åííûå ïîñåëåíöû ïðåâðàùàþòñÿ â ðàáîòíèêîâ).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ñîçäàíèå þíèòîâ â ãîðîäàõ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Èñòî÷íèê áîëüøèíñòâà þíèòîâ - [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]ãîðîä[\LINK], ñì. íèæå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âîçíèêíîâåíèå þíèòîâ â ãîðîäàõ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Â ãîðîäàõ àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ïîÿâëÿþòñÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]çíàìåíèòîñòè[\LINK]. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. â ñîîòâåòñòâóþùåì ðàçäåëå.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äàðû îò äðóãèõ äåðæàâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèò ìîæíî ïîëó÷èòü â äàð îò äðóãîé äåðæàâû, íî ýòî ñëó÷àåòñÿ êðàéíå ðåäêî.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ñîçäàíèå þíèòîâ â ãîðîäàõ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Êàê ãîâîðèëîñü âûøå, áîëüøèíñòâî þíèòîâ áåðóò íà÷àëî â ãîðîäàõ. Òàì æå ñîçäàþòñÿ çäàíèÿ (è äðóãèå ñïåöèàëèçèðîâàííûå îáúåêòû). Äâå âåùè íåëüçÿ ñîçäàâàòü îäíîâðåìåííî, ïîýòîìó çàëîã óñïåõà â èãðå - ïðàâèëüíî âûáèðàòü ìåæäó þíèòàìè è ïîñòðîéêàìè. Ñì. òàêæå [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Ãîðîäà[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âûáîð íîâîãî þíèòà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Êîãäà ãîðîä ãîòîâ ñîçäàòü þíèò èëè ïîñòðîéêó, ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ ïàíåëü ðàçâèòèÿ ãîðîäà. Íà íåé ïåðå÷èñëåíî, ÷òî ìîæíî ñîçäàòü è çà êàêîé ñðîê. Ñòîèò ùåëêíóòü îáúåêò, è íàä íèì íà÷íåòñÿ ðàáîòà. ×òîáû ïåðåêëþ÷èòü ãîðîä íà ñîçäàíèå ÷åãî-íèáóäü äðóãîãî, ùåëêíèòå íîâûé îáúåêò íà ïàíåëè ãîðîäà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äîñòóïíîñòü þíèòîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Íå âñå þíèòû ìîæíî ñîçäàâàòü ñ ïåðâûõ ìèíóò èãðû. Äëÿ íåêîòîðûõ òðåáóþòñÿ îïðåäåëåííûå [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]òåõíîëîãèè[\LINK] èëè [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñû[\LINK], íàïðèìåð, äëÿ [LINK=UNIT_SWORDSMAN]ìå÷íèêîâ[\LINK] - óìåíèå äåëàòü [LINK=TECH_IRON_WORKING]æåëåçíûå èçäåëèÿ[\LINK] è äîñòóï ê [LINK=BONUS_IRON]æåëåçó[\LINK]. Äðóãèå þíèòû çàâèñÿò îò [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]ïîñòðîåê[\LINK] è/èëè [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]ðåëèãèè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Âðåìÿ íà ñîçäàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Âðåìÿ íà ñîçäàíèå þíèòà çàâèñèò îò [LINK=CONCEPT_PRODUCTION]ïðîèçâîäñòâà[\LINK]. ×åì áîëüøå ïðîäóêöèè ïðîèçâîäèò ãîðîä, òåì áûñòðåå â íåì ãîòîâÿòñÿ þíèòû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàñõîäû íà ñîäåðæàíèå þíèòîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Êîëè÷åñòâî áåñïëàòíûõ þíèòîâ çàâèñèò îò óðîâíÿ ñëîæíîñòè èãðû. Êàæäûé þíèò ñâåðõ ýòîãî ÷èñëà îáõîäèòñÿ â îäíó åäèíèöó çîëîòà çà õîä. Íåêîòîðûå [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]ïàðàäèãìû[\LINK] âëèÿþò íà êîëè÷åñòâî áåñïëàòíûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ðàñõîäû íà þíèòû â ïóòè[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñíàáæåíèå è ñîäåðæàíèå þíèòîâ ñòîèò äîðîæå, êîãäà îíè çà ãðàíèöåé ñâîåé äåðæàâû. Ïîõîä ïðîòèâ ñîñåäà ñåðüåçíî îïóñòîøèò êàçíó.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âûäåëåíèå þíèòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèò, îáâåäåííûé â êðóã, "âûäåëåí" è æäåò ïðèêàçàíèé. Âñå æäóùèå þíèòû ïî î÷åðåäè âûäåëÿþòñÿ àâòîìàòè÷åñêè; òå, ó êîòîðûõ óæå åñòü çàäàíèÿ, êîìïüþòåð ïðîïóñêàåò. Ëþáîé þíèò ìîæíî âûäåëèòü âðó÷íóþ, ùåëêíóâ åãî.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïàíåëü ïðèêàçîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Âûäåëåííûé þíèò ìîæíî ïåðåìåñòèòü (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Äâèæåíèå[\LINK]) èëè çàñòàâèòü íàïàñòü íà äðóãîé þíèò (ñì. [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Áîé[\LINK]). Ïðî÷èå âàðèàíòû ïåðå÷èñëåíû íà "ïàíåëè ïðèêàçîâ" þíèòà, âíèçó â ñåðåäèíå ýêðàíà. ×òîáû îòäàòü ïðèêàç, ùåëêíèòå åãî çíà÷îê íà ýòîé ïàíåëè (äëÿ ìíîãèõ ïðèêàçîâ åñòü òàêæå ãîðÿ÷èå êëàâèøè).[PARAGRAPH:2]Èãðà ïðåäîñòàâëÿåò øèðîêèé íàáîð ïðèêàçîâ â çàâèñèìîñòè îò òèïà þíèòà, îò åãî çäîðîâüÿ, îïûòà, ìåñòîíàõîæäåíèÿ è ïðî÷åãî. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äðóãèå ïðèêàçû[\BOLD]. [LINK=UNIT_BOMBER]Áîìáàðäèðîâùèê[\LINK] ìîæíî îòïðàâèòü ÷òî-íèáóäü áîìáèòü, [LINK=UNIT_FIGHTER]èñòðåáèòåëü[\LINK] - íà ðàçâåäêó, [LINK=UNIT_GALLEON]ãàëåîí[\LINK] - ñ ãðóçîì, è òàê äàëåå. Âîçìîæíîñòè êàæäîãî òèïà [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]þíèòîâ[\LINK] ïåðå÷èñëåíû â åãî ðàçäåëå Öèâèëîïåäèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âûäåëåíèå íåñêîëüêèõ þíèòîâ[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìîæíî âûäåëèòü íåñêîëüêî þíèòîâ è îòäàòü èì îáùèé ïðèêàç. Äëÿ ýòîãî îíè äîëæíû íàõîäèòüñÿ íà îäíîé êëåòêå. Ùåëêíèòå îäèí þíèò, çàòåì îñòàëüíûå, óäåðæèâàÿ êëàâèøó Shift - îíè òîæå áóäóò âûäåëåíû.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Äâèæåíèå ãðóïï þíèòîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè âûäåëèòü íåñêîëüêî þíèòîâ è ïðèêàçàòü èì ïåðåìåùàòüñÿ, îíè îòïðàâÿòñÿ âìåñòå ñî ñêîðîñòüþ ñàìîãî òèõîõîäíîãî â ãðóïïå. (Ñ ïîñåëåíöåì ðàçóìíî îòïðàâëÿòü âîåííûé þíèò äëÿ çàùèòû îò âñòðå÷íûõ çâåðåé è âàðâàðîâ.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Áîé ãðóïï þíèòîâ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ïðèêàçàòü ãðóïïå þíèòîâ íàïàñòü íà âðàæåñêèé þíèò, àòàêîâàòü áóäåò ñàìûé ìîùíûé þíèò â ãðóïïå. Â ñëó÷àå íåóäà÷è àòàêà ïðåêðàòèòñÿ, à ÷òîáû ïðîäîëæèòü, ïðèäåòñÿ ïîâòîðèòü ïðèêàç îñòàâøèìñÿ. Íî åñëè â íàñòðîéêàõ èãðû ðàçðåøèòü ñîâìåñòíûå àòàêè, þíèòû íàïàäóò ñîâìåñòíî è ñðàçó äîâåäóò áîé äî êîíöà.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Ãðóïïû þíèòîâ è îáúåêòû[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ìîæíî âûäåëèòü íåñêîëüêèõ ðàáîòíèêîâ è íàïðàâèòü èõ íà îáúåêò; âìåñòå îíè ïîñòðîÿò îáúåêò ãîðàçäî áûñòðåå.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Íàâûêè[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîáåäà ïðèíîñèò áîåâîìó þíèòó åäèíèöû îïûòà, à äîñòàòî÷íûé îïûò - [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]íàâûêè[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Òèïû þíèòîâ [\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèòû äåëÿòñÿ íà òèïû; íàïðèìåð, [LINK=UNIT_MUSKETMAN]ìóøêåòåðû[\LINK] îòíîñÿòñÿ ê îãíåñòðåëüíûì þíèòàì, à [LINK=UNIT_KNIGHT]ðûöàðè[\LINK] ê êîííûì. Ìíîãèå ñïîñîáíîñòè è íàâûêè îòíîñÿòñÿ ê öåëûì òèïàì. Òàê, [LINK=UNIT_SPEARMAN]êîïüåíîñöû[\LINK] èìåþò èçíà÷àëüíîå ïðåèìóùåñòâî ïåðåä êîííûìè þíèòàìè, à êâàëèôèêàöèÿ [LINK=PROMOTION_SHOCK]Øîê[\LINK] ïðèáàâëÿåò 25% ïðîòèâ ïåõîòíûõ þíèòîâ. Ïîäðîáíåå ñì. [LINK=PEDIA_MAIN_PROMOTION]Íàâûêè[\LINK] è îïèñàíèÿ îòäåëüíûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: [H1]Units[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, the term "unit" refers to anything that can move around the map. There are a number of different types of units in play - military units, work units, missionaries and great people - with military units forming the bulk of them.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Unit Statistics[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]All units have two basic statistics (or "stats"): movement speed and combat strength.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Movement Speed[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A unit's movement speed determines how quickly the unit can move around the map. Movement speeds generally range from 1 to 8. Some units have movement speeds of 0, which indicates that these units have special rules governing their movement. See the section on [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Movement[\LINK] for details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Combat Strength[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A unit's combat strength determines how tough the unit is when fighting an enemy unit. Combat strengths range from 1 to 40, and this base strength can be affected by many modifiers (see [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat[\LINK]). Some units have combat strengths of 0, which indicates that the unit cannot fight or has special rules governing combat. See the section on [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Combat[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Acquiring Units[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can obtain units in a number of ways:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Game Start[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You have two or more units at the start of a game. At least one of these units is a settler; the remainder are workers or military units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Tribal Villages[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You may gain a new unit when one of your units enters a tribal village. (Or you may gain gold, technology, or experience - or the village may be hostile and generate barbarians to attack your unit.)[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Capturing Units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=UNIT_WORKER]Workers[\LINK] and [LINK=UNIT_SETTLER]Settlers[\LINK] are automatically captured when attacked by a military unit, or when they are in a city that is captured. (Note that settler units turn into workers when captured.)[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Constructing Units in Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You construct most of your units in [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK]. See below.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Generating Units in Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Your cities generate [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] units automatically. See that section for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Gifts from other Civilizations[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Very rarely, a civilization may give you a unit.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Constructing Units in Cities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]As discussed above, most of your units come from your cities. Cities also construct buildings (plus other specialized items). They can only construct one item at a time - balancing the need for units against the need for buildings is crucial to your success in the game. Following is some information about constructing units; more can be found in the [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK] entry.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Choosing Units to Construct[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When a city is ready to begin constructing a new unit or building, the city construction menu appears. This lists everything that you can construct in that city, as well as the time required for construction. Click on the unit/building you wish to build and the city will begin construction immediately. If you wish to change what a city is constructing, go to the city screen and click on the new item you wish to build.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unit Availability[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Not all units are available for construction at the start of the game. Many units have [LINK=CONCEPT_TECHNOLOGY]Technological[\LINK] requirements, and some units require that you have access to one or more [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]Resources[\LINK]; for example, you cannot build a [LINK=UNIT_SWORDSMAN]Swordsman[\LINK] until you have researched [LINK=TECH_IRON_WORKING]Iron Working[\LINK] and have access to [LINK=BONUS_IRON]Iron[\LINK]. Also, a few units have [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Building[\LINK] and/or [LINK=CONCEPT_RELIGION]Religious[\LINK] prerequisites.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Construction Time[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A unit's construction time is based upon the city's [LINK=CONCEPT_PRODUCTION]Production[\LINK]. The greater the amount of production a city has, the faster it can train new units.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unit Support Costs[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The number of free units you will be able to have is affected by the Difficulty Level you are playing. Once you have surpassed the number of free units you are awarded, you will be charged per unit over your free unit total. Each unit costs one gold per turn to maintain.
